Type II Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 12 years ago and under control with oral anti-diabetic drugs (Metformin 1000 mg twice daily). 3. High Cholesterol: Diagnosed 10 years ago and being managed with a statin medication (Atorvastatin 20 mg daily). 4. Overweight: He has a BMI of 28 and is on a weight loss regimen. 5. He was a heavy smoker but quit 5 years ago.  IV. Family Medical History: 1. Father died of myocardial infarction at age 65. 2. Mother with well-controlled hypertension and lives independently at the age of 88. 3. His elder brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his late 50s is stable post coronary artery bypass grafting surgery.  In summary  Mr. Walker is a 62-year-old male patient with an extensive past medical history including hypertension  type II diabetes  high cholesterol  and a positive family history of coronary artery disease. These factors along with his history of smoking have possibly contributed to his current symptoms of chest pain suggestive of coronary artery disease. Further evaluation and management strategies need to be implemented in light of his high-risk profile.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease Patient Presentation  Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the clinic with a complaint of recurring chest discomfort.  Demographics:   The patient is a retired accountant and married with three adult children. He lives in a suburban area in Pennsylvania and has been generally in good health until the last two years. He is a non-smoker and moderate drinker. Upon discussion  he revealed a family history of heart diseases; his father passed away from a myocardial infarction at an age of 65.  Clinical History:  Mr. Doe was first diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia five years ago during a routine check-up  after which he was put on pharmaceutical therapy to control his low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels. However  his drug compliance rate has been reported to be inconsistent. He struggles with the consumption of fast food which may have contributed to the progression of his initial cluster of symptoms - dyspnea  fatigue  and shortness of breath - which were first noticed around two years ago. With the exacerbation of symptoms  he sought medical service a year ago and post-consultation was advised dietary modification and lifestyle changes. However  his stubborn adherence to previously established habits notably diminished overall adherence. Hence  the chest discomfort he is experiencing right now.  Investigations:  Candidate for further clinical investigations such as electrocardiogram (ECG)  coronary angiogram  and blood tests to confirm the diagnosis of coronary artery disease. Other laboratory tests to be considered would be liver and thyroid function tests and a complete lipid profile.  Current Status:  The patient is currently taking statins and aspirin as per prescription. He has also been advised to lose weight  do moderate exercise  and adopt a heart-healthy diet including the consumption of whole grains  lean meats  low-fat dairy products  and a high proportion of fruits and vegetables.  In summary  we can see that the non-compliance to treatment  maintained consumption of unhealthy diet  and his genetic predisposition have combined and contributed to his current cardiological complaints. His case coins the need for a multi-dimensional approach in managing coronary artery diseases  drawing from both pharmacotherapeutic advances and lifestyle interventions. He is advised to closely follow through the treatment and further assessments will be carried out to ascertain/prognosticate his cardiac health.

Patient Presentation  Gender: Male  Age: 60 years old  Ethnicity: African-American  Employment Status: Retired – Former Corporate Manager  Insurance: Medicare  Marital Status: Married  Patient lives with his wife in a suburban home; both his wife and one of his two adult children  who live in the same city  are close and reliable sources of support.  Presenting Issue: The patient has been experiencing intermittent chest discomfort  neck and jaw pain  as well as occasional shortness of breath  primarily during physical activities.  Past Medical History: The patient reports a history of hypertension for the past 15 years  managed successfully with lisinopril. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus  treated with metformin  and a history of hyperlipidemia for which he is on atorvastatin.  Lifestyle: The patient is a former smoker with a 20-pack-per-year history. He quit smoking 10 years ago. The patient drinks alcohol socially  reporting an average of 2-3 drinks per week. He admits he has a sedentary lifestyle  finding it difficult to engage in regular physical activities due to his demanding former job.  Family History: His father died at the age of 66 from a myocardial infarction. His mother has a history of hypertension and stroke. Both his siblings have hypertension  and his older brother has type 2 diabetes. His younger son (age 28) has recently been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia.  In summary  this is a 60-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hyperlipidemia that presents with chest discomfort  neck and jaw pain  and occasional shortness of breath which are indicative of likely Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Given these symptoms and his strong family history of cardiac disease  along with other risk factors such as a history of smoking  his sedentary lifestyle  and his past medical history  a thorough evaluation for possible CAD is necessary.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 62-year-old male named John Smith. Mr. Smith is a Caucasian and a retired mechanical engineer who resides in Austin  Texas. He has lived in the United States for his entire life.  Mr. Smith presented to the clinic complaining of recurrent chest pains that radiate to his left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath during his usual morning walks. The pain is usually relieved by rest and intensified by physical activities. The intensity of pain is gradually increasing over the past two months. He also reported episodes of early morning profuse sweating.  He has a past medical history of hypertension  diagnosed 10 years ago  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago. He also experienced dyslipidemia  with high LDL cholesterol levels diagnosed approximately 8 years back. He has been on medications for all these health issues. Mr. Smith underwent an appendectomy in his twenties and denied any other surgical history.  Unfortunately  Mr. Smith has a history of smoking about a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years  although he has cut back significantly in the past 7 years to about 3-4 cigarettes per day. He used to consume alcohol moderately but quit 6 years ago.  Mr. Smith has a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD). His father died at the age of 71 due to a heart attack  and his older brother had a bypass surgery at the age of 65. His mother has a history of hypertension and his younger sister is diabetic.  Considering his presenting symptoms  past medical history  lifestyle  and family history  he was evaluated for CAD. Subsequent ras to his echocardiogram  EKG and stress tests confirmed critical narrowing of his coronary arteries which are suggestive of CAD. His blood cholesterol and blood sugar levels are also elevated despite being on medication.  The patient is recommended for cardiac catheterization for a more definitive diagnosis and further exclusion of other cardiac diseases. He was also advised to make lifestyle modifications like smoking cessation  weight management  a heart-healthy diet  and regular exercise to manage and prevent further progress of his CAD.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. John Doe  is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents with symptoms highly suggestive of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Mr. Doe hails from an urban setting in New York City where he lives alone. His occupation involves limited physical activity as he is retired after serving lengthy tenure as a realtor. Mr. Doe is a widower with two grown-up children residing outside of the state.   Symptoms:  Major symptoms Mr. Doe experiences include shortness of breath on exertion  palpitation  and chest discomfort mainly described as a dull ache. The chest discomfort sensation slightly radiates to his left arm and subsides with rest. He also reports episodes of indigestion and extreme fatigue after minimal physical activities.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history. He is a long-term hypertensive patient with poor compliance due to doubtful medication dependence. In addition to that  he was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) around ten years ago which he has had difficulty managing due to an inconsistent diet strategy. Records showcase recurrent hospital admissions due to fluctuating blood sugar levels. Furthermore  he is a former heavy smoker who quit 5 years ago but doesn't exercise religiously due to existing comorbidities.   Family History:  His family history is also significant with his father succumbing to myocardial infarction at 70 and his mother to strokes at her early 60s. His older brother also suffers from CAD but is managing it with medication and lifestyle changes.   Risk factors:  Major risk factors for CAD in Mr. Doe include advancing age  gender (male)  hypertension  T2DM  tobacco use  sedentary lifestyle  and significant family history of cardiovascular diseases.   The clinical presentation  past medical history  and risk factors collectively contribute to a high level of suspicion for the onset of CAD in Mr. Doe. Further diagnostic workup is warranted to enhance our understanding of his current health status and to commence the most appropriate management plan.   The goal for Mr. Doe's treatment will be to manage his symptoms  slow down or stop the progression of CAD  lower the risk of future heart disease-related events  and improve his quality of life. This will hopefully be achieved through a combination of lifestyle changes  medication management  and possibly  revascularization procedures.

Patient Presentation:  I would like to present a case of a 58-year-old male patient  Mr. John who is Native American residing at New Mexico  United States. He has been presenting with symptoms indicative of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Mr. John is an ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago  but had a smoking history of 20 years. He works as an administrative executive in a local firm and leads a sedentary lifestyle  with infrequent physical exercise. He reports that over the past four months  he experiences episodes of chest pain  especially when performing physical activities or under stress.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and dyslipidemia  both diagnosed six years ago and being managed with Enalapril and Atorvastatin respectively. In spite of medication  his blood pressure and cholesterol levels have not been well-controlled. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.   On the anthropometric front  he has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28 kg/m²  placing him in the overweight category. His waist circumference is 104 cm  suggesting abdominal obesity.  His diet mostly includes high-fat and high-sodium foods. He admits to rarely consuming fruits  vegetables or whole grain products. He also reveals moderate alcohol consumption  about two drinks per day.  To summarize  Mr. John is a hypertensive and dyslipidemic patient with a family history of CAD  presenting with classic symptoms of angina  leading to a presumptive diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease. His risk factors include his age  male gender  Native American ethnicity  sedentary lifestyle  past history of smoking  elevated blood pressure and lipid levels  family history of CAD  overweight and abdominal obesity  poor diet  and moderate alcohol consumption. He requires a thorough evaluation for confirming the diagnosis and management of his condition.

Patient Profile:   Ms. Eleanor Summers  a 65-year-old Caucasian female  presented herself at our facility  complaining of chest discomfort. She reports experiencing chest pain on exertion for the last six weeks  along with shortness of breath and occasional dizziness. Further  she mentioned that these symptoms often subside with rest.  Medical history:  Ms. Summers is a retired nurse and has been a widow for five years. She lives alone  but her two adult children live nearby. She has a 15-year smoking history  but quit ten years ago. A known hypertensive  she has been using amlodipine 10mg daily for the last five years without any reported side effects. She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus three years ago  managed with metformin 500mg twice daily.   Family history:  She has a strong family history of cardiovascular disease. Her father lost his life due to myocardial infarction at age 62  and her elder brother is living with angioplasty.  Physical examination:  Ms. Summers is overweight (BMI: 28.5) with a blood pressure of 135/85mmHg. She has bilateral pitting pedal edema  and a regular heart rhythm was noted at a rate of 80 beats/min. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  This history and clinical findings are indicative of coronary artery disease (CAD)  but further diagnostic evaluation is essential to confirm and determine the extent of the disease.  Presentation conclusion:   Ms. Summers is showing symptoms that could be consistent with coronary artery disease. Given her age  family history  past medical history of hypertension and diabetes  and her previous cigarette smoking  she is at a higher risk for cardiac complications. The healthcare team will need to ensure comprehensive assessment  timely diagnosis  risk stratification  and a management plan to improve her quality of life and prevent potential complications. Future patient education and lifestyle modifications like a healthy diet  regular physical activity  and weight management  will also form an essential part of her ongoing supportive care.

Patient Presentation:   I have here a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. John Doe who is presenting with symptoms suggestive of coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient has been experiencing intermittent episodes of chest pain for the last six weeks  especially after engaging in moderate physical activities. These episodes are often accompanied by shortness of breath and sometimes  excessive sweating. He also reports of light-headedness and occasional dizziness.  In terms of past medical history  he was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 8 years ago. Unfortunately  his compliance to the prescribed antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications has been inconsistent. He underwent a stress test four years ago due to similar but less intense symptoms  which showed negative results for ischemia at that time.   Mr. Doe is a retired engineer  lives with his wife and maintains a sedentary lifestyle. He has a 40 pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit a year ago. He reports regular consumption of alcohol on social occasions only  and denied illicit drug use. His father suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his mother from a stroke at the age of 75.  Recent laboratory tests showed elevated LDL cholesterol levels of 160 mg/dL and moderately raised blood pressure values averaging 155/90 mmHg. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is noted as 28.2  placing him in the overweight category.  In summary  Mr. Doe is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who now presented with symptoms suggestive of coronary artery disease. His risk factors include age  male gender  family history  elevated LDL cholesterol levels  hypertension  history of tobacco usage  sedentary lifestyle  and overweight status. The possibility of a coronary artery disease is worrying especially due to his number of major risk factors  hence necessitating further diagnostic evaluation.

Title: Case Presentation of Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Patient's Profile: Name: Mr. John Anderson Age: 65 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanic  Chief Complaint: Complains of frequent chest pain and discomfort  particularly upon exertion.  Present Illness: Episodes of chest pain have been occurring for over six months but have recently increased in frequency. Associated symptoms include dyspnea  fatigue  light-headedness and mild nausea.  Past Medical History: Known hypertensive for ten years  controlled with medication. Diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes five years ago  managed with Metformin. No known history of any other diseases.   Family History: Father suffered from myocardial infarction at age 62. Elder brother also has a history of coronary artery disease.  Social History: 40 pack-years smoking history  quit 5 years ago. Consumes alcohol moderately. No illicit drug use. Limited physical activity.  Review of Systems: Oral hypoglycemic for diabetes has been helpful in maintaining controlled blood glucose levels  but there are slight fluctuations occasionally. Compliance with antihypertensive treatment is satisfactory. No complaints of palpitations or syncopal attacks. Gastrointestinal system essentially normal.   Physical Examination: Patient is comfortable at rest. Slightly obese. Vital signs: BP - 140/90 mmHg  PR - 90/min  RR - 18/min  Temp - 98.2 F. Cardiac auscultation normal with no added sounds  murmurs or rubs. Chest clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdomen soft and non-tender.  In conclusion  Mr. Anderson is presenting with classic angina symptoms. His medical history  including hypertension  diabetes  and familial predisposition reinforce the likelihood of coronary artery disease. Further cardiovascular evaluation is warranted to confirm the diagnosis and elaborate the plan of management. The patient will also benefit from lifestyle modification counseling.

Title: Case Presentation of Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Introduction: Mr. John Doe  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented to our outpatient clinic. He is a resident of Victoria  BC  and a retired school teacher. He lives with his wife and maintains an active lifestyle.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Doe's primary complaint was of recurrent episodes of chest discomfort that he described as heavy  central pressure-like pain. The episodes often occurred during exertion  such as when climbing stairs or walking briskly and were relieved by rest within 5 minutes.  Demographics: Mr. Doe has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which was diagnosed about ten years ago  and hyperlipidemia  which was diagnosed five years ago. He had a 20-pack-per-year history of smoking  but quit smoking ten years ago. Additionally  he has a family history of cardiovascular disease – his father experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Clinical Assessment: Clinical examination was largely unremarkable. His blood pressure was slightly elevated  measuring 140/90 mmHg  but otherwise he presented stable vital signs.   Past Medical History: His long-term issues with hypertension and hyperlipidemia have usually been well-controlled with a combination of lifestyle modification and medication (a thiazide diuretic for hypertension and a statin for hyperlipidemia). He is up-to-date on his vaccinations and undergoes annual physical exams. He has no known drug allergies.  Evaluation: Considering patient's age  clinical presentation with exercise-induced angina  history of smoking  a family history of early-onset coronary artery disease  and chronic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the suspicion for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) is high.   Conclusion: Mr. Doe has been recommended for further diagnostic evaluation with stress testing and  if indicated  coronary angiography to confirm the suspicion of CAD and to identify the severity and extent of the disease. His current medication regimen will be reviewed and potentially adjusted. Mr. Doe has been advised to continue a heart-healthy lifestyle  including regular exercise  eating a diet rich in fruits  vegetables  whole grains  and lean proteins; and maintaining a healthy weight.

Patient Presentation: Mr. John Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to our clinic today with complaints of persistent chest pain worsening over the last few months. The patient describes the pain as a heavy and tight sensation occuring primarily in the central portion of the chest  which frequently radiates to the left arm and neck. The pain is usually triggered by physical exertion or intense emotional stress and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin administration.  Patient’s pertinent medical history includes hypertension (diagnosed 10 years ago)  Type 2 diabetes mellitus (diagnosed 7 years ago)  and hypercholesterolemia (diagnosed 5 years ago). All conditions have been consistently managed with pharmaceutical intervention including ACE inhibitors  metformin  and statin therapy  respectively. The patient is a former smoker (20 packs/year)  quit 15 years ago. He admits that he consumes alcohol occasionally and leads a sub-optimally active lifestyle. The patient’s father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.   Physical examination reveals a mildly overweight man with a body mass index (BMI) of 27. His vitals on presentation are: Blood pressure - 140/90mmHg (despite on antihypertensives)  pulse - 78 beats/minute  regular and respiratory rate - 16 breaths/minute. A cardiovascular exam demonstrates no overt abnormalities  with normal heart sounds  no murmurs  and no signs of heart failure.  In conclusion  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old male with a pertinent medical history significant for multiple cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  Type 2 diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  personal smoking history  and a family history of coronary artery disease. As such  his recurrent and predictable chest pain with characteristics of angina pectoris  especially with known cardiac risk factors  are highly suggestive of coronary artery disease. The ongoing management plan involves further cardiologic evaluation  lifestyle modifications along with optimization of his antihypertensive  antihyperglycaemic  and lipid-lowering regimens.

Slide 1: Introduction  Today we are discussing the case of a 67-year-old Caucasian male patient diagnosed with advanced coronary artery disease (CAD).  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  The patient is a retired construction worker  non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumer  mainly of wine and beer. He has a height of 175 cm and weighs 85 kg. Blood pressure readings have been consistently around 140/90 mmHg. He lives in a suburban area with his wife who is a primary caregiver. He is a father to three adult children and has six grandchildren.   Slide 3: Medical History  The patient has a history of high cholesterol  which has been managed with statins for the past 15 years  and well-controlled Type 2 diabetes which was diagnosed approximately 10 years ago. One key point in his past medical history is a heart attack he suffered five years ago. It resulted in a hospital stay in which a coronary angioplasty with stent placement was successfully performed in one of his coronary arteries.   Slide 4: Family History  The patient's father had advanced CAD  which led to his death at the age of 69. The patient's mother lived up to 82 years  dying from a stroke. Two older siblings are alive with no known cardiovascular diseases. One younger brother died of a heart attack at an early age of 52.  Slide 5: Current Medical Condition  Currently  the patient suffers from symptoms suggestive of angina; he experiences chest discomfort and shortness of breath during exertion like climbing stairs but is relieved at rest. Recently  these symptoms have been experienced more frequently and with less physical stress. Medications currently prescribed include aspirin  metformin for diabetes  and atorvastatin for cholesterol.   Slide 6: Discussion  Given the patient's demographic profile  medical history  family history  and ongoing symptoms  his management presents both challenges and opportunities. These include lifestyle modification  optimizing medical therapy  and consideration for further intervention to manage his coronary artery disease effectively.

Patient Presentation: We are discussing the case of Mr. John Sturgess  a 64-year-old Caucasian male from Houston  Texas  who has presented with symptoms consistent with coronary artery disease (CAD). His symptoms include episodes of chest pain  particularly upon physical exertion  shortness of breath  fatigue  and excessive sweating.   Demographics:  Mr. Sturgess is an electrical engineer by profession and is now semi-retired. He is married and has two children. He is a non-smoker but admits to consuming alcohol occasionally. His family history is significant with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67 and his mother having had hypertension.   Past Medical History and Lifestyle: Mr. Sturgess has a medical history of type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed eight years ago  for which he is on oral hypoglycemic medication. He also has a five-year history of hypertension  controlled with amlodipine. He does not report any known drug allergies. Additionally  Mr. Sturgess acknowledges that he does not participate in regular physical activity and follows a diet that is high in sugar and processed foods. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is within the obese range  at 31.               Emerging Clinical Picture: By considering Mr. Sturgess's age  family history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and sedentary lifestyle  he is considered at high risk for coronary artery disease. His current symptoms underscore the likelihood of this diagnosis.   Moving forward with this potential diagnosis  we need to further investigate with diagnostic tests such as electrocardiogram  cardiac stress tests  and coronary angiogram  among others. Tailoring a comprehensive and effective management plan involving lifestyle modifications  medication optimization  and possibly involving angioplasty or bypass surgery could greatly improve the quality and longevity of Mr. Sturgess's life.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: Mr. John Matthews is a 61-year-old Caucasian male currently residing in the suburban community of Nashville  Tennessee. He is a retired accountant who enjoys golfing and gardening in his leisure time and has a prior smoking history of about 30 years  having quit smoking 10 years ago.   Medical History: Mr. Matthews had been comparatively healthy until five years ago when he was diagnosed with Stage 2 hypertension. Despite being prescribed antihypertensive medications  his blood pressure has remained mildly elevated. During a routine follow-up visit  Mr. Matthews complained of occasional chest discomfort during physical exertion which subsided during rest. Angina pectoris was suspected and he was further evaluated.  Family History: His family history revealed that his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65 and his mother has a history of diabetes mellitus. His older brother also had a premature coronary artery disease diagnosed at the age of 55.  Clinical Presentation:  Two weeks back  Mr. Matthews experienced a severe episode of chest pain  which radiated to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms included profuse sweating and shortness of breath. He was taken to the nearby emergency department and was found to have an elevated troponin level suggesting an acute coronary syndrome.  Other Significant Medical History:  Mr. Matthews has a history of hyperlipidemia. His BMI indicates he is overweight with a value of 27.5. His lipid profile checked 3 months ago revealed elevated levels of LDL cholesterol. Despite the initiation of statin therapy  his cholesterol levels remained relatively high.   He is currently on Aspirin  Metoprolol  and Atorvastatin. He doesn't have any known allergies. He consumes alcohol socially but denies any current substance abuse issues. He has been married for 35 years  has two children  and lives a relatively sedentary lifestyle.  Current Diagnosis:  Given his age  gender  family history  hypertensive and hyperlipidemia status  together with the strong clinical presentation and the elevated cardiac enzymes  Mr. John Matthews has been diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: The patient under review is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. John Smith  who has presented with symptoms indicative of coronary artery disease. He is a retired construction worker and currently residing in Bethesda  Maryland with his wife.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith reports experiencing occasional discomfort in his chest that he describes as ""a heavy pressure "" along with shortness of breath  especially during exertion. These symptoms have been frequent for the last two months but seem to have increased in severity over the last week.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history  including type 2 diabetes mellitus  which was diagnosed 10 years ago and is currently managed with metformin. He was diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  managed with lisinopril. He also has a 40-pack year history of smoking but quit five years prior to this evaluation. There is no history of previous surgeries.   Family History: He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died at age 70 from a heart attack and an older brother is living with congestive heart failure.   Social History: Mr. Smith has a history of heavy tobacco use but no history of alcohol or illicit drug use. He reports a sedentary lifestyle since retiring five years ago and admits to a diet high in fats and carbohydrates.  Review of Systems: Positive for chest discomfort  shortness of breath  and easy fatigability. Negative for fever  cough  palpitations  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  lower limb swelling  nosocomial weight gain  or syncope.  Current Medications: Mr. Smith is currently on Metformin (500mg twice a day) for his type 2 diabetes and Lisinopril (20mg once daily) for hypertension.  Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable with a BP of 140/90mmHg  pulse rate 85bpm  respiratory rate 18bpm  temperature 98.2F  and BMI at 29. Cardiac auscultation reveals a normal S1 and S2 with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary  abdominal  and neurological examinations are within normal limits.  Conclusion: In summary  Mr. Smith's symptoms  risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  past smoking history  family history of cardiovascular disease  and lifestyle suggest a probable diagnosis of coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic evaluation with electrocardiogram  echocardiogram and coronary angiography is recommended to confirm the diagnosis and decide the optimum therapeutic strategy.

Title: Patient Presentation on Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 65 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired banker Ethnicity: African-American Residential Location: Urban  New York City  Presenting Problem:  The patient has been reporting a frequent feeling of exhaustion during mild physical activities and shortness of breath for the last six months. In recent weeks  he also expressed experiencing unspecific chest pain and discomfort.   Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and has been on medication since then. His blood pressure remains borderline with occasional spikes.  2. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: He was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes five years ago. His glycemic levels are not well-controlled due to his non-compliance with prescribed dietary changes.  3. Dyslipidemia: A year ago  the patient had elevated triglyceride levels and low-density lipoprotein-cholesterol levels  for which he was advised lifestyle changes but has been inconsistent in implementing these changes.  4. No known allergies.  5. No history of surgeries.  6. The patient is an ex-smoker and quit smoking 20 years ago. He admits to daily alcohol consumption.   Family History: His father had an myocardial infarction at the age of 68. His mother has well controlled Type II diabetes. One older sibling died from stroke.  Current Situation: Given his medical history along with his symptoms of fatigue  shortness of breath  and consistent chest discomfort  a strong suspicion of Coronary Artery Disease arises. ECG and subsequent investigations will be carried out to establish the diagnosis and evaluate the extent of cardiac damage. The patient’s persistent unhealthy lifestyle habits could have contributed to this potential diagnosis and it’s crucial to address this with him. Patient education is paramount in managing primary and secondary risk factors and preventing further progression of disease.   Treatment recommendations will depend on diagnostic test results. At the very least  it will be crucial for Mr. Johnson to make lifestyle changes  such as adopting healthy eating habits and regular physical activity  monitoring glucose levels  managing stress and abstaining from alcohol.

Title: Patient Presentation: 63-Year-old Male with Coronary Artery Disease  I. Introduction We present the case of a 63-year-old African American male  Mr. Smith  with a diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Mr. Smith is a retired school teacher  born and residing in Houston Texas  married with 3 children. He is a non-smoker  drinks moderate wine on social occasions  and does not use recreational drugs. He has a family history of CAD - both his father and older brother having suffered from heart attacks in their late fifties.  II. Clinical History Mr. Smith was diagnosed with CAD at the age of 59 following bouts of chest pain (angina) during physical exertion. The diagnosis was confirmed through a coronary angiogram that showed two of his coronary arteries had 70% blockage.  III. Past Medical History Mr. Smith has a history of high blood pressure and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medication. He also suffered a minor ischemic stroke at the age of 61  with no significant residual neurological deficits. In addition  he was diagnosed with moderate obesity (BMI of 32)  and elevated cholesterol levels.  IV. Recent Medical Examinations and Laboratory Findings His most recent physical examination showed a blood pressure of 130/80 mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per minute  BMI of 30. Laboratory findings include an HbA1c of 7.2%  fasting blood sugar of 130 mg/dl  LDL of 140 mg/dl  HDL of 38 mg/dl  and triglycerides of 180 mg/dl. His EKG showed non-specific ST-T wave changes.  V. Current Medication Mr. Smith is currently on aspirin  a beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  an ACE inhibitor (Lisinopril)  a cholesterol-lowering statin (Atorvastatin)  and an oral hypoglycemic agent (Metformin) for his diabetes.  VI. Summary In summary  Mr. Smith is a 63-year-old African American male with a history of CAD  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  stroke  and hyperlipidemia - all risk factors for the progression of CAD. He is on appropriate medical management for his condition with regular follow-ups to monitor his status and adjust treatment as required. Mr. Smith's case underscores the importance of regular monitoring and proactive management of CAD risk factors.

Presentation of patient:  Patient's name is Mr. John Baily  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer by profession  residing at Springfield  Massachusetts. Mr. Baily presented with complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  and fatigue  especially during physical exertion. He reports that the chest pain is a squeezing type  frequently radiating towards the arm and jaw.   His medical history reveals he has been hypertensive for the past ten years and type two diabetic for the past five years. Both hypertension and diabetes are relatively controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg once daily for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for T2DM). Mr. Baily has been a smoker for approximately 40 years with a 20-pack-year history. His family history reveals his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  indicating a possible genetic predisposition.   In terms of his lifestyle  he follows a diet high in fat and cholesterol and has a sedentary lifestyle with little regular exercise. He admits to consuming alcohol but denies any illicit drug use. He has no known drug allergies.  Conclusion: Considering his clinical presentation  past medical history and lifestyle  the preliminary diagnosis for Mr. Baily is Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). His hypertensive and diabetic conditions  along with his smoking history  familial predisposition  age  unhealthy diet  and lack of regular physical exercise  make him a high-risk candidate for the disease. Further investigations like ECG  echocardiogram or angiogram may be necessary for a definitive diagnosis and to decide the management plan. Prompt lifestyle modifications are recommended to prevent disease progression.

Patient Presentation Overview:   Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Sex: Male Age: 64 years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Medical History:  Mr. John Doe  a 64-year-old retired engineer  has walked into the clinic today reporting discomfort and tightness in his chest that appears to radiate to his left arm. The symptoms often seem aggravated while performing activities and mildly recede when he takes rest. He also mentioned episodes of shortness of breath accompanied by fatigue which occur particularly during physical exertion. He confirms the symptoms have been occurring for the past few weeks.  His past medical history is significant with diagnosed hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 10 years. He had a smoking habit of 20 cigarettes per day for the past 30 years but quit smoking about 5 years ago. He also occasionally consumes alcohol  especially during social gatherings. He doesn't engage in regular physical exercises and has a family history of coronary artery disease  his father having experienced a heart attack at the age of 60.   Mr. Doe's current medication regimen includes Metformin  Lisinopril  and a daily low-dose aspirin.  Patient's vital signs upon preliminary examination today are as follows: Temperature: 98.6°F   Blood Pressure: 156/96 mmHg   Resting Heart Rate: 85 beats per minute   Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths per minute   Oxygen Saturation: 95%.  Based on the symptoms presented  his significant medical history  and his lifestyle factors  it is strongly suspected that Mr. Doe may be having stable angina which could be an indication of advanced coronary artery disease (CAD). It is recommended that he perform further diagnostic tests including an electrocardiogram (ECG)  a stress test  and a coronary angiography if needed  to further investigate and confirm the diagnosis of CAD. His current blood pressure also requires immediate attention and adjustment of his treatment plan.

Patient Presentation: John Doe  Demographic Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 56-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today complaining of recurring chest pain. He is an accountant by profession and lives in the suburbs with his wife and two adult children. Mr. Doe is a former smoker with a pack-year history of 20 years. He quit smoking ten years ago but confesses to leading a sedentary lifestyle with moderate alcohol consumption on weekends. Mr. Doe has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 62  and his elder brother also has coronary artery disease.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with type II diabetes for the last 8 years  which is moderately controlled with metformin. He is also taking medication for hypertension diagnosed five years ago. His last checkup was around six months ago  and his BP was relatively controlled at 130/85 mmHg. His LDL was 150 mg/dL  and his HDL was 40 mg/dL.   Regarding the chest pain  he mentions bouts of discomfort  tightness  and heaviness within his chest region that comes and goes. The intensity varies from mild to severe  particularly during physical or emotional stress. The discomfort sometimes radiates down his left arm and up to his neck.  In conclusion  considering Mr. Doe's age  medical history  family history  lifestyle  and presenting symptoms  he is at a high risk of coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic tests  including ECG  stress test  and possibly coronary angiography  would be beneficial for confirmation. A comprehensive plan encompassing pharmacological treatment  dietary modification  exercise prescription  and possibly revascularization procedures may be needed depending on the severity of his coronary artery disease. Therapeutic goals should focus on relief of symptoms  slowing progression of the disease  and reducing future risks like myocardial infarction.

Presentation of Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: The patient is Mr. James Walker  a 65-year-old Caucasian male who is retired. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He lives with his wife  has 2 children  and 3 grandchildren. He has a past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which has been managed with medications for the past 10 years.   Chief Complaint: Mr. Walker presents today with a 2-week history of persistent chest pain that he describes as ""squeezing"" in nature. The pain radiates to his left arm and is accompanied by episodes of shortness of breath  especially on moderate exertion like walking up stairs or lifting something heavy.  Past Medical History: Mr. Walker has a diagnosis of hypertension diagnosed 16 years ago and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago. These conditions are being managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 20mg daily. He was also prescribed low-dose Aspirin as a preventative measure 5 years ago. There is no history of any major surgeries  hospitalizations or any known drug allergies.   Family History: He has a strong family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having suffered a heart attack at age 62 and his mother suffering from stroke at age 68. His older brother  aged 67  was diagnosed with coronary artery disease two years ago.  Lifestyle: Mr. Walker has a sedentary lifestyle and has been advised regularly about the importance of exercise and physical activity. His diet consists mainly of high carbohydrate foods and he admits that he struggles with portion control.   Physical Examination: At this visit  his Blood Pressure readings are 145/85 mmHg  Pulse is regular with a rate of 88 beats/min  respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min  BMI is 28  and SpO2 is 96% at room air. Cardiac examination reveals normal heart sounds without any murmurs or gallops.   Impression: Given his symptoms - persistent chest pain and shortness of breath on exertion  along with his risk factors - hypertension  history of diabetes  family history of cardiovascular diseases and sedentary lifestyle  there is a high probability of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further diagnostic testing such as Electrocardiogram and Stress Test would be necessary to confirm diagnosis and determine the severity of CAD.

Patient Presentation  Good afternoon  Today I’m presenting a case of Mr. John Doe  a 56-year-old Caucasian male. He is a resident of Springfield  Massachusetts working as an accountant.  Mr. Doe has presented to us today with complaints of heavy and discomforting chest pain radiating towards his left arm for the past two weeks. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  fatigue  dizziness  and irregular heartbeats. He is notably a smoker for the past 40 years and an occasional drinker. His daily diet includes high-fat fast food and has led to obesity  with a BMI of 32.  Noteworthy aspects in his past medical history include Hypertension for the past three years which is controlled through medication. Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed seven years ago  he is currently on oral hypoglycemic agents. He also had a minor stroke approximately two years ago which did not cause any significant long-term effects. There is a familial history of heart disease; his father passed away due to a heart attack at the age of 63.  His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and low-dose aspirin due to his stroke history. He does not have any reported allergies. His vaccination history is up-to-date.  Physical examination reveals obesity  mild pallor  and sweating. His BP is 150/95 mm Hg  and heart rate of 90 bpm with irregular rhythm. There are also signs of decrease in breath sounds at bases of lungs. Lab tests revealed high blood sugar and increased LDL cholesterol levels.  Given his history  clinical presentation  and lifestyle factors  we are considering a diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further investigations including EKG  stress test and possibly cardiac catheterization will be employed to confirm the diagnosis.   Thank you for your attention. This concludes our presentation of Mr. Doe's case.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information: Mr. Richard Brown  a 64-year-old  African American male  residing in New York City.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension  diagnosed 10 years ago and currently on Lisinopril. - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 8 years ago and currently managed with Metformin. - Known case of Hypercholesterolemia  controlled with lifestyle modifications and Atorvastatin - Former smoker but quit 5 years ago - Family history of cardiovascular diseases  father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at age 59.  Presenting Complaint: - Mr. Brown has been experiencing recurrent episodes of chest pain over the last few weeks.  - He describes it as squeezing or pressure type chest pain  primarily on the left side  radiating to the left arm  occasionally accompanied by shortness of breath. - The pain typically develops during physical exertion and is relieved with rest within 10 minutes. - There were also instances of nocturnal chest pain and chest discomfort during moments of emotional distress. - Episodes are becoming more frequent and severe  compromising his daily activities.  Physical Examination: - General Examination: Conscious  oriented  and appears distressed due to pain.  - Vitals: BP- 145/90 mmHg  Pulse- 85/minute  Respiratory rate- 18/minute.  - Cardiovascular Examination: All heart sounds heard  no murmurs  no peripheral edema noted.   The overall clinical picture is consistent with Chronic stable angina  a typical clinical presentation of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further diagnostic tests including ECG  stress testing  and coronary angiogram are planned to confirm the diagnosis and map out an appropriate treatment plan.  It must be highlighted that Mr. Brown's age  ethnicity  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  past smoking history  and family history of cardiovascular diseases place him at a significantly higher risk for CAD.  Objective for Therapy: - Relief from symptoms - Prevent progression of the disease - Reduce the risk for acute coronary events and the associated mortality and morbidity.   Clinical follow-up and coordination with multidisciplinary teams will be necessary considering management of his coexisting conditions. His lifestyle modifications would include a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise and diabetic  hypertension and lipid management. The possibility of more aggressive interventional procedures or surgery will be considered based on the progression of the disease and response to therapy.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 65-year-old African-American male with a diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). He resides in a suburban area and is retired  with a past occupation in heavy industrial labor. He is married and has two grown children. He is a non-smoker but admits to drinking alcohol occasionally. He maintains a moderately high-fat diet and leads a sedentary lifestyle.   Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and dyslipidemia  or abnormal lipid (fat) levels in the blood – both of which have been under control with medications. He has borderline diabetes mellitus  for which he was counselled about lifestyle modifications but was not on medications. His family history is significant with his father having succumbed to a myocardial infarction at 70 years old and his mother with a history of stroke in her late sixties. The patient has been taking atenolol  a beta-blocker  for his hypertension  and a statin daily for his dyslipidemia for the past 10 years.   Recent Symptoms:  Recently  he has been experiencing intermittent chest pain  particularly during activities like gardening. The pain is described as intense and central  radiating to his left arm  and relieved upon rest or intake of prescribed sublingual nitroglycerin tablets. The episodes of pain have been increasing in both frequency and intensity over the past several months leading to the diagnosis of CAD.   In conclusion  this patient's demographic factors  lifestyle choices  and medical history make him a high-risk candidate for worsening CAD. If not managed appropriately  it may lead to serious complications like myocardial infarction. Comprehensive medical management and necessary lifestyle modifications are crucial in preventing further disease progression.

Title: Presentation of Coronary Artery Disease in a Geriatric Patient  Patient Information: Patient: Mr. James Sullivan Age: 67 years Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant Residential History: Lifelong resident of Boston  Massachusetts  Medical History: Maj. James Sullivan is a retired accountant and a Vietnam veteran. He is presenting with a recent history of fatigue  angina  and shortness of breath particularly during physical activities  which are the characteristic symptoms of coronary artery disease (CAD). The symptoms have been severe enough to disrupt his daily activities.  Mr. Sullivan has an extensive past medical history which includes: 1. Diabetes Mellitus type 2 diagnosed at age 50; controlled through metformin and lifestyle changes. 2. Hypertension diagnosed in his mid-40s; managed with Lisinopril. 3. High cholesterol levels diagnosed at age 45; managed with atorvastatin. 4. Smoker for 30 years  quit 12 years ago.  He has familial history of coronary artery disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He follows a mixed diet and does regular exercise  but his exercise capacity has reduced recently due to the onset of angina and breathlessness.   Since his retirement  he has been observing regular medical check-ups to monitor and control his diabetes and hypertension. Despite consistent efforts to maintain his health  given his genetic predisposition along with his past lifestyle habits and existing comorbidities  he has developed coronary artery disease.  Currently  he is adhering to his medication regime  taking Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and atorvastatin for his high cholesterol levels.  In conclusion  improving Mr. Sullivan's quality of life by managing his coronary artery disease symptoms will be our primary focus. This would include advancements in his medication routine  lifestyle modifications  and possibly considering invasive procedures based on the severity of his CAD.

Title: Presentation of a patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Meet Mr. John  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with severe chest pain radiating to the left arm and jaw  palpitations  shortness of breath  fatigue  and excessive sweating. He comes from a low-income community in the urban region of Seattle and works part time as a furniture retailer. Currently living alone  his diet primarily consists of processed  high fat  and high cholesterol foods and he has a history of smoking 20 cigarettes per day for the last 35 years.  In reference to his medical history  he was diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus roughly 15 years ago. Unfortunately  his adherence to medication has remained inconsistent due to financial constraints and lack of prioritizing his health.   He had a previous acute myocardial infarction 4 years ago and underwent percutaneous coronary intervention with satisfactory results. Thereafter  he was advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle  including regular exercise and a controlled  nutritious diet  but remained non-compliant.  Family history is significant with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at 66 years of age  and his elder sister being diagnosed with angina at 60. Unfortunately  Mr. John didn't follow any preventive measures though there were evident risk factors and a positive family history.  His social history also reveals a considerable amount of stress due to various personal and financial issues. Sleep cycles are disrupted and he admits to consuming alcohol frequently as a form of stress-relief.  Given his history of smoking  poor diet  lack of exercise  chronic conditions like hypertension and diabetes  previous myocardial infarction and a family history of heart disease  Mr. John presents a classic textbook case of coronary artery disease.

Title: Patient Case Presentation: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Identification: The patient is a 64-year old Caucasian male  known as Mr. B  who resides in New York City. He is retired and lives with his wife. He has two children and five grandchildren. He has a 45-year history of smoking two packs per day  but quit five years ago. He is overweight  BMI 30  and leads a sedentary lifestyle. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption.  Chief Complaint: Mr. B presented with chest discomfort and shortness of breath  which he has been experiencing for several weeks. He reported the pain is worse during physical activities and somewhat relieved with rest.  Medical History:  Mr. B has a history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  for which he takes antihypertensive drugs. He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled with insulin and dietary adjustments for the past 15 years  dyslipidemia managed with statins for eight years  and had a transient ischemic attack six years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 78.  Physical Examination: Mr. B appeared anxious. He had a blood pressure of 155/95 mm Hg  heart rate 90 bpm  and SpO2 96% on room air. Auscultation revealed normal heart sounds without any murmur and diminished breath sounds in both the lungs.  Laboratory Tests:  His hemoglobin A1c was 7.3%  LDL cholesterol was 140 mg/dL  and fasting blood glucose level was 150 mg/dL. An Electrocardiogram (EKG) showed T-wave inversion in leads V1-V3.  Presumptive Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical presentation  past medical history  and initial diagnostic findings  Mr. B is suspected of having coronary artery disease.   Plan: We plan to hospitalize Mr. B for further investigation and management. The high suspicion for coronary artery disease leads us to plan for coronary angiography as an appropriate diagnosis approach. Depending on the findings  revascularization procedures  PCI or CABG may be considered. A tailored treatment plan  including medication adjustment  lifestyle modifications  and a cardiac rehabilitation program  will be discussed after the results.

Presentation of Patient  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 61 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Bank Manager - Marital Status: Married - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Place of Residence: San Francisco  California  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Doe has complained of frequent episodes of chest pain  that typically occurs with physical exertion or emotional distress but tends to resolve with rest. He has also reported shortness of breath  especially while walking for long distances or while climbing stairs. Patient Presentation:  I'd like to present a 62-year-old African American male patient  Mr. J. He resides in Newark  New Jersey  and is a retired truck driver. His wife referred him after observing recurrent episodes of chest pains. The patient smokes about two packs of cigarettes weekly and admits to being a heavy drinker until about ten years ago. His BMI is 29 and he leads a predominantly sedentary lifestyle.   In terms of his medical history  Mr. J has hypertension which was diagnosed ten years ago and he is on Lisinopril 20mg once daily. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago and has been on Simvastatin 20 mg. Also  the patient had a transient ischemic attack about six years ago with no noted residual neurological deficits. Despite these  he has been inconsistent with routine medical check-ups in recent years. He has no known allergies.  His family history reveals his father died of a heart attack at the age of 69  while his mother passed away at 75 due to complications from diabetes.   Over the past few months  Mr. J has been experiencing episodes of chest pain  which typically occur during physical exertion and resolves with rest. Recently  these episodes are more frequent and severe and sometimes he reports experiencing them even while resting.   Given the nature of his symptoms  his risk factors including smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  his family history and his ethnic background  we consider these symptoms consistent with coronary artery disease (CAD). Further diagnostics including electrocardiogram (ECG)  echocardiogram and possibly angiography are advised for a conclusive diagnosis. Mr. J will benefit from a cardiovascular review and close monitoring by a cardiologist. There will also be a need for health education regarding lifestyle changes  medication adherence  and regular follow-ups.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is Mr. John Smith  a 67-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired engineer  and lives with his wife in Chicago  Illinois. His primary spoken language is English. He is non-Hispanic and has a personal monthly income level of between $3000-$4000  supplemented by medical insurance.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith has presented with symptoms of worsening chest pain that occurs during physical exertion and eases when at rest (angina). He has been experiencing shortness of breath and fatigue  which are new symptoms that have been ongoing for the past two weeks.   Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years and has been well controlled with metformin and lifestyle modifications. He also has a recorded history of high cholesterol and hypertension  which have been managed with statin therapy and Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) for the past 5 years.   Family History:  He has a family history of ischemic heart disease. His father suffered a myocardial infarction in his early 60s and his paternal uncle also had coronary artery disease.  Social History:  Mr. Smith is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  previously smoking 1 pack per day for twenty years. He drinks alcohol occasionally  maybe 1 or 2 units per week. He used to be physically active in his early life but not in the recent years after retirement.   Preventive Care:  He religiously gets his annual flu shots and was updated on the pneumonia vaccine last year. His colonoscopy was done 3 years ago and was normal.  Considering his present symptoms  past medical  family  and social history  it’s definite that he's at high risk of coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic tests including ECG  echocardiogram and possibly coronary angiography should be planned to confirm the diagnosis.

Presentation of Patient with Coronary Artery Disease   I'd like to present Mr. D.S.  a 65-year-old retired construction manager from Kansas City. He is an African American male and weighs around 255 pounds. His height is about 5'8"". Mr. D.S. has a considerable history of smoking  consuming at least a pack per day for the past 40 years. He also has a frequently unmonitored diet with a clear preference for foods high in cholesterol and fats. He does not maintain a regular exercise routine and his sedentary lifestyle contributes to his current condition.  Mr. D.S. has a significant medical history. He was diagnosed with hypertension at age 50  and Type II diabetes mellitus five years later. Both conditions are being treated with medications  though control has been erratic primarily due to poor adherence. He also has a diagnosed hyperlipidemia. His father suffered a fatal stroke at the age of 55 which might raise his potential genetic predisposition to cardiovascular diseases.  About five days ago  Mr. D.S. started experiencing intermittent chest pain  particularly after any physical exertion. The pain was described as ‘squeezing’ in nature  radiating to his left shoulder and arm  and he also noted episodes of shortness of breath upon mild exertion. He occasionally feels light-headed during these episodes.  These symptoms are highly indicative of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  more specifically angina pectoris due to possible significant atherosclerotic plaque buildup. Given the patient's risk factors including his age  race  hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  unhealthy diet  lack of physical exercise and family history  it is highly likely that he has developed CAD. Immediate diagnostic and therapeutic steps should be taken to manage Mr. D.S.’s condition.
