He denies syncope  lower extremity edema  and recent illnesses.   Physical Examination:  Height is 5’11’’  and weight is 228 pounds. Vital signs show blood pressure of 138/88 mmHg. Pulse is 78 beats per minute. Physical examination is significant for normal S1 and S2 and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops detected. There are no signs of peripheral edema or cyanosis. Assessment of his lungs is clear bilaterally  with no evidence of rales  wheezes or rhonchi.   Risk Factors: This patient’s age  male gender  past history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and significant family history put him at high risk for coronary artery disease. His history of tobacco use also significantly contributes to his progression to CAD. Emergency evaluation is warranted to prevent a potential life-threatening event.

Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  56-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint:  Patient reports experiencing episodes of chest pain which typically occur during physical activity and resolve after rest.  History Present Illness:  Over the past six months  he has noticed progressively increasing angina. Most recently  he reports an episode of chest pain while resting  which was relieved upon taking sublingual nitroglycerin. Symptoms are described as a central burning chest discomfort  radiating to his left arm  associated with shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  1) Hypertension (diagnosed 5 years ago and under medication) 2) Hyperlipidemia (diagnosed 3 years ago and under medication) 3) Type II Diabetes Mellitus (diagnosed 6 years ago and under medication) 4) Ex-Smoker (quit 2 years ago after smoking 1 pack/day for 30 years) 5) Family history of heart disease (Father had myocardial infarction at age 58)  Review of Systems:  Positive for fatigue  sweating  nausea.  Physical Examination: Vital signs are stable. No acute distress noted. Patient is alert  oriented and cooperative. Chest exam revealed normal lung sounds  heart sounds reveal no murmurs or gallops. No edema noted in lower extremities. Other physical examinations are within normal limits.  Diagnostic data: Not available. The physician may need to order relevant tests such as an electrocardiogram (ECG)  stress test  blood tests  and possibly a coronary angiogram to confirm diagnosis.   Assessment: Given the described symptoms and medical history  the patient is suspected to have Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further diagnostic evaluation required to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity.   Plan: Consider referral to cardiologist for further evaluation and management. Patient should continue current medications and follow a heart-healthy lifestyle including a low salt  low cholesterol diet  maintaining a healthy weight  exercising regularly  managing stress  and regular follow-up. Patient should be educated about recognizing the symptoms of a potential heart attack and advised to seek immediate medical attention.

Patient Presentation:    Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old Caucasian male presenting with complaints of intermittent  dull chest pain occurring primarily with exertion and relieved with rest. He describes the pain as a pressure-like discomfort on the left side of his chest  radiating to his left arm and jaw. He also reports associated shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness primarily during episodes of chest pain. These symptoms began a few months ago  and have gradually increased in frequency and severity.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Johnson has a history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and Hypertension  both under control with medications (Metformin and Lisinopril respectively). He is a former smoker  who quit 20 years ago  with a 15 pack-years smoking history. He also reports a family history of heart disease with his father undergoing CABG at age 60  and a brother who had an MI at age 55.   Reviewed Of Systems (ROS):  Negative for fever  chills  cough  abdominal pain  or lower extremity swelling.   Social History:  He lives with his wife and is retired from his work as an accountant. He does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. He also leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle.   Current Medications:  Metformin 500mg twice daily  Lisinopril 10mg once daily  Atorvastatin 10mg every night.  Physical Examination:  Vital Signs: BP: 130/80 mmHg  HR: 75 bpm  RR: 16 bpm  SpO2: 98% on room air  Weight: 220 pounds  Height: 5'10"".   General: Well-appearing  not in acute distress. CV: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulm: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes  rales  or rhonchi. Abd: Soft  nontender. No hepatosplenomegaly. Ext: No edema. Warm and well perfused. Neuro: Alert and oriented to person  place  and time. CN II-XII grossly intact.   The overall clinical scenario is suggestive of stable angina pectoris secondary to coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Gary Martin  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic today reporting intermittent episodes of chest pain radiating to the left arm  most commonly during physical activities such as climbing the stairs or walking long distances. The pain often subsides when he rests. He also mentions feelings of unusual fatigue and shortness of breath.   The patient has been a smoker for the past 30 years  averaging one pack per day. His diet is high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables. His Body Mass Index is 32 which classifies him as obese. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical exercise.   Past medical history includes hypertension for the past ten years  controlled with Lisinopril  and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed with Metformin. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  as both his mother and his brother have experienced myocardial infarctions.   Mr. Martin’s current medications include Lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension  Metformin 1000mg twice daily for diabetes  and low-dose Aspirin 81mg as a prophylactic measure. He is noncompliant with his lipid-lowering agent  Atorvastatin  expressing concerns about side effects.   This medical history  family history  lifestyle  and the present complaints strongly suspect the diagnosis of coronary artery disease in Mr. Martin.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 55-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of increasing episodes of chest discomfort over the last 6 months. The discomfort is described as feeling heavy and 'squeezing' in nature  typically in the central chest  often radiates to his left arm and jaw. These episodes typically last for 10-15 minutes and are relieved by rest.  His risk factors include a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia and a 30-year smoking history of 1 pack per day. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in saturated fats. He also has a family history of heart disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at age 65.   Past Medical History is significant for Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 7 years ago  for which he takes Metformin daily. He has also been receiving treatment for his hypertension and high cholesterol with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively for the last 5 years.  His vitals: Blood Pressure: 145/95 mmHg  HR: 90 bpm  BMI: 30. Laboratory findings revealed that his fasting blood glucose was elevated at 180 mg/dL and his total cholesterol was also elevated at 250 mg/dL with low HDL and high LDL levels. The ECG shows nonspecific ST-T wave abnormalities.   Based on these conclusions combined with clinical presentation  suspect diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (stable angina). Further investigations through a stress test or coronary angiography may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis.

Patient Information: 69-year-old Hispanic male  Chief Complaint: Persistent chest pain radiating to the left arm accompanying with shortness of breath  notably during moderate physical activity.  History of Present Illness: Pain started about two weeks ago  severity has been progressively increasing and now he experiences chest pain even during mundane activities. The pain is described as squeezing or tightening in the chest area  and sometimes comes with lightheadedness and cold sweat.  Medical History:  1) Hypertension: Diagnosed 15 years ago  currently managed with Amlodipine 5mg daily. 2) Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily.  Family History: His father and two older brothers had myocardial infarctions in their early 60s.   Social History: He is a retired construction worker  married and father of three children. Quit smoking 10 years ago; he had been a pack-a-day smoker for 35 years. He admits he has a sedentary lifestyle and his diet is rich in fatty and sugary foods.  Physical Examination: Patient appears distressed. Vital signs are blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  pulse 80 beats per minute  respiration 20 breaths per minute  temperature 97.6 F  and O2 Saturation 96% on room air. Chest auscultation shows no wheezes or crackles. Heart-S1 S2 are normal; no extra heart sounds or murmurs. Abdomen is soft  non tender  no organomegaly. Neurological exam is non focal.  Lab Tests: ECG shows T wave inversions in leads V1-V4. Troponin level is slightly elevated. Fasting Blood Sugar is 160 mg/dL  HbA1c is 7.6%. Lipid profile shows elevated LDL and triglycerides  and low HDL.   Assessment: His symptomatology  ECG findings  lab results and history all point towards coronary artery disease as the most likely diagnosis. High risk factors include type 2 diabetes  hypertension  high cholesterol  family history of heart disease  and smoking history. Stress test and coronary angiography to be considered for further evaluation. Would benefit from lifestyle changes and possibly medications to control lipid levels and to prevent clot formation. Urgent reevaluation for symptoms worsening or if they occur at rest.

Patient Presentation:  Mrs. D  a 64-year-old Caucasian female  presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of recurrent chest pain for the past 1 month. She describes the pain as 'crushing'  localized to the middle of her chest and sometimes radiating to her left shoulder. The pain typically occurs after physical exertion  like climbing stairs or carrying groceries  and is usually relieved after resting. She also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional sweating.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mrs. D has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been controlled on medication for the past 10 years. She is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but had a 20-pack-year smoking history prior to cessation. She also reports a family history of heart disease  with her father having suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. On further exploration  she follows a high-fat diet and leads a sedentary lifestyle due to her retired status. She is currently on atenolol 50mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia.  In consideration of her clinical symptoms  risk factors  and past medical history  a differential diagnosis of coronary artery disease is suggested. Further cardiac evaluation including electrocardiogram (ECG) and possibly a stress test are planned.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Anderson Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Anderson presented with a 3-month history of progressively worsening chest discomfort  especially during exertion  which usually subsides upon rest. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath when walking up the stairs  persistent fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness.   Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago  controlled with Lisinopril. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus under control  diagnosed 7 years ago  managed with Metformin. 3. Smoker for over 40 years  consuming 20 cigarettes daily. Alcohol consumption is moderate at most. 4. Was diagnosed with high cholesterol 2 years ago  managed with Atorvastatin. 5. Family history of heart diseases with his father having undergone CABG at the age of 65.  6. No known drug allergies.  Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension 2. Metformin 1000mg twice daily for Diabetes Mellitus 3. Atorvastatin 40mg at night for hypercholesterolemia  Upon physical examination  Mr. Anderson had a Blood Pressure of 140/85 mmHg  pulse 78 bpm  BMI 29 kg/m2  and breath sounds were clear bilaterally on auscultation. Examination of the cardiovascular system showed no abnormalities.  This suggests that Mr. Anderson could be potentially suffering from coronary artery disease  given his symptoms and risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  diabetes  hypercholesterolemia  obesity  and family history of heart disease. It is recommended that he undergo further investigations to confirm the diagnosis and determine the severity of the disease for proper management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. James Thompson is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of worsening chest pain over the past few weeks. The pain  described as a heaviness or tightness in the chest  typically occurs with exertion and improving with rest. The pain episodes are not associated with shortness of breath  nausea  or diaphoresis. However  he recently has started experiencing these episodes while at rest  which have increased in frequency and intensity over the past week.  Mr. Thompson has a past medical history notable for hypertension and high cholesterol  both diagnosed 10 years ago and currently managed with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. He also has a 20-pack year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago.   His family history is significant  as his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60  and his elder brother underwent percutaneous coronary intervention procedure at the age of 53 due to coronary artery disease.  On physical examination  his blood pressure is elevated  at 145/90 mmHg  with a regular heart rate of 88 bpm. Heart sounds reveal no audible murmurs. BMI is calculated to be 28  putting him in the overweight category.   Overall  his worsening symptoms  associated risk factors including family history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and past smoking history  are highly suggestive of the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic complaining of increasing episodes of chest discomfort over the past month. The pain is described as pressure-like  located under the mid-sternal region  radiating to his left arm  and lasting from 5 to 10 minutes. The discomfort is typically precipitated by moderate physical exertion and is quickly relieved with rest.   The episodes are more frequent during periods of emotional stress. There are associated symptoms of shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and nausea. He denies symptom occurrence during sleep  and there is no history of dizziness  palpitations  or fainting episodes. Mr. Smith is a former smoker with 25 pack-years history but quit smoking ten years back.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension for ten years for which he takes medication  and type II diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago for which he follows dietary control and oral hypoglycemics.   Family history is pertinent for his father who had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and his elder brother had bypass surgery at the age of 62. He lives alone  retires from a stressful managerial job  follows a diet high in fats and carbs  and has a sedentary lifestyle lacking routine exercise.   A physical examination shows a well-nourished male at rest  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse of 78 beats per minute  and no detectable murmurs or gallops on cardiac examination. His BMI is the 28 indicative of overweight. His fasting blood glucose is 140 mg/dl and HbA1c is 7.3%. He shows theodolite discoloration of feet suggesting peripheral arterial disease.   Given his symptoms  risk factors  family history  and physical examination findings  further diagnostic workup is advised to confirm the suspected diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Braxton is a 58-year-old African-American male presenting with intermittent chest pain that is sometimes associated with shortness of breath and palpitations. He describes the chest pain as heaviness and pressure  which is most severe when he is physically active or under stress. The symptoms often subside when he rests or sleeps. He denies nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis  but occasionally experiences lightheadedness.  He has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which have been managed with medications- Lisonopril  Atorvastatin  and Metformin respectively. His medications are not updated and he is non-compliant with regular appointments.  Mr. Braxton has been a chronic smoker  with a history of smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years. He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.   On his maternal side  his mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his father had a stroke at the age of 70. He has two older brothers: one brother had bypass surgery at the age of 55 and the other brother has no known heart disease.   The patient is a retired salesman  currently living with his wife  and their diet tends to be high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle with very little physical activity.   Upon physical examination  the patient appears overweight with a body mass index of 30. Initial vitals reveal blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 bpm  respiration rate of 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 96% at room air. His cardiovascular examination reveals normal S1 and S2 heart sounds with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presents today with complaints of chest pain  particularly when carrying out physical activities. He describes the pain as “pressure-like”  lasting about 10 minutes and typically relieved by rest. He also experiences episodes of shortness of breath  excessive fatigue  and occasional lightheadedness.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thomas has a past medical history most significant for hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin. He is also a two-pack per day smoker for the past 45 years and admits to having a sedentary lifestyle and a diet that is high in fat and carbohydrates. He has no known allergies. Family history is significant for a father who had a fatal myocardial infarction at age 60 and a brother who underwent bypass surgery at the age of 65.  Physical Examination: On examination  patient’s blood pressure read 145/90 mmHg and his pulse was 78 beats per minute and regular. Heart sounds were normal with no murmurs or gallops. His lungs were clear bilaterally. Pedal pulses were diminished bilaterally with no signs of edema.  The combination of this patient's characteristic chest pain episodes which are induced by exertion but mitigated by rest  along with his past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic smoking suggest strongly that the patient may be suffering from coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic experiencing intermittent chest pain  particularly after exertion  for the last few months. The pain is usually relieved with rest. He also reports a recent increase in fatigue  decreased activity tolerance  occasional lightheadedness and shortness of breath  and discomfort in his left arm.  Past medical history reveals that the patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  which has been controlled with medication (Lisinopril). The patient also has a 35-year history of heavy smoking (1 pack/day) but quit smoking 5 years ago upon his diagnosis with type 2 diabetes mellitus. His diabetes has been managed with dietary modifications and daily Metformin intake.  His father had a myocardial infarction at 62 years old. He does not exercise regularly and his diet is high in saturated fat and sodium. He works as a manager in a stressful organizational environment. He consumes alcohol inconsistively - approximately 1-2 drinks per week.   Current medications include Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension  and Metformin 750mg twice a day for type 2 diabetes. The patient is currently not taking any over-the-counter medications  herbal supplements  or illicit substances.  This patient is suspected for coronary artery disease due to his presenting symptoms  age  sex  medical history including hypertension  diabetes  smoking  family history  and a lifestyle with high stress  poor diet  lack of exercise  and minimal alcohol consumption.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Jimenez  a 58-year-old Hispanic male with a past medical history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  comes into the clinic complaining of persistent discomfort in his chest especially after physical activity  and intermittent shortness of breath over the last six months. He also describes occasional indigestion-like discomfort and fatigue. He is a current smoker and has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. His chiropractor father suffered a heart attack at the age of 60 and passed away due to a subsequent stroke at the age of 63. His 65-year-old sister was recently diagnosed with angina. He is non-compliant with his medication and has poor diet control. He is a retired veteran and currently works part-time as a security guard. His vital signs are: Blood Pressure: 152/94 mmHg  Heart Rate: 84 beats/minute  Respiratory Rate: 18 breaths/minute  Oxygen Saturation: 98% on Room Air  Body Mass Index: 30.2 kg/m². On physical examination  he appears anxious. His cardiovascular exam reveals regular rate and rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallops.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Roberts is a 61-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the office today with complaints of intermittent chest pain over the past month. The pain is often centrally located  lasts several minutes  and is typically brought on by exertion but relieved by rest or sublingual nitroglycerin. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  and occasional dizziness and nausea. He has been increasingly fatigued in recent weeks. He denies any episodes of syncope  palpitations  cough  or fever.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both under control with medication. He had a positive treadmill stress test for ischemia 2 years ago  but has been symptom-free on medical management until recently. No prior surgeries. He consumes alcohol moderately and quit smoking 10 years ago after a 30-pack year history.  Family history includes a father who died of an MI at the age of 66. His mother is alive and well at 85. He has one older brother who has hypertension.  He is married  recently retired civil engineer  lives with his wife. He leads a sedentary lifestyle since retirement. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Aspirin. Reports adherence to his medications.  Physical exam findings were consistent with a mildly distressed man due to pain. Cardiac examination revealed normal S1 and S2 with no apparent murmurs  rubs or gallops. Pulmonary examination was within normal with clear breath sounds bilaterally. No peripheral edema noted.   Given his clinical presentation  past medical history  and physical examination findings  an urgent evaluation for coronary artery disease is being considered.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 64-year-old Caucasian male and a retired businessman who presents with a two-week history of increasing exertional chest pain. He describes the pain as a squeezing sensation located in the center of his chest  occurring during moderate exertion and subsiding after rest. The pain sometimes radiates to his left arm. Though he initially dismissed it as heartburn associated with his frequent spicy meals  the pain has been worsening and occurring with less exertion.   The patient's history is significant for poorly controlled Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus over the past 10 years and mild Hypertension. He also admits to a 20-year history of smoking 2 packs of cigarettes a day  which he quit 5 years ago after a mild stroke. He consumes moderate amounts of alcohol and has a family history of early onset heart disease (father passed away at the age of 55 due to heart attack).   He does not have any allergies but takes daily medications for his diabetes and hypertension. These include Metformin 500 mg twice a day and Lisinopril 20 mg once a day. He is currently not on any antiplatelet therapy. His records show that his last LDL cholesterol level  done six months ago  was 160 mg/dL.  He denies experiencing symptoms such as shortness of breath  palpitations  or syncope. However  he reports noticing the occasional heavy pounding heartbeat especially at night.   On physical examination  he is slightly overweight with a BMI of 28. He appears mildly anxious. His blood pressure is 148/86 mmHg  pulse 84 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. There are no apparent cardiac murmurs and lungs are clear to auscultation. His pulses in the lower extremities are palpable.   An EKG has been ordered and a consult with Cardiology is scheduled to discuss potential further diagnostic modalities and therapeutic options. Main concern based on the above details is Coronary Artery Disease.

Patient Information: Mr. J. Smith  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  married with 3 adult children.   Presenting Complaint: Reporting recent onset of central  gripping chest discomfort radiating to the left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  sweating  and dizziness. The pain occurs with exertion  especially climbing stairs or walking uphill  and is relieved by rest.  Past Medical History: History of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  diagnosed five years ago. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history of tobacco use. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Current Medications: Hydrochlorothiazide 12.5 mg daily for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20 mg daily at night for hyperlipidemia.   Family History: First-degree male relative with premature ischemic heart disease  and his mother is alive with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Social History: Retired engineer living with his wife. He quit smoking 10 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. His diet is high in saturated fats  and he does low-intensity exercises twice a week.  Review of Systems: Reports fatigue  bouts of night sweats  occasional mild confusion  decreased appetite but denies any bowel/bladder changes  weight loss  or bleeding tendencies. He endorses regular sleep but recently has been waking up due to chest discomfort.  Physical Examination: His vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiovascular examination reveals distant heart sounds and a grade II/VI systolic murmur. His lungs are clear to auscultation  and the remainder of the examination is unremarkable.   Based on the symptoms  family history  age  and sex  a presentation suggestive of stable coronary artery disease is apparent.

Patient Information: 65-year-old Caucasian male plumber  85 kg weight and 1.78 m tall  non-smoker  on a rather sedentary lifestyle  often with high-fat  high-sugar diet.   Chief Complaint: Central chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw  mainly during physical exertion  relieved by rest  repeated episodes for the last 6 months. Recently  episodes have been happening more frequently.  Past Medical History: Hypertensive for 10 years  diabetes mellitus type 2 for 5 years  both controlled with medications. Father had myocardial infarction at age 59.  Physical Examination:  - Blood Pressure: 140/90 mmHg - Heart Rate: 80 beats per minute - Breathing Rate: 16 breaths per minute - Temperature: Body temperature within normal range. - Cardiovascular Exam: No murmurs heard  regular rhythm. No evidence of heart failure (i.e.  ankle swelling  raised JVP).  Laboratory and Imaging Results:  - Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed signs of previous silent myocardial infarction. - Blood Tests: Elevated HbA1c  LDL cholesterol  and triglycerides. Normal liver and kidney function tests. - Exercise Stress Test: Developed chest pain and ST changes on EKG after 5 minutes of exercise. - Coronary Angiogram: Significant narrowing in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.   Diagnosis: Coronary artery disease (CAD)  confirmed by angiogram.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Smith  Demographics:  Age: 62 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired police officer Location: Salt Lake City  Utah  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the clinic complaining of recurrent chest discomfort especially upon exertion  often relieved by rest. He describes the sensation as pressure-like and situated in the middle of his chest. He also notes that he sometimes feels out of breath and fatigued after physical activities. He recently also experienced episodes of dizziness and palpitations.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of high blood pressure and has been on medication for the same for the last ten years. His lipid profile shows elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol levels  putting him in the high risk category for heart diseases. He quit smoking 5 years ago after a 20-year smoking history. His father suffered a heart attack in his early sixties.   Medication History:  He is currently under diuretics and beta-blockers for his hypertension.  Family History:  His father had coronary artery disease and passed away from a myocardial infarction. His mother is diabetic.  Lifestyle:  Mr. Smith does not exercise regularly and follows a diet rich in saturated fats. He drinks socially and has quit smoking.  On physical exam:  Blood pressure: 145/95 mmHg;  BMI: 28;  Heart: Normal S1 and S2  no murmur;  Lungs: Clear.  Mr. Smith’s symptoms  along with his past medical history and lifestyle risk factors  suggest that he could possibly be suffering from coronary artery disease. This preliminary diagnosis will need further diagnostic testing to confirm.

Patient Information: Mr. John Harrison  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of chest pain  especially on exertion.  Chief Complaint: He states the pain is often a squeezing or pressure-like sensation  in the mid-chest area  radiating to his left arm. He notes that the pain tends to subside upon rest  but is significantly worsening and affecting his daily tasks.  Past Medical History: Mr. Harrison was diagnosed with type II diabetes 10 years ago  which he manages with moderate control. His medical history is also notable for hypertension for the past 15 years  dyslipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease due to a 40 pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking five years ago. He also had a previous myocardial infarction at the age of 55.  Family History: His father had a heart attack at the age of 60 and died of stroke at 75  while his mother lived with angina for many years before passing from lung cancer at 80. His younger brother  currently 62  was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Current Medications: Mr. Harrison’s medications include metformin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and a short-acting bronchodilator.  Review of Systems: Patient denies shortness of breath  cough  fevers  or any other symptoms.   Social History: He leads a sedentary life  having retired from a stressful desk job five years ago. His diet is rich in fatty and processed foods. He regularly consumes alcohol moderately  about 1-2 standard drinks per day. He lives with his wife  their children have moved out of state for university and work.  Physical Exam: On examination  Mr. Harrison is alert and oriented. BP: 140/90 mm Hg  HR: 85 beats/min  BMI: 28. Physical examination reveals diminished breath sounds bilaterally on chest auscultation.  Assessment: Given his symptoms and risk factors (advanced age  male  personal and family history of cardiovascular diseases  uncontrolled hypertension  and dyslipidemia)  Mr. Harrison is likely presenting with coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic investigations are warranted  including an EKG  stress test  possible angiography  and relevant laboratory work-ups to evaluate his current cardiovascular risk status and determine appropriate management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 60-year-old Caucasian male who presents today with a chief complaint of chest pain. The pain worsens with exertion and improves with rest. It is described as a heavy  central chest discomfort radiating to his left arm. Episodes of this pain have become more frequent over the past few weeks  and he has also noted an increased feeling of fatigue and shortness of breath during exertion.   He is a smoker of 20 cigarettes per day for 30 years and admits to a diet high in saturated fats and a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. He is a regular alcohol consumer  primarily beer  approximate 10-12 drinks per week.   His mother experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his father died of stroke at 67. He works as an account manager under high-stress conditions.  His past medical history includes hypertension  which has been controlled with Lisinopril 10mg per day. He also has a diagnosis of type II diabetes  managed with metformin 500mg twice a day. He denies any known drug allergies.  On physical examination  he appears overweight with a BMI of 30. Blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  heart rate is 88 bpm  and respiratory rate is 15 breaths per minute. Auscultation of the heart reveals no added sounds or murmurs. His lungs are clear  and abdominal examination is unremarkable.   Initial laboratory findings showed a fasting plasma glucose level of 7 mmol/L  cholesterol of 6.8 mmol/L  LDL level 3.9 mmol/L  HDL 1.0 mmol/L  and a serum triglyceride level of 2.2 mmol/L. His EKG showed T-wave inversion in leads II  III  and aVF  suggesting possible ischemia.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Davis is a 63 year old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with complaints of intermittent episodes of chest discomfort  typically brought on by physical exertion or emotional stress and relieved by rest. He describes the discomfort as a pressure-like sensation  “like someone is sitting on his chest”. These episodes last between 5 to 10 minutes. In addition  he reports experiencing fatigue  shortness of breath  and occasional palpitations.  His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes for which he takes Metformin  hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia managed with Simvastatin. He has a 35 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity. His diet is high in saturated fats and carbohydrates.   Family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. His younger brother has undergone coronary artery bypass graft surgery at the age of 50. He denies history of illicit drug use or alcohol excess.   He states that he is concerned about his symptoms and is aware of his high risk factors for heart disease.

Patient Information: A 62-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department.   Chief Complaint: Severe chest pain radiating towards the left arm and neck.  History of Present Illness: The patient has had intermittent chest discomfort for the past 2 months  often associated with exercise and relieved with rest. Over the past 24 hours  the chest pain has become more severe and persistent  enduring for more than 20 minutes at a time  and relief with rest has diminished.   Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension (Managed with Lisinopril 10mg once daily)  2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus (Managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily) 3. Hyperlipidaemia (Managed with Atorvastatin 20mg once daily) 4. He had a transient ischemic attack 5 years ago with no residual neurologic deficit.  Social History:  He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years. He reports occasional alcohol intake  mainly on weekends.  Family History:  His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 58 years. His older brother  65  also has a history of coronary artery disease and underwent angioplasty at the age of 60.   Medications: Lisinopril  Metformin  and Atorvastatin  Review of Systems: No complaints of shortness of breath  palpitations  dizziness  or symptoms suggestive of congestive heart failure.  Physical Exam:  Vital Signs: BP 160/95  HR 88  Temp 98.3  RR 18 General: Nervous  uncomfortable due to chest pain  CVS: Normal S1  S2  no murmurs Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally  no wheezing or crackles Abdominal: Soft  Non-tender  Laboratory Investigations:  EKG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads. Initial troponin level was slightly elevated. Lipid Panel: Total cholesterol-220  LDL-140  HDL-35  Triglycerides-280 Fasting Blood Glucose: 145 mg/dL  Assessment:  Based on the presentation  clinical history  and the physical examination  the patient likely has a case of unstable angina or acute myocardial infarction (acute coronary syndrome)  under the umbrella of coronary artery disease.   Plan:  Patient should be immediately treated with aspirin and nitroglycerin if not allergic. Further steps should include coronary angiography  possible cardiac catheterization. Long-term strategies should include aggressive risk factor modification  such as smoking cessation  blood pressure control  diabetes management  statin therapy for high cholesterol  and possibly low-dose aspirin for secondary prevention. Lifestyle modifications should also be reinforced.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 68-year-old African American male presents with complaints of chest pain mainly on exertion  shortness of breath and occasional nausea. His pain tends to subside at rest. He describes the pain as a pressure-like feeling in the middle of his chest called angina. Episodes of angina occur more frequently over the last few weeks. He denies any fever  cough  or history of trauma. He also has a relevant past medical history of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension for the last 10 years. He admits of smoking one pack per day for approximately 40 years and a diet high in saturated fats. His father died of acute myocardial infarction at the age of 60. He has been non-compliant with his medications due to financial struggles and lack of health insurance. He does not exercise regularly and admits to moderate alcohol consumption. He has not noticed any lower extremity edema  and denies any episodes of syncope. His physical examination is significant for a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 78/min  obesity and decreased breath sounds at lung bases. An electrocardiogram shows a T-wave inversion.

Patient Information: A 67-year-old African American male with a BMI of 30.  Presenting Issue: Patient reports experiencing episodes of chest discomfort and shortness of breath over the past several weeks  predominantly during moderate physical activity or stressful situations. These episodes typically last 5-10 minutes and are relieved with rest.  Past Medical History: Patient has a 20-year history of controlled hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Also has a 15-year history of smoking  though claims to have quit 10 years ago. He has had previous medical consults for hyperlipidemia and obesity. No previous cardiac events known. Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 58.   Social History: Retired engineer  lives with his wife. Drinks alcohol occasionally. No illicit drug use.  Family History: Besides his father  also has two older brothers with coronary artery disease. Paternal grandmother had a stroke in her sixties  maternal side has several members with diabetes.  Medications: Lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes.   Physical Examination: Blood pressure 140/90 mm Hg. Heart rate 85 beats per minute and regular. Patient has mild obesity. Cardiovascular examination shows no murmurs or gallops.  Summary: This is a 67-year-old male with significant risk factors for heart disease including age  family history of early coronary artery disease  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and history of smoking. The presentation of activity-induced chest discomfort relieved by rest is highly suggestive of stable angina related to Coronary Artery Disease. Further evaluation  including cardiac testing is warranted.

Patient Information:   Mr. Allen is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with chief complaints of chest pain over the last two weeks. He reports the pain as a “heavy feeling and pressure in his chest” that is not associated with physical exertion and often occurs at rest. The pain also sometimes radiates down to his left arm and occasionally he experiences accompanying shortness of breath.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Allen has a significant medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus that are quite well-controlled with medications. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago.  His paternal grandfather and father both died of heart attacks in their 60s. He used to smoke but quit over 10 years ago and he reports lifelong sedentary lifestyle with alcohol consumption in moderation.   On examination: His physical examination is remarkable for obesity (BMI of 32)  slightly impaired chest excursions  and tenderness in the left subcostal region. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 140/90 mmHg.  Presumption: Given his classic symptomatology as well as risk factors - male gender  advanced age  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  family history of cardiovascular disease  past smoking history  and sedentary lifestyle - a presumptive diagnosis of coronary artery disease is made. He is scheduled for further diagnostics including blood tests  EKG  and possibly an angiogram depending on results.

Patient Presentation  Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired businessman  who presents with chest discomfort for the past three months. The pain is described as a central pressure-like discomfort  radiating to his left arm  worsened with exertion  and relieved by rest. The pain episodes generally last 5-10 minutes and are associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. There have not been any episodes of syncope or near syncope. Patient noticed increasing intensity of pain and reduced exercise tolerance over the three weeks.  He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes for the past 15 years  hypertension for 20 years  and hypercholesterolemia for 10 years  all of which are relatively well controlled on medications. His family history includes a father with myocardial infarction at age 62  and a brother with angina pectoris in his early sixties.  He smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol moderately. His diet mainly includes red meat  and he admits to minimal physical activity.  On physical examination  he is an obese male in moderate distress. His blood pressure is 155/90 mmHg and heart rate is 85 beats per minute. Cardiac examination reveals normal heart sounds and no murmurs. There is no peripheral edema.  Given his history  symptoms  and risk factors  he is suspected of having coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presented to the clinic today complaining of intermittent chest pain that typically occurs when he is exercising or carrying heavy objects  and abates when he is at rest. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure centrally located in his chest. The severity of his angina has been progressive over the past six months.   In addition to chest pain  he has been experiencing shortness of breath upon exertion and occasional feelings of dizziness. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit cigarette smoking 10 years ago. His history also reveals that his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.  Upon physical examination  his blood pressure is elevated at 145/90 mmHg. He has a BMI of 30  indicating obesity. The remainder of his physical exam  including cardiovascular and respiratory exams  is relatively unremarkable. Lipid panel indicates elevated levels of cholesterol including LDL. He adheres to the medical treatment which includes anti-hypertensive  anti-diabetic  and lipid-lowering drugs.  Due to his obvious risk factors  increased angina  and increasing exertional dyspnea  Mr Doe has been referred for further cardiovascular evaluation to determine the extent of his presumed coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old African-American male who presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of chest discomfort on exertion for the past two months. He describes the discomfort as a pressure-like sensation located in the center of his chest that sometimes radiates to both arms  typically occurring after walking about 1 to 2 blocks  and relieved by rest within 5-10 minutes. The discomfort is not associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  or syncope.   Mr. Smith has a 15-year history of hypertension  well controlled with Losartan  and a 10-year history of type II diabetes mellitus  managed with Metformin. This is his first presentation with any type of chest pain.  Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker and an active smoker with a 25-pack per year history. He drinks alcohol occasionally. His mother had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. His father also had hypertension and died of a stroke. His preventive health screenings  including cholesterol and blood pressure  are up-to-date.  Mr. Smith's BMI is 29 kg/m^2  blood pressure is 134/82 mmHg  heart rate 86 beats per minute  he is afebrile with saturation at 96% on room air. On examination  his heart sounds were normal without any added sounds  murmurs  or pericardial rubs. His lungs were clear on auscultation. An EKG showed no signs of ST-segment or T-wave abnormalities.  This history  physical examination  and risk factors suggest the possibility of stable angina due to coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic workup and appropriate management are recommended.  Note: Since diagnosis and management decisions are based on probabilities and personalization of care  outcomes may vary on a case to case basis. Always consult with a healthcare professional for appropriate medical advice.

Patient Presentation:  A 57-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of worsening chronic chest pain. He describes the pain as central  heavy discomfort  which he comments has been growing in intensity over the past six months. The pain is provoked by exertion  such as walking uphill or carrying heavy items  and is relieved by rest. Episodes are typically lasting 5 minutes and occasionally radiates down his left arm.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension and Type 2 diabetes  which has been managed with a combination of medications including metformin and lisinopril for the past ten years. He has a 35 pack-year smoking history and quit smoking about one year ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 62. His BMI is currently 28  indicating he is overweight.  Currently  his medications include Metformin 500mg BID and Lisinopril 10mg QD. He denies the use of illicit drugs. He consumes alcohol in moderation  with an estimated three to four drinks per week. The patient lives with his wife  and he retired two years ago from his job as a manual laborer. He confesses he has been mostly sedentary since his retirement.  On physical examination  the patient appears moderately obese but not in acute distress. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg; pulse is 78 beats per minute. His lung examination is clear to auscultation bilaterally  and his cardiac examination shows regular rhythm without any murmurs or gallops. There are no significant findings on his abdominal and neurological examination.   Based on the patient's age  sex  presenting symptoms  and past medical history  he is at high risk for coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African-American male presenting to the office with chief complaints of intermittent central chest pain radiating to the left arm  shortness of breath  and fatigue for the past few weeks. The chest discomfort usually comes on with exertion  such as walking up stairs or mowing the lawn  and is relieved by rest.   He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking 10 years ago. His lifestyle is somewhat sedentary. He doesn't exercise regularly and has a diet rich in processed foods. His BMI is 32 indicating obesity.  He has a known past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he regularly takes Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin  respectively. However  he admits that he does not take his medications regularly  and has not been following up with visits to his primary care physician.   His family history is significant  his father had an early myocardial infarction at 55 years of age and his mother was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. These history factors all increased his risk for early onset coronary artery disease.    On physical examination  he has moderate obesity  blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 85 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute with an oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. He also has reduced breath sounds in the bases of the lungs  likely due to his obesity and evidence of left ventricular hypertrophy on examination of the heart.  These symptoms together with his risk factors suggest symptomatic coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the office with chief complaints of progressive chest discomfort while carrying out daily activities  worsening over the past 4 to 6 weeks. The discomfort is described as a dull pressure sensation beginning in the center of his chest  sometimes radiating to his jaw and left arm. He admits to associated symptoms such as shortness of breath  profuse sweating  lightheadedness  and occasional palpitations  typically brought on by exertion and usually relieved with rest. He denies any symptoms at rest or nocturnal awakening with chest discomfort.   Demographic Details:  Mr. Smith is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago  although he smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for almost 30 years. He admits to drinking a glass of wine occasionally. He has a sedentary lifestyle and a high-stress life.  Relevant Past Medical History:  His pertinent past medical history reveals type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 10 years ago  being managed on twice-daily Metformin. He also has a history of hypertension controlled with Lisinopril  elevated cholesterol that is not currently being treated  and is clinically obese with a BMI of 34. His family history is significant for his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 66. On his last visit 12 months ago  his lipid profile was abnormal with elevated LDL cholesterol and triglycerides.

Patient Presentation:  Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Smith  presenting with complaints of intermittent chest pain  which he describes as a ""tight  squeezing sensation"" that radiates to his left arm. The pain usually occurs when he's undergoing some physical activities like climbing stairs or during periods of emotional stress. He rates his pain at 6/10 at its worst  improving with rest.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  both of which have been inadequately controlled over the past few years. He has a 35 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking five years ago. He had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58 and bypass surgery was performed subsequently. Since then he has been on aspirin and a beta blocker but he's non-compliant to his medications. His father had coronary artery disease and died from a heart attack at the age of 60.  Mr. Smith is married  recently retired  and experiencing ongoing life stressors  including the death of a close family member. His sedentary lifestyle with a diet rich in saturated fats and carbohydrates is contributing to his obesity; his BMI is currently 32 kg/m². His alcohol intake is moderate.  Last bloodwork revealed elevated LDL cholesterol (180 mg/dl)  reduced HDL cholesterol (35 mg/dl)  and high fasting blood glucose (180 mg/dl).   This exploration of Mr. Smith's past medical history  lifestyle  and recent test results point quite strongly towards the likelihood of coronary artery disease being responsible for his presenting symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Smith is a 60-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with complaints of progressively worsening chest pain over the past four months  especially upon exertion. The pain radiates to his left arm and is associated with occasional difficulties in breathing  profuse sweating  fatigability  and feeling faint. These symptoms often spontaneously resolve with rest. He reports having experienced three episodes of similar chest pain within the week.  He has a past medical history of hypertension for 15 years and type 2 diabetes mellitus for 10 years  for which he is on medication with reasonable control. He reports smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years and has a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD) - his father had myocardial infarction at the age of 62. He denies any history of previous similar chest pain. His diet is high in sodium and saturated fats and he admits to being sedentary most of the time. He does not take any illicit drugs or alcohol.  Mr. Smith does not report any known drug allergies. His current medications include Metformin for his diabetes and Lisinopril for his hypertension. He does not regularly exercise  and his diet consists mainly of processed and fast foods due to his busy work schedule. His BMI is 31  indicating obesity.  The patient's occupation is a corporate job which he describes as significantly stressful. He admits having been advised lifestyle modifications earlier but has not been able to make significant changes. He expresses concern about his symptoms and the impact they are making on his work life and daily activities.

Patient Profile: Mr. James  a 62-year-old African-American male  presents himself in the clinic today complaining of consistent chest pain for the past two weeks. He describes his pain as ""pressure like "" which usually starts in the center of the chest and sometimes radiates to his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath  specifically during physical exertion.  His wife reports he has been increasingly fatigued for the last month. He is a retired accountant  lives with his wife  and has a 20-pack year history of smoking  although he quit 10 years ago. Furthermore  he has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  poorly controlled due to inconsistent medication adherence. He is currently taking Amlodipine 5mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily.  He has a strong family history of heart disease; his father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 58. He admits being physically inactive and his diet is high in fats. He denies any history of illicit drug use. He does not have any known allergies. Mr. James’s BMI is 30 indicating he is obese.   The patient's prevailing complaints  along with his age  gender  race  smoking history  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia provide a high level of suspicion for coronary artery disease. His further workup would likely include laboratory testing  ECG  possibly a stress test  echocardiogram  and referral to a cardiologist for possible cardiac catheterization.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Brown  a 62-year old African-American male  presents to the clinic today reporting increasing shortness of breath  especially on exertion  and occasional chest discomfort over the past few weeks. The discomfort is described as a pressure sensation in the center of the chest  not associated with meals  and often relieved by rest. He expresses concern as his father died from a heart attack at the age of 65.  He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  Type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  averaging one pack per day. He admits that he is sedentary and overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30. He also shares that his diet is high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables.  He has no known drug allergies. Family history is positive for premature coronary artery disease with his father and two paternal uncles having experienced heart attacks before the age of 55. His mother had a stroke at the age of 70.  Upon further examination  blood pressure is slightly elevated with readings of 140/90 mmHg and his body mass index (BMI) is 30. An EKG shows minor ST-T wave changes. The rest of his physical examination  including cardiac auscultation  is unremarkable.  There is a strong suspicion of coronary artery disease given patient's age  symptoms  risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  smoking  family history  obesity) and minor changes on his EKG.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male who presents with a chief complaint of chest pain and shortness of breath  especially during times of physical exertion. The chest discomfort is described as a dull pressure-like sensation  radiating towards the left shoulder and sometimes accompanied by nausea. Mr. Johnson reports that this discomfort has been going on intermittently for about 2 months now but has taken a turn for the worse over the past week.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a known history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  both of which he has been managing for the past 6 years with Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively. He also has a 30-pack year smoking history  although he quit about 5 years ago. His father had a history of premature coronary artery disease  having suffered from a heart attack at the age of 50. He does not follow a regular exercise regimen  and his diet is predominantly high in fats and carbohydrates. He denies any known drug allergies. He has a sedentary lifestyle and works as an accountant. Despite the shortness of breath and chest discomfort  the patient denies syncope  palpitations  lower extremity edema  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  named John  retired automotive engineer  who presented to the clinic today reporting a two-month history of intermittent chest discomfort. The discomfort is generally described as a squeezing sensation  which is often associated with exertion and can last from 1 to 15 minutes  but relieves with rest. It is located in the central chest and occasionally radiates to his left arm. The patient also mentions experiencing similar discomfort after a large meal. He also complains of shortness of breath during mild physical activities which was not present six months ago. He denies any history of palpitations  syncope  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or lower limb edema.   The patient has an acknowledged 10-year history of hypertension and dyslipidemia  both are controlled with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively). He was a smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 6 years ago. His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.   No known drug allergies. Vaccinations up to date.   In terms of his lifestyle  he admits to minimal exercise and a diet balanced between meats  starches  fruits  and vegetables. He consumes alcohol infrequently and has never used illicit drugs but has been under moderate stress due to family matters.  On physical examination  he is alert  oriented  and appears well. His height is 5'10""  he weighs 210 pounds  the blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg in the right arm  pulse rate 70 bpm  respiratory rate 14 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6 F  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. On cardiovascular examination  there is no jugular venous distention  the carotid upstroke is brisk without bruits  the point of maximal impulse is not displaced  there are normal S1 and S2 without S3 or S4  and no rubs  murmurs or gallops are noted. His lung sounds were clear bilaterally  and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.

Patient Presentation: A male patient  64 years old  Caucasian  retired engineer  currently residing in Chicago  Illinois  was referred by his GP for further management of newly suspected Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).   He presents with complaints of discomfort and pressure-like pain in his center-left chest which often extends to his left arm. These episodes usually occur on physical exertion and are relieved by rest. He also has noticed episodes of shortness of breath  particularly on going upstairs or walking more than a block  which were not present six months ago.  Past medical history is significant for hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 3 years ago  both are currently controlled with medications. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  with a total of 40 pack-years. He admits to a diet high in cholesterol and saturated fats and limited physical activity. His father died of a myocardial infarction at age 67.   He currently takes Metformin 500 mg twice daily for diabetes  Lisinopril 10 mg once daily for hypertension  and Aspirin 81 mg once daily as recommended by his GP during his last visit. He reports medication compliance. His body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m^2.  He denies any recent illnesses  hospitalizations  surgical history  or allergies. His alcohol consumption is limited to social occasions  and he denies illicit drug use. He is married and lives with his wife. He has two grown children in good health.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic today for a routine follow-up appointment. He has been experiencing some intermittent chest discomfort and shortness of breath  particularly with exertion  for the past couple months. He describes the discomfort as a ""pressure"" that feels like ""someone is sitting on his chest."" Occasionally  the discomfort radiates to his left arm. Rest and sublingual nitroglycerin typically relieve these symptoms.  Early morning nausea and profuse sweating often accompany these episodes. His discomfort level today is reported to be 2 out of a 10-point scale  but it has peaked at 6 in the past. Smith reports that his symptoms do limit his daily activities  particularly the exercise he used to take and the physical part of his work.  Past medical history includes hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  all of which are managed with medications. He has been a smoker for 40 years  smoking a pack of cigarettes a day and has a strong family history of heart disease - his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 60 and his older brother had a stent placed for coronary artery disease at the age of 55.  On physical examination  he has a BMI of 30 kg/m2. He is alert  oriented  and in no acute distress. His blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg and heart rate is 85 bpm. Cardiac auscultation reveals regular rhythm without any murmurs. Pulmonary auscultation reveals clear lung fields.   Investigations including an EKG  stress test  and possibly cardiac catheterization may be necessary for further evaluation and treatment considerations of this patient’s suspected coronary artery disease.

Patient Information: A 63-year-old Caucasian male  retired  previously working in a stressful corporate job  current smoker with a 40 pack-year history  and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Issue: The patient presents with a chief complaint of exertional chest discomfort that radiates to his left arm and neck  occurring intermittently for the last six weeks. The discomfort typically lasts about 10-15 minutes and alleviated by rest. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional dizziness.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension diagnosed ten years ago  on medication with Lisinopril 20mg a day and Metoprolol 50mg a day. He also has controlled type-2 diabetes  diagnosed five years ago  managed with diet and Metformin 500mg twice a day. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 67  and his mother passed away at 72 due to stroke.  Physical Examination: On examination  he is a well-nourished male  not in acute distress. His blood pressure is 140/90mmHg  the pulse rate is 78 beats/minute  and respiratory rate is 18 breaths/minute  the body mass index is 27kg/m2. Cardiovascular exam is unremarkable with normal S1and S2 with no murmurs  and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Extremities do not have any edema.  This presentation is suggestive of stable angina pectoris secondary to coronary artery disease. Further evaluation including electrocardiogram (EKG) and potentially cardiac stress tests would be the next steps in management.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 67-year-old male from a Hispanic background  retired  a frequent smoker with moderate alcohol consumption and a diet high in saturated fats and cholesterol.  Chief Complaint: He presents with a primary complaint of recurrent chest discomfort occurring mainly during physical activities such as mowing the lawn or even during stressful situations. The discomfort is felt in the central chest  described as a 'heavy' or 'pressing' sensation radiating to the jaw and left arm which lasts for about 10-15 minutes each time.  History of Present Illness: These episodes have been increasing in frequency over the past three months. He denies associated shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or cold sweats. He noticed that the symptoms can be relieved by rest or by using nitroglycerin tablets prescribed by his primary care doctor.      Past Medical History: He has a past medical history of hyperlipidemia and hypertension  both being treated for the last five years with medication. He also suffers from Type II Diabetes  diagnosed seven years ago. There is no history of myocardial infarction  stroke  or any surgical procedures in the past. The patient also reports a strong family history of heart diseases  with his father having died of a heart attack at 60 and his elder brother recently undergoing angioplasty.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  blood pressure is 142/92 mm Hg  pulse 78/min  BMI 28  showing slight obesity. No jugular venous distension or peripheral edema is noticed. Cardiac auscultation reveals no murmurs  and lung sounds are clear. Basic cardiovascular examinations do not show express signs of heart failure.  This patient's current symptoms  along with his past medical and family history  strongly indicate probable Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Further tests  such as ECG  stress test or angiography  are recommended for a definitive diagnosis and to assess the disease's severity.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Castillo is a 67-year-old Hispanic male with reported fatigue over the last several months. He has been experiencing occasional chest pain  often described as a heavy  squeezing feeling  which usually occurs during physical activity and subsides with rest. More recently  however  he has noticed episodes of chest pain even at rest  sometimes awakening him from sleep.   This pain is occasionally associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. He denies any recent weight loss  but notes he has been unable to maintain his routine daily walks due to his symptoms. Mr. Castillo also reports a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently on Lisinopril and Simvastatin.   He has been a smoker for 35 years and generally consumes alcohol moderately. Family history is significant with his father suffering a heart attack at age 69 and his older brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 64. He lives at home with his wife  who has expressed growing concern over his health. He has owned a landscaping company until his retirement 5 years ago.   Mr. Castillo has not seen a healthcare provider for almost two years and has not been taking his medications regularly due to lack of access and poor health literacy. Lastly  he recently decided to seek medical attention due to worsening symptoms.

Patient Information: Mr. James Smith  65-year-old Caucasian male  retired banker  Chief Complaint: Chest discomfort and shortness of breath upon exertion for the past several weeks. Primarily experienced when climbing stairs or doing yard work. Relieved by rest.  Past Medical History: Hypertension managed with Lisinopril  Type II Diabetes managed with Metformin  high cholesterol on Atorvastatin. 30 pack-year smoking history  quit 5 years ago. Occasional alcohol use  non-drug user.  Family History: Father had a heart attack at 60. Mother has Type II diabetes and hypertension.  Review of Systems: No recent fever  fatigue  night sweats  cough  abdominal pain  altered bowel habits or urinary symptoms. Has experienced occasional lightheadedness but no episodes of syncope.  Physical Exam: Blood pressure 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 75 bpm  BMI 28  respiratory rate 14 breaths per minute  temperature 98.6 F. He is alert and oriented. Cardiovascular exam reveals regular rhythm without murmur. There are no peripheral signs of atherosclerosis. Chest is clear on auscultation and abdomen is soft  non-tender without organomegaly.  Additional Contextual details: Lives with wife  who reports he has been less active due to his symptoms. Has 2 adult children living out of state. Concerns about grandfather's ability to play with grandchildren due to symptoms. He enjoys gardening and reading in his spare time. Patient is visibly worried about his symptoms.

Chief Complaint: Chest pain   Patient Information: Mr. John Williams  a 65-year-old African American male  presents to the clinic with reports of chest pain that's been gradually worsening over the last three months. He describes it as a pressure-like discomfort located in the center of his chest that gets worse with physical exertion but relieves with rest. He also reports episodes of breathlessness and fatigue during normal activities which were previously easy for him.   Past Medical History: Mr. Williams has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years but quit 5 years ago. He is currently on antihypertensive and antidiabetic medications. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Social History: He lives with his wife and is a retired school teacher. He quit smoking but still drinks alcohol in moderation. He does not engage in regular exercise and has an unsatisfactory diet with high sodium and fat intake.  Physical Examination: Mr. Williams is obese with a BMI of 30. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and his pulse is 78 beats per minute. Auscultation reveals normal heart sounds with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Lower extremities show no signs of edema.   Investigations: If based on his symptoms and risk factors  diagnostic tests such as blood tests  ECG and possibly a stress test would be appropriate to help confirm the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Edward Turner  a 62-year-old Caucasian man  presents with a chief complaint of persistent  intermittent chest pain which has been occurring for several weeks. The chest discomfort is described as a tightness  usually lasting 2 to 5 minutes  that radiates to his left arm. The symptoms occur with exertion and are usually relieved by rest  though he notes two instances within the last week where it awakened him during the sleep.  Mr. Turner is a retired engineer  a lifetime smoker with a 45 pack-year history  and has a body mass index of 31  indicating obesity. He admits to a high-stress lifestyle with limited physical activity and acknowledges a diet high in saturated fats. He consumes alcohol moderately. There is a strong family history of heart disease  with his father having died from a heart attack in his early 50s and his brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his mid-40s.  He has a known history of hypertension managed with hydrochlorothiazide for the past seven years and has been on statin therapy (atorvastatin) for moderate hypercholesterolemia for four years. Despite these treatments  his blood pressure and cholesterol levels remain borderline high.  This presentation suggests the likelihood of coronary artery disease in Mr. Turner  considering his age  gender  lifestyle  family history  and uncontrolled risk factors. Further diagnostic tests including an electrocardiogram  cardiac enzyme test  and possibly a stress test or cardiac catheterization are required in order to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Information: A 63-year-old Caucasian male  retired railway worker  residing in New York  married with two adult children.  Chief Complaint: He is presenting with continual angina  described as a heavy  squeezing chest pain that radiates to his left arm and jaw  exacerbated by exertion and emotional stress and relieved partially by rest and nitroglycerin.  History of Present Illness: Chest discomfort began approximately 2 months ago but has progressively worsened. The patient also reports increasing episodes of breathlessness upon exertion and occasional episodes of restlessness at night accompanied by cold sweats. He denies syncope  palpitation  or edema.  Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension for 10 years  well controlled with daily lisinopril. He has hypercholesterolemia  managed with atorvastatin for the past 5 years. He was a 40-pack-year smoker but quit 7 years ago.   Family History: Father died at 70 years of age due to myocardial infarction; Mother alive at 87 years of age with hypertension and diabetes.  Social History: He is retired  a non-drinker  no illicit drug use.   Review of Systems: Denies recent fever  weight changes  gastrointestinal symptoms  or genitourinary symptoms.   Physical exam: Vital signs include BP 140/80  P 88  RR 18  T 98.7°F  BMI 28 kg/m2. Patient is alert  oriented  and in moderate distress associated with his pain. Cardiac exam revealed normal S1 and S2  no murmurs  irregular rhythm. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdomen is soft  non-tender and non-distended.   Lab Testing: ECG completed showing ST-segment depression suggestive of ischemia. Pending blood work to check for troponin levels  lipid panel  CBC  basic metabolic panel.  Impression: This man’s symptoms are indicative of stable angina secondary to possible coronary artery disease  given the risk factors of age  hypercholesterolemia  hypertension  smoking history  and positive family history.   Plan: Cardiology consult  hospital admission for further evaluation and management. Outlined lifestyle modifications including a low cholesterol diet  increased physical activity and cardiac rehabilitation. The patient was educated on the symptoms and signs of unstable angina and myocardial infarction  advised to present to the ER if the latter occur.

Patient: Mr. Smith  Caucasian male  aged 58 years old   Presenting Symptoms: Patient reports a 2-month history of experiencing intermittent chest pain often radiating to his left arm  accompanied by episodes of shortness of breath. The patient describes the chest pain as a feeling of ""pressure"" that worsens with physical activity but is relieved when at rest. It is non-radiating  intermittent in nature  and lasts for about 5-10 minutes. He also reports episodes of feeling dizzy.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago  which he has been managing with qd lisinopril 10 mg and metformin  respectively. He had been on a statin for high cholesterol levels but stopped his medication one year ago due to perceived side effects.  Lifestyle: The patient is a former smoker who quit 5 years ago  previously smoking one pack per day for over 30 years. Mr. Smith admits that his diet is poor  full of high-fat and high-cholesterol foods. He also mentions that he has led a mostly sedentary lifestyle  with minimal physical exercise.  Family History: His father suffered a myocardial infarction at age 60. He has one brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease in his early 50s.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 58-year-old Caucasian male who presents complaining of intermittent chest pain over the past two months  worse with exertion and relieved with rest. He also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  light-headedness  and a sense of impending doom during these episodes.   Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is on a daily regimen of hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin respectively. He has a known family history of myocardial infarctions at an early age  with his father dying suddenly of a heart attack at age 55. He currently smokes half a pack of cigarettes per day and admits to a sedentary lifestyle at his office job  but denies alcohol or drug use.   Recent Physical Examination:  Vital signs revealed blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg and heart rate of 105 bpm. A cardiovascular examination showed a regular rate and rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Chest exam was clear with no apparent respiratory distress. The rest of the physical examination was within normal limits.   Recent Laboratory Data:  Lipid profile was abnormal with LDL cholesterol of 180 mg/dL  HDL cholesterol of 40 mg/dL  and total cholesterol of 260 mg/dL. Other blood work including complete blood count and metabolic panel was unremarkable.   In summary  given Mr. Doe's risk factors  family history and presentation  clinical suspicion for coronary artery disease is high and further investigation may be necessary.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African-American male presenting today with complaints of on-and-off chest pain (angina) for the last 2 weeks  particularly when exercising or under stress. The pain is described as a heavy pressure sensation in the middle of the chest that sometimes radiates to his left arm and neck. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath with exertional activities.   Further probing reveals that he has a history and risk factors for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  including:  - Hypertension diagnosed ten years ago  currently under treatment - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed five years ago  managed with statins - History of smoking (1 pack/day) for about 30 years but he quit 5 years ago  - Family history of CAD: His father suffered from a heart attack at the age of 60 - Sedentary lifestyle with poor dietary habits  He has not previously been diagnosed with CAD  diabetes  or other cardiovascular diseases and has not undergone any surgical interventions in the past.
