Presentation Title: A Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) in Elderly Women  Slide 1: Introduction Begin with a brief introduction on the prevalence and significance of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) worldwide. Mention that CAD remains a leading cause of morbidity and mortality despite advances in diagnosis and therapeutic strategies.  Slide 2: Patient Profile Introduce the subject of your case study – a 72-year-old Hispanic woman. The patient is a retired kindergarten teacher who lives with her husband and is frequently visited by her children and grandchildren.   Slide 3: Past Medical History Discuss the patient's past medical history  which includes hypertension for which she has been on medication for 8 years. She is also a type 2 diabetic  under control with oral hypoglycemic agents for 5 years. Mention her lifestyle: A former smoker who quit 15 years ago  occasional alcohol drinker  follows a diet rich in carbohydrates.  Slide 4: Onset of CAD Discuss the initial symptoms that occurred 6 months ago. The patient began experiencing episodes of chest pain and shortness of breath  especially during physical exertion. She initially doubted these symptoms but the frequency and severity increased over time.   Slide 5: Diagnostics and Findings Detail how she was diagnosed with coronary artery disease. Explain that the patient underwent an EKG and a stress test  which suggested CAD. An angiogram revealed significant blockages in two of her coronary arteries.   Slide 6: Treatment and Management Discuss the treatment she received - a drug-eluting stent was placed in the obstructed arteries. She is now on dual antiplatelet therapy  β-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and statins for the management of CAD. Lifestyle modifications and a comprehensive diabetes care plan were also put in place.   Slide 7: Follow-up and Current Status Report on her current status post-treatment  including improvements and any persisting issues. Highlight that her chest pain and shortness of breath have significantly improved. She is active  living a qualitatively better life  and following her medication and lifestyle regimen rigidly.  Slide 8: Takeaways Conclude the presentation by offering insight gleaned from this case study  emphasizing the importance of timely and appropriate treatment and the role lifestyle plays in managing CAD.   Slide 9: Q&A Open the floor to questions  engaging the audience in a discussion about coronary artery disease using the presented case study as a reference.   Slide 10: References Display all references used while creating this presentation  ensuring credibility and the chance for listeners to read further if interested.   End of Presentation

Title: Case Presentation on Coronary Artery Disease  Slide 1: Introduction • Case Presentation on a patient with a history of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). • Exploring past medical history  current symptoms  and a careful examination to prepare a holistic treatment plan.  Slide 2: Demographics • Patient Information: Male  Age 65  Caucasian  Retired Bank Officer  a non-smoker with a history of moderate alcohol consumption. • BMI: 28  indicating overweight. • Lifestyle: Sedentary with limited physical exercise.  Slide 3: Past Medical History • History of Hypertension: Diagnosed with high blood pressure 10 years ago  controlled with medication. • Hyperlipidemia: Detected 5 years ago  also controlled with medication. • Family History: The patient's father suffered from CAD and underwent a bypass surgery at the age of 70.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints  • Symptoms: The patient complains of chest pain  particularly during physical exertion  which he describes as a heavy  pressing feeling in the centre of the chest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath and fatigue.   Slide 5: Clinical Assessment • Physical Examination: Appears distressed due to chest discomfort  pulse rate slightly increased. • Cardiovascular Examination: Mild elevation in blood pressure observed  heart sounds S1 and S2 heard normally  no additional murmurs.   Slide 6: Diagnostic Findings • ECG: The EKG showed T wave inversion in the anterior leads consistent with CAD. • Blood tests: Increased LDL cholesterol levels and moderately increased troponin level. • Coronary Angiography: Shows significant stenosis in the Left Anterior Descending artery.  Slide 7: Management Plan • Advise for lifestyle modification: Start regular exercise and diet modification to reduce BMI. • Adjustment of medications to manage symptoms and control risk factors. • Coronary artery bypass surgery (CABG) has been discussed as a potential treatment option given the significant obstruction in LAD. • Postoperative cardiac rehabilitation programme suggested for better patient outcomes.  Slide 8: Conclusion • A comprehensive care plan has been established for our patient which includes lifestyle changes  medication adjustments  possible surgical intervention  and a postoperative rehabilitation program. Regular follow-ups will ensure optimum care and health outcomes.

Title: A Case Study of Coronary Artery Disease  Slide 1: Introduction  An in-depth presentation of a case displaying a 68-year-old male patient diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Slide 2: Demographics Our patient  Mr. X  is an Asian male aged 68  residing in Melbourne. He is a retired engineer  married with two children. He has been living a sedentary lifestyle since his retirement.  Slide 3: Past Medical History He was formerly a smoker but quit twenty years ago. He also has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  which has been managed with medication for the past 8 years. His father died of a heart attack at age 71  indicating a potential genetic predisposition.  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints Mr. X sought medical care following episodes of chest pain  frequently experienced when he was walking or stressed  eased by rest. Associated symptoms included fatigue and shortness of breath.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Evaluation After detailed physical examination and laboratory investigation  including EKG and stress test  the patient was diagnosed with significant CAD.  Slide 6: Current Medical Status The patient was found to have three-vessel disease on coronary angiography  with a high degree of stenosis. His blood cholesterol levels were also elevated  and the blood pressure control was suboptimal despite medication.  Slide 7: Management Plan  Mr. X was prescribed a modified dietary plan  an increase in moderate-level physical activities  along with medications for managing his blood pressure  cholesterol  and blood sugar. Invasive solutions like coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) were also discussed given the severity of his disease.  Slide 8: Conclusion This case reinforces the need for regular follow-ups in patients with risk factors and how lifestyle modifications can contribute to controlling the progress of CAD. Medical professionals should consider both non-invasive and invasive solutions depending on the patient's condition. This case thus highlights the complexity of managing CAD patients.  Slide 9: Questions & Answers Feedback and Clarification.   Note: Always maintain strict patient confidentiality and respect for privacy when discussing or presenting cases.

Title: Case Presentation on Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Slide 1: Introduction The purpose of this presentation is to provide an in-depth overview of a case involving Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  emphasizing its symptoms  cause  and complications.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our patient is a 56-year-old Caucasian male  identified as 'Patient X.' He is a non-smoker and mildly obese (BMI: 30.2 kg/m²). His family history holds significant for CAD  with both his father and grandfather suffering from the disease.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Patient X has a history of high blood pressure and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes five years ago. Compliance to medication has been inconsistent and regular check-ups were not maintained. An unhealthy diet coupled with lack of physical exercise has contributed to his current condition.  Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms He presented with complaints of consistent chest pain for two weeks  specifically during high stress and physical exertion  indicating stable angina as a key symptom. The discomfort was described as a squeezing pressure or heaviness  radiating to the left arm and jaw.  Slide 5: Investigations & Diagnosis EKG displayed ST segment depression  and blood tests indicated elevated cardiac enzymes  both indicative of CAD. An Echo-cardiogram revealed reduced blood flow to the heart muscle  confirming the diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease.  Slide 6: Management Conservative management was first introduced with targeted lifestyle modifications such as a balanced low-sodium diet  regular exercise and  stress management. Medication regimen included anti-platelets  cholesterol-lowering drugs  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors. Due to severe stenosis seen in coronary angiography  he was recommended for coronary artery bypass grafting.  Slide 7: Conclusion The prompt recognition of CAD symptoms and understanding of the patient's past medical history contributed to an effective management plan. The crucial aspect remains lifestyle modification and regular follow-up to manage CAD.  Slide 8: Questions & Discussion Open floor for any questions or further discussion on the presented case. How can we better educate and motivate patients like 'Patient X' to make necessary lifestyle changes? How can we ensure regular follow-up in such cases?

Title: Case Presentation on a Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Slide 1: Introduction • Topic: Understanding Coronary Artery Disease in the geriatric age group. A case of Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male suffering from CAD.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics & Past Medical History • Demographics: Mr. Doe is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanical engineer  living with his wife in a suburban area. He has a past history of smoking for 2 decades but quit 15 years ago. He reported a sedentary lifestyle and an irregular diet.  • Medical History: He was diagnosed with Type-2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago and Hyperlipidemia two years ago.   Slide 3: Recent Medical Developments & Presenting Symptoms • Mr. Doe was prescribed medication to manage his T2DM and Hyperlipidemia but not fully compliant to the regimen.  • He recently started experiencing episodes of angina primarily exertional  shortness of breath  and occasional palpitations.   Slide 4: Preliminary Investigations • Blood Tests: Indicated high levels of LDL and reduced HDL levels  slightly increased blood sugar levels. • Resting ECG showed ST-depression  which pointed to possible ischemia.   Slide 5: Diagnosis • With his persistent symptoms  ECG findings  and his past medical history  he was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease.  Slide 6: Management and Treatment Plan • Prescription of anti-anginal medications  anti-platelets  and cholesterol-regulating medications. • Lifestyle modifications emphasized - Low cholesterol diet  increased physical activity  closely monitored diabetic control. •Consideration of invasive procedures like angioplasty or bypass surgery based on future developments and evaluations.  Slide 7: Long-Term Considerations • Regular check-ups and monitoring are essential to prevent complications such as Acute Coronary Syndrome or heart failure.  • Sustained adherence to medication and lifestyle changes can significantly improve his quality of life and prognosis.  Slide 8: Conclusion • Coronary Artery Disease is a significant public health issue  especially among the elderly population. • Early detection  effective management  and promoting healthy lifestyle changes are crucial in reducing the disease's morbidity and mortality. Slide 1: Title: Case Presentation: Patient with Coronary Artery Disease  Slide 2: Demographics:  The patient in focus is a 58-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired military officer and resides in the urban area of California. He lives with his wife and two adult children. The patient is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate-to-high alcohol consumption.   Slide 3: Medical History: The patient has a notable history of hypertension  diagnosed ten years prior. He has been on antihypertensive therapy  but his adherence to medication has been inconsistent. Additionally  he has experienced elevated cholesterol levels for the past six years.  Slide 4: Symptoms & Diagnosis: The patient presented with complaints of recurrent chest pain  primarily during physical exertion. After clinical examination and further diagnostic tests including ECG  echocardiogram  and coronary angiogram  he was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Slide 5: Risk Factors: Primary risk factors for this patient include age  gender  hypertension  elevated cholesterol levels  and a history of heavy alcohol consumption. His sedentary lifestyle post-retirement paired with an inconsistent adherence to hypertension medication may have contributed to the disease progression.  Slide 6: Treatment & Management: The patient is currently on a regimen that includes medications like Beta-blockers and Statins  which are intended to lower the blood pressure and cholesterol levels  respectively. A reiteration of the importance of medication adherence has been emphasized. A cardiac rehabilitation program has been advocated with lifestyle amendments that include a balanced diet  regular exercise  and abstinence from alcohol.  Conclusion: This case resonates with the commonly observed trend of CAD in males above the age of 50 with risk factors such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and high alcohol intake. Management through medication  lifestyle changes  and emphasis on medication adherence are crucial components of care.  Following the presentation  a discussion can take place surrounding improvements in patient education in order to better manage conditions like CAD.

Introduction: Welcome everyone to this case presentation. Today  we will be discussing about a patient who has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Patient Demographics: Our patient is a 63-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Doe. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban region in Texas. His height is 6 ft  he weighs 220 lbs  which puts him in the obese category with a BMI of 30. He is a former smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a rich history of health conditions. He was diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 43 and type-2 diabetes at the age of 52. He has been on medication to control these  namely  Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes along with dietary modifications. However  his adherence to these medications and lifestyle changes have been inconsistent.   Apart from these  he has faced episodes of dyslipidemia. His latest lipid profile showed elevated levels of LDL cholesterol and triglycerides and decreased levels of HDL cholesterol  indicative of a high risk for atherogenesis. He was prescribed statin therapy for this but was noncompliant due to reported side effects.  Present Condition: Mr. Doe recently came to the clinic complaining of chest discomfort during exertion that relieved with rest. His ECG revealed ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion. Troponin levels were also increased. Given his risk factors and symptoms  he was diagnosed with stable angina  a manifestation of coronary artery disease.  Conclusion: CAD poses a significant risk to Mr. Doe's health and quality of life  considering his comorbidities and lifestyle. Early recognition  strict maintenance of blood pressure  glucose and cholesterol levels  and commitment to lifestyle changes can slow the progression of CAD and decrease the possibility of adverse cardiac events.  In our next session  we will discuss the comprehensive management plan for Mr. Doe that combines pharmacological treatments and lifestyle modifications  to maintain his quality of life. We will also discuss the ways to enhance his compliance to these treatments.  Thank you for your attention.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a Middle-Aged Male Patient: A Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction - Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 55-year-old Caucasian male. - Occupation: Office worker - Lifestyle: Sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activities.  Slide 2: Past Medical History - Smoker for the past 30 years. - High alcohol intake: Approximately 20 units/week. - Obesity with a BMI of 31 kg/m2. - Family History: Father died from myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Slide 3: Symptoms and Diagnosis - Presented with symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  and fatigue.  - Diagnosis: After a series of tests - ECG  stress test  and coronary angiography  the patient is diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Slide 4: Pathophysiology of CAD - CAD is commonly caused by the build-up of plaque in the coronary arteries  reducing blood flow to the heart. - In this case  the patient's sedentary lifestyle  smoking habits  alcohol intake  and genetic predisposition created the environment for plaque formation and progression of CAD.  Slide 5: Current Management - Lifestyle modifications advised: Smoking cessation  alcohol reduction  diet modifications  and commencement of regular exercise. - Medical treatment initiated: Prescription of low-dose aspirin  a statin for cholesterol  and a beta-blocker to manage hypertension.  Slide 6: Prognosis and Follow-Up  - Follow-up recommended with a cardiologist every three months. - With appropriate lifestyle modifications and medication adherence  prognosis can be favorable. - Early detection and intervention is key in managing CAD and preventing acute incidents like myocardial infarction.  Slide 7: Summary - This case exhibits how lifestyle factors can significantly contribute to the development of CAD. - It reiterates the importance of early detection  lifestyle changes  and strict adherence to medication for optimal management of CAD.   Slide 8: Case Study Questions  - What are the primary risk factors evident in this case? - How do these risk factors contribute to the development of CAD? - What are the cornerstones of CAD management? Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and type II diabetes mellitus  who has been experiencing progressively increasing episodes of chest pain over the past 6 months. These episodes typically occur while he is engaging in physical activities  like climbing the stairs  but have also occurred during times of emotional stress. He describes the pain as a heavy pressure behind his sternum that might radiate to his left arm  occasionally accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. He reports that the pain is usually relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. The patient has been a smoker for the past 40 years. Patient's father had his first myocardial infarction at 66-years-old. He is currently on hydrochlorothiazide  metformin  and atorvastatin. However  he has been non-compliant with his medications and diet.

Patient Presentation: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented with a two-week history of intermittent chest pain  typically induced by physical activity and relieved by rest. The chest pain is often associated with shortness of breath  fatigue  and episodes of profuse sweating.   Past Medical History: The patient has been hypertensive for the last 15 years and was diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus five years ago  both managed with medication. Conference with the patient revealed that he was a smoker until 10 years ago and has a family history of coronary artery disease with his father having suffered a myocardial infarction at 65. The patient is also known to have a high fat diet and does minimal physical activity.   Clinical Findings: Vital signs showed slightly elevated blood pressure (150/95). Cardiovascular examination revealed mild tachycardia with no other abnormalities. No significant findings were noted in respiratory  gastrointestinal and central nervous system examinations. The patient appeared anxious  and the rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.   Synthesis: The patient's age  gender  positive family history  previous smoking habit  dietary practices  hypertension  diabetes  and physical inactivity collectively pose a high risk for coronary artery disease  which is suspected given the chest pain characteristics and accompanying symptoms.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Nelson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents with intermittent chest pain and shortness of breath  which have been worsening over the past 4 months. The chest pain is often exacerbated by physical activity and subsides at rest. Relevant medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. The patient has been non-compliant with his prescribed medications  including Aspirin  Metformin  Lisinopril  and a Statin regimen. A family history reveals a father who suffered a myocardial infarction in his 50s. Mr. Nelson is a former smoker with a pack history of 35 years  has a sedentary lifestyle  and admits to following a diet high in processed and fatty foods. His BMI is 29.8  indicating overweight status. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure reading of 155/90 mmHg and an increased heart rate. He denies experiencing nausea or lightheadedness.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a 4-month history of gradual onset  intermittent chest pain radiating to the left arm  exacerbated with exertion and relieved by rest. He also reports general fatigue and occasion shortness of breath. The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension and dyslipidemia controlled on amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. He has a 35-pack-year history of smoking  and a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  with his father having a myocardial infarction in his late 60s. On physical examination  he is overweight with a BMI of 30  blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg  and heart rate of 85 bpm. Cardiovascular examination reveals no murmurs or added sounds. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. Given his cardiac risk factors  clinical presentation  and family history  the patient is suspected to have coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old African American male  Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Both conditions are managed with oral medications. The patient is also a former smoker  having quit smoking about a decade ago  but has a cumulative smoking history of 30 pack-years. There is a documented familial history of premature coronary artery disease; the patient's father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 60. A sedentary lifestyle  regularly consuming a high-fat diet  and obesity with a BMI of 32 kg/m2 are additional risk factors.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing episodes of exertional chest pain radiating to the left arm over the last two weeks. The pain typically occurs with strenuous activities and subsides with rest. The patient also reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a feeling of tightness in the chest area. Recently  the patient noticed a decrease in their usual exercise tolerance. There have been no reported episodes of syncope or palpitations.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Jackson  a 57-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes presents with symptoms of chronic stable angina. Over the past month  Mr. Jackson has experienced intermittent chest discomfort  pressure  and tightness  primarily during physical exertion and relieved by rest. The episodes tend to last for 2 to 5 minutes. His chest discomfort also increases in frequency and severity when he is under stress. The pain does not radiate  and there is no associated dyspnea  nausea  or diaphoresis.  Mr. Jackson's risk factors include age  gender  ethnicity  uncontrolled hypertension  and diabetes. He is a former smoker but quit ten years ago. His father had a myocardial infarction at 62 years of age.   On physical examination  his blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg  heart rate is 80 beats per minute  and heart rhythm is regular without murmurs. He has peripheral edema. His chest examination is normal.  In conclusion  Mr. Jackson's symptoms of chest discomfort on exertion  describe a stable pattern  suggestive of significant coronary artery disease (CAD). His risk factors and family history increase the likelihood of CAD. His physical findings are relatively unremarkable  but his blood pressure is not at target  which adds to his cardiovascular risk.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous smoking habit of 20 pack-years  but quit 15 years ago. He presents with a three-day history of intermittent central chest pain that radiates to his left arm. The pain is especially notable during physical activities like climbing stairs or walking on an incline. He describes the pain as tight and squeezing and is sometimes associated with shortness of breath and profuse sweating. His pain does not subside with rest. He reports having similar but less severe episodes over the past 6 months which had resolved on their own. He has no known allergies  his current medications include amlodipine and atorvastatin  and he has never had any prior surgeries. His father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 70. He does not have diabetes  nor any significant pulmonary or renal diseases. On physical examination  vital signs are normal  cardiac exam reveals normal S1 and S2 with no additional heart sounds  but there's presence of 2/6 systolic murmur. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. His ECG indicates signs of ischemia.

Patient is a 64-year-old African American male with a known medical history of hypertension  type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  and Hyperlipidemia now presenting with chronic exertional angina for the past 3 months. The patient experiences a gripping chest discomfort radiating to the left arm  typically triggered by physical effort (walking or climbing stairs) and relieved by rest. The episodes usually last for about 2-5 minutes. Recently  he has noted increased frequency of the chest pain episodes and also mentioned experiencing similar chest discomfort while at rest. Additionally  he reports episodes of exertional dyspnea. He is a former smoker and has a family history of premature coronary artery disease. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male.   Medical History: Mr. Johnson is a non-smoker with well-controlled hypertension. He has a family history of early-onset heart disease. Mr. Johnson has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes that is managed on oral hypoglycemic drugs.   Presenting Complaint: He visits the clinic complaining of recurring chest pain over the past two months  especially with physical exertion. The pain typically radiates to his left arm. He also reports dyspnea on exertion and increasing fatigue over the past few weeks. He has had no previous episodes of chest pain but noted recently that the pain is relieved by rest and nitroglycerin.   Relevant Findings: On physical examination  he appears fatigued but is not in acute distress. His blood pressure is 138/85 mmHg  heart rate is 77 bpm  and his BMI is 30.5. The cardiovascular examination reveals no abnormalities. His diabetes is well controlled  with an HbA1c of 6.8%.  Hypothesis: Symptoms of exertional chest pain  left arm pain  dyspnea  and fatigue  in combination with his age  gender  medical history  and family history  are concerning for stable angina due to coronary artery disease.  Plan: Recommend further diagnostic testing with a stress test and possibly a coronary angiogram. Management will be guided by test results and potentially involve lifestyle modification  medication management  and potentially invasive procedures. Immediate referral to a cardiologist is a next step.

Patient Information: 65-year-old Caucasian male  Chief Complaint: Intermittent chest pain for 3 weeks  Medical History: Hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10 mg daily)  type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled by diet and Metformin  and a 30 pack-year smoking history. No previous surgeries or hospitalizations.   Presenting Symptoms: Reports consistent  dull pain in the left side of the chest  radiating to the left arm and jaw  worse on exertion and relieved by rest. The pain is sometimes associated with shortness of breath and light-headedness. There are no other associated symptoms like fever  cough  headache  or weight loss. Denies any recent trauma or injury. No family history of heart disease.  On examination  the patient appears to be in moderate distress. Vital signs are stable. Cardiac auscultation notes regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary exam is unremarkable. Other systemic examinations reveal no abnormal findings.

Patient Profile: Mr. Richard  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  ex-smoker with a 20-year pack history  presents with chronic chest pain and difficulty in breathing.  Medical History: The patient has a significant medical history with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and systemic hypertension. Two years ago  he was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels that have been resistant to dietary and lifestyle changes. He has been on anti-diabetic  antihypertensives  and statin therapy for years. His father had coronary artery disease (CAD) and passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Richard complains of chronic  dull chest pain over the past 2 months  which initially occurred only during excessive physical activity but now even during rest. The pain  located in the center of the chest  often radiates to the left shoulder and arm. He describes the pain as a ""squeezing"" sensation or ""feeling of pressure"". In addition  he has episodes of shortness of breath  lightheadedness  and excessive fatigue. No palpitations  syncope  or loss of consciousness.  Based on the medical history and symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD) seems likely. Further diagnostic tests such as ECG  stress test  and coronary angiography for definitive diagnosis and the extent of disease are warranted. The primary concern is managing angina and preventing myocardial infarction or other complications of CAD.

Demographics: A 56-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases – his father had a myocardial infarction at age 62 and his mother had a stroke at age 65. He is a current smoker with a 20-pack year smoking history. His medications include metformin for diabetes and lisinopril for hypertension.  Presenting Symptoms: He presents with a 2-week history of shortness of breath and chest pain. The chest pain is described as pressure-like sensation in the mid-chest area  occurring intermittently  frequently during physical exertion and relieved by rest. The pain lasts for around 10 minutes and radiates to his left arm. He also reports occasional episodes of fatigue  dizziness and diaphoresis.

Patient Description: Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old African-American male.  Relevant Medical History: He is hypertensive  diabetic for the last 15 years and has a 25-year history of smoking one pack per day  although he quit smoking 5 years ago. There is a significant family history of early-onset coronary artery disease.  Relevant Symptoms on Presentation: For the past 2 weeks  he has been experiencing worsening exertional chest discomfort  radiating to his left arm  which lasts around 10-15 minutes and resolves with rest. Additionally  he reports associated symptoms of shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and episodes of lightheadedness.   Recent Findings: Patient's EKG shows ST depressions in leads II  III  and aVF during symptom onset. His cardiac biomarkers are within the normal range.   Impression: The patient's symptoms  along with the changes noted on EKG and significant risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and family history of CAD)  suggest stable angina due to suspected coronary artery disease.

A 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 25-year history of smoking presents with recurrent angina. The patient characterizes the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that radiates to his left arm and occurs with exertion or emotional stress  but resolves with rest. He also occasionally experiences shortness of breath  especially when carrying out physical activities. The episodes of angina increased in frequency and severity over the past three months. He denies any symptoms of syncope  palpitations  or lower extremity swelling. His current medications include atorvastatin and a daily aspirin which he has been taking for the past five years. He lives with his wife  has two adult children and works as a civil engineer. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 65.

Patient is a 67-year-old African American male  with a medical history notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. He presents with chronic  worsening angina over the past two months. The patient describes the chest pain as heavy pressure in the central chest  classically radiating to the left jaw and arm. The pain is precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin use. He also reports increasing episodes of dyspnea with less strenuous activity than before and occasional diaphoresis. No history of diabetes  stroke  or early heart disease in the family. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. His physical examination is unremarkable  without signs of heart failure. ECG shows signs of previous silent myocardial infarction.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old African-American male.   Medical History: Hypertension controlled by angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus managed by oral hypoglycemics. Never smoked. No family history of heart disease.  Presenting Complaints: Victim of recent episode of central  crushing  and squeezing chest pain radiating to left shoulder and neck lasting for 30 minutes associated with shortness of breath. Pain was rated as 8 on a scale of 1-10. Experienced couple of similar  but lesser intense  episodes over the last week which were self-relieved.   Associated Symptoms: Nausea  profuse sweating  and sensation of palpitations during these episodes. Reports weight gain of 10 pounds in the last six months with associated fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. No complaints of cough  fever  or any urinary symptoms.  Clinical Impression: Symptom profile suggestive of coronary artery disease  likely exertional angina extending to unstable angina.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African-American male.  Medical History: The patient has a documented history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He was a smoker for 20 years but quit smoking 10 years ago. His family history includes his father who suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.  Presenting Problems: He presents with a two-week history of exertional chest pain which radiates to his left arm. He additionally reports shortness of breath and fatigue. The pain is relieved with rest and is increasing in frequency.  Problem Representation: 65-year-old male with risk factors of a history of smoking  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and a strong family history  now presents with increasing episodes of exertional chest pain radiating to left arm  associated with dyspnea and fatigue suggestive of coronary artery disease.

Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes presents with difficulty in breathing and chest pain for the past three weeks. The patient descibes the pain as consistent  heavy with a squeezing sensation in the chest that sometimes radiates to his left arm. He also complains of fatigue  dizziness  nausea  and light-headedness. The chest pain is aggravated by physical activity and is relieved by rest. The patient has a 40 pack-year history of smoking and a family history of coronary artery disease. He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and lipid lowering therapy. His review of systems is positive for recent weight loss and decreased appetite.

Patient Representation:  A 67-year-old African American male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and type 2 diabetes presents with exertional chest pain and intermittent shortness of breath for the past two months. The patient describes the chest pain as pressure-like and radiating to his left arm  occurring mainly with exertion and subsiding with rest. The patient has no history of previous myocardial infarction or any cardiac procedures. He is a former smoker but quit 10 years ago. On examination  his blood pressure is slightly elevated  but other vitals are within range. A 12 lead EKG shows non-specific ST-segment changes. These symptoms  in view of his significant risk factors (hypertension  high cholesterol  type 2 diabetes)  suggest a high likelihood of coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker and non-alcoholic  with a history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with recurrent episodes of chest pain. The chest pain  described as crushing in nature  is predominantly on the left side  radiates to the left arm  and is frequently triggered by physical exertion or emotional stress  and relieved by rest. He also reports accompanying symptoms including shortness of breath  sweating  and fatigue. He is compliant with his medications which include metformin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril. He does not have any known drug allergies. The patient's family history is significant for coronary artery disease  with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. His BMI indicates overweight and physical examination reveals slightly high blood pressure. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and his diet involves high fatty and carbohydrate content.

Patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  uncontrolled type II diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. He is a current smoker with a 30-pack-year history of smoking. The patient presents to the office with new onset of chest pain for the past two weeks. He describes the pain as ""pressure"" in the center of his chest  typically triggered by exercise and relieved with rest. He also noticed episodes of shortness of breath  and lightheadedness during these episodes of chest pain. He denies associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting or diaphoresis. In emergency situations  the patient experienced chest pain at rest. His father had a heart attack at age 50. He is non-compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive and diabetic medications.  EKG shows evidence of myocardial ischemia. His elevated troponin levels suggest myocardial damage. The patient is likely suffering from stable angina pectoris  which may have recently transitioned to unstable angina or acute coronary syndrome given his symptoms at rest.

Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old African American male with a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents with gradually worsening chest discomfort over the past few months. He describes this discomfort as a pressure sensation in the center of his chest that tends to increase with exertion and is somewhat relieved by rest. Recently  he has experienced two episodes even while at rest. The discomfort radiates to his left arm and is sometimes accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes a day  has a sedentary lifestyle and consumes a diet high in cholesterol and fats. The review of systems is otherwise notable for increased fatigue and decreased exercise tolerance. Pedigree analysis reveals a strong familial predisposition to cardiovascular diseases - his father and two uncles had myocardial infarction in their 60's. Physical exam is significant for a blood pressure of 155/95 mm Hg  BMI of 30  and diminished peripheral pulses.

Patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  currently a smoker with a 20-pack year history  presents with a 3-month history of angina  characterized by central chest discomfort radiating to the left arm  particularly upon exertion and relieved by rest. Further characterized by shortness of breath  excessive sweat  and occasional nausea. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and Type II diabetes mellitus  which are being treated with medication. His family history is notable for his father who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. On presentation  his blood pressure is 160/90 mmHg  pulse 90 bpm  BMI 30 kg/m2  and physical examination is unremarkable. ECG shows ST segment depression and T wave inversion in the anterior leads. Further definitive testing may be indicated to confirm the diagnosis and guide treatment.

Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus presents with a chief complaint of intermittent  exertional chest pain radiating to his left arm over the past three months. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation alleviated by rest and sublingual nitroglycerin. He denies any associated symptoms like shortness of breath  diaphoresis  nausea  or vomiting. His current medications include ACE inhibitors  beta-blockers  and statins. He is an ex-smoker  having quit 2 years back with a 25 pack-years history. He reports moderate alcohol consumption and denies any illicit drug use. His father had a history of fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 62. On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious  with pulse 80/min  blood pressure 145/85 mmHg  BMI of 30  and normal heart sounds. The EKG shows transient ST segment depressions during episodes of chest pain. Cardiac enzymes are within normal limits.

Patient Representation:   Mr. Jones  a 65-year-old African American male  presents with a 2 month-history of intermittent chest pain  especially after exertion or emotional stress. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2  both controlled under medication for 10 years. The patient also has a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient notes that the chest pain is central and pressurized  sometimes radiating to his left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath and sweating. These episodes typically last for 5-10 minutes and alleviated with rest. No associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or syncope. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 55. The patient has no known drug allergies. On examination  he is in mild distress due to pain  cardiovascular examination reveals blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg and heart rate of 80 beats per minute with no murmurs  rubs or gallops.

A 65-year-old African-American male patient with a notable medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with complaints of episodic chest pain  particularly during exertion for the last two months. The pain is described as a pressure-like sensation in the middle of his chest that usually lasts about 10-15 minutes  abating once he rests. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath and profuse perspiration. He reports smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years and has a paternal history of myocardial infarction at a relatively young age (60). He denies any episodes of syncope  palpitations  or orthopnea. His regular medications include metformin for diabetes  amlodipine for hypertension  and atorvastatin for high cholesterol. He has no known drug or food allergies. Physical examination reveals an obese gentleman in moderate distress while talking. Other findings include blood pressure of 155/90mmHg  a heart rate of 80 bpm  intact jugular venous pressure  normal heart sounds without murmurs  and no peripheral edema. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.

Mr. Ahmed is a 56-year-old South Asian male with a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes who presents with 2 months of progressive chest pain. The pain is described as a constant  squeezing  central chest pain that radiates to his left arm  lasting approximately 10-15 mins at rest  but can get worse with moderate exercise like climbing stairs.  His symptoms also include shortness of breath  fatigue  and sweating  but he denies fevers  chills  cough  or palpitations. He has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at age 52. He is a non-smoker and does not consume alcohol but is sedentary and struggles with obesity. His symptoms are suggestive of angina due to coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Diabetes mellitus type 2  who presents with worsening chest pain that radiates to his left arm. The pain started 3 days ago and is associated with shortness of breath  fatigue  and a feeling of tightness in the chest. The patient reports that the pain worsens with exertion  such as climbing stairs or carrying grocery bags. Patient has an 8-year smoking history (quit 20 years ago) with a family history of heart disease and stroke. He denies any associated symptoms such as dizziness  nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or loss of consciousness. Physical examination reveals a moderately obese male in mild distress due to pain  with diaphoresis  blood pressure of 152/94 mmHg  pulse rate 86 bpm  respiratory rate 20 bpm  and SPO2 95% in room air. Cardiac examination shows a regular rhythm without any murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Patient's ECG shows T wave inversions in leads II  III  aVF  and V2-V6. A diagnosis of unstable Angina related to possible Coronary Artery Disease is considered.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Peterson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  current smoker with a 40 pack-year history  presents with a two-week history of intermittent chest pain radiating to his left arm. Characteristically  his pain is typically provoked by exertion and relieved by rest.   Past Medical History: Mr. Peterson has a known history of Hypertension and Type II diabetes  both well managed on medication. His father died from a heart attack at the age of 58.  Current Symptoms: Patient reports a recent history of 'chest tightness'  brief episodes of dizziness  shortness of breath upon exertion  and fatigue. He denied any palpitations  syncope  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.   Family History: His mother had Type II diabetes and his younger brother is currently being treated for hypertension.

Patient Problem Representation:  A 63-year-old male presents with a two-week history of recurring chest pain that tends to get worse during activities and relieves with rest. He characterizes the pain as a pressure-like sensation that sometimes radiates to his left arm. Accompanying symptoms include shortness of breath and occasional episodes of sweating. He has a history of high blood pressure for 10 years and type II diabetes mellitus for the past 8 years  both controlled by medication. He smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 67. He is non-compliant with his diet and exercise regimen. There is no history of similar episodes in the past. The patient has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28  denoting overweight. His ejection fraction is 50%.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male   Medical History: Long-standing history of hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus  for which he takes metformin and lisinopril. Ex-smoker  with a 20 pack-year smoking history  which stopped about 10 years ago. He had a previous myocardial infarction 5 years ago.   Chief Complaint: Constant  dull  and central chest pain for the past 3 hours  radiating to the left arm and jaw. Accompanied by nausea  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis.   Physical Examination Findings: Vital signs reveal blood pressure of 140/90mmHg  pulse 105 bpm  respiration rate of 20 breaths/min  and O2 Sat 95% on room air. Pale  diaphoretic patient appears to be in mild distress. Chest exam has regular rhythm with no murmur. There are decreased breath sounds at the right base. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.   Conclusion: The symptoms of chest pain  nausea  shortness of breath  and diaphoresis in this patient with previous coronary artery disease  hypertension  and diabetes suggest an acute coronary syndrome  likely a myocardial infarction. The patient needs immediate cardiac evaluation including EKG and cardiac markers.

Patient Profile: Mr. Davis  a 62-year-old male with an extensive history of smoking 2 packs/day for the past 30 years and poorly controlled Type 2 diabetes mellitus.  Medical History: In addition to his smoking and diabetes  Mr. Davis has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been inconsistently compliant with his medications. There is a strong family history of heart diseases with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Davis has been experiencing exertional chest pain over the past 3 weeks  which typically lasts for 10-15 minutes and is relieved by rest. The pain has been progressively worsening in intensity and has been associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and a sense of impending doom. He denies any associated nausea  vomiting  or radiation of pain.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr Davis is mildly obese with a BMI of 32. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 158/100mm Hg and heart rate of 86 beats/min. Cardiovascular examination revealed no abnormalities.  Final Assessment: Given Mr. Davis' age  male gender  diabetes  smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history of heart disease  and his presentation with typical angina symptoms  he is suspected to have Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The suspicion is high  necessitating immediate hospital admission and further cardiac evaluation.

Patient X is a 63-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and diabetes mellitus who comes with complaints of angina-like chest pain for the past several days. He describes the pain as squeezing and tight  located in the central chest area that radiates to his left arm and is exacerbated by physical activities such as climbing stairs. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  fatigue  and excessive sweating during these episodes. The mentioned symptoms worsen during stressful situations and are alleviated by rest and the use of nitroglycerin. His father had myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his younger brother suffers from angina pectoris. Cardiac review of systems is positive for orthopnea and exertional dyspnea. Besides  the patient reports that he is a former smoker and has been quit for 5 years  but previously had a 20 pack-year history.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old African American male with a 15-year history of type II diabetes and hypertension. He has been a 1 pack a day smoker for 40 years and has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having suffered a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 72. Lately  he's been experiencing occasional periods of crushing chest pain that typically occurs with physical exertion and lasts about 10-15 minutes. The pain radiates to his left shoulder and is associated with shortness of breath  occurring nearly every day for the past week. He notes that taking nitroglycerin tablets and rest usually alleviates the chest discomfort. However  the frequency of episodes has increased in the past two days. He also mentions feeling unusually fatigued even with minor exertion during this period and has episodes of cold  clammy sweats. He has not experienced any nausea  vomiting  or palpitations.

Patient is a 65-year-old male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-year history of smoking. The patient presented to the emergency department experiencing distressing chest pain and shortness of breath that started while he was exerting himself in the garden. The chest pain can be characterized as a pressure-like sensation  worsened with physical activity and lessened with rest. The pain also radiates to the left arm and jaw. Accompanying symptoms include diaphoresis and nausea. The patient rated the initial chest pain as an 8 on a scale from 0 to 10. He also has a family history of heart disease in his father and a brother. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs and is currently employed as an accountant. The patient is alert  oriented  but appears anxious. His blood pressure on arrival was 150/90 mmHg  heart rate was 100 beats per minute  oxygen saturation 92% on room air  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute.

Patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  known diabetic (controlled with metformin) and a 30-year pack-a-day smoker  with a family history of coronary heart disease  presenting with complaints of persisting severe chest pain radiating down the left arm and shortness of breath  particularly when exercising  over the past three weeks. The patient also reveals a two-month history of episodes of nocturnal awakening due to chest discomfort and increasing fatigue. The pain is characterized as tightness and fullness  unrelieved by rest. Patient denies nausea  vomiting  and diaphoresis. On examination  patient is afebrile  blood pressure is 150/90  heart rate is 76/min  and respiratory rate is 18/min. There are no audible heart murmurs or crepitations in lungs. EKG shows ST depressions and T wave inversions. The patient is alert and oriented and pain is currently under control. Symptoms suggest ischemia  consistent with the patient's advanced risk factors for coronary artery disease. Following diagnosis confirmation  treatment will include optimization of modifiable risk factors and medical management  with consideration for revascularization procedures.

Patient Presentation: A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with a 2 week history of exertional chest pain.  Problem Representation: 65yo African-American M w/ PMHx HTN  HLD  and heavy smoking history presents with classic angina symptoms of exertional substernal chest pain for 2 weeks. Patient reports the chest pain is relieved by rest  associated with diaphoresis and shortness of breath. No history of previous cardiac events. Physical examination reveals blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg and bilateral decreased lung sounds. EKG shows T-wave inversion in leads II  III  and aVF.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Jones is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  Type II Diabetes Mellitus  and a 35-year history of tobacco use  presenting with recent episodes of chest pain. His chest pain is described as crushing/squeezing in nature  radiating to the left arm and jaw  exacerbated with exertion and relieved by rest. These episodes are also associated with shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and palpitations. The patient reports a previous history of intermittent angina over the past month but believes the episodes to be much more frequent over the past week which are not relieved by Nitroglycerin. He has an inactive lifestyle with occasional alcohol use. His family history is pertinent for coronary artery disease and myocardial infarction in father at age 56. He reports poor adherence to medication and dietary regimen. On examination his blood pressure is 150/90  pulse 95  respiratory rate 19  BMI 30  S1  S2 cardiac sounds with no murmurs.   This clinical context aligns with progressing coronary artery disease  warranting further diagnostic evaluation and management adjustment.

Patient Information: Mr. Brown  65-year-old African-American male   Medical History: Long-standing history of smoking (25 years)  hypertensive  uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus  high cholesterol  obesity  and a strong family history of heart disease; father and paternal uncle both died of heart attacks during their mid 60s. He has been noncompliant with his prescribed regimen for hypertension  diabetes  and cholesterol management.  Presentation: Mr. Brown presented in the ED with worsening chest discomfort  described as intense pressure akin to someone ""sitting on his chest"" for the past 6 hours. The pain begins in the center of his chest and radiates to his left arm. He also reported symptoms of shortness of breath  nausea  heavy sweating without cause  and feeling light-headed. His lips and hands appeared pale. On examination  vital signs were: BP 180/95 mmHg  HR 100 beats/minute  RR 22 breaths/minute  SpO2 90% on room air.  Based on Mr. Brown's symptoms  presenting vitals  and substantial risk factors for coronary artery disease  we strongly suspect an acute coronary syndrome. Need immediate evaluation with EKG and cardiac biomarkers.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical Problem: The patient presents with complaints of recurrent chest pain  increasing in severity over the past three months. The pain is typically located in the center of his chest  often radiating to his left arm. The discomfort is commonly triggered by physical activity or stress and is usually relieved by rest. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath on exertion and occasional episodes of diaphoresis.  Medical History: Relevant medical history includes a diagnosis of hyperlipidemia and hypertension for the last 15 years. The patient used to smoke one pack/day for 30 years but quit 5 years ago. He has a family history of coronary artery disease with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Current Medications: His current daily medications include amlodipine 5mg for blood pressure and atorvastatin 20mg for cholesterol.  Under consideration: The patient's chronic history of hyperlipidemia  hypertension  a positive family history  past tobacco use  and the nature of his symptoms are indicative of coronary artery disease (CAD). The temporal correlation of his symptoms with activity suggests stable angina  an indication of significant CAD. Further diagnostic tests  including an electrocardiogram and stress testing  are recommended.

Problem Representation:  A 67-year-old Hispanic male with a known medical history of hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and a 20-pack-year smoking history  currently on anti-hypertensives and statins presents with increasingly frequent episodes of exertional chest pain over the past two months. The pain is described as a pressure-like feeling that radiates to his left arm. These episodes last around 15 minutes and are precipitated by walking a couple of blocks  or carrying heavy groceries. Recently  he has also noted some episodes at rest. He denies any associated diaphoresis  nausea  or syncope. He has a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD) in his brother who had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. His physical examination is only remarkable for an elevated blood pressure of 148/95 mmHg.

Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant  presenting with worsening chest pain over the past 2 weeks. The pain is characterized as substernal  pressure-like  progressively intensifying in severity  lasts for 30-45 minutes  and radiates to his left arm. It is frequently brought on by exertion  notably when climbing stairs in his home and relieved by rest. The patient has history of hypertension and smoking (quit 10 years back  smoked 1 pack/day for 40 years). Mother had myocardial infarction at age of 60. Patient is currently on Lisinopril and Aspirin. There is no complaint of shortness of breath  but he states increasing fatigue over past several weeks.  On physical examination  he is a slightly overweight (BMI 26) but otherwise well appearing male in no evident respiratory distress. Vital signs are stable with a blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals regular rate and rhythm  normal heart sounds  but no notable murmurs. Lungs are clear to auscultation. His EKG shows some signs of potential past ischemic changes but no apparent acute findings. Laboratory findings pending. This patient likely has exacerbation of coronary artery disease. Further consults  testing  or interventions may be necessary.

Patient Profile: A 57-year-old male  Caucasian  a professional lawyer  and a lifelong smoker with a 30-pack-year history.  Relevant Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension for the past ten years  controlled on hydrochlorothiazide (HCTZ) and lisinopril. He also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed five years ago  managed with metformin and diet control. The patient's father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 50.  Current Presentation: The patient reports a 6-month history of intermittent  exertion-induced chest discomfort  often relieved by rest. He describes it as a heavy feeling  centrally located  and occasionally radiating to his left arm. He reports associated shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional episodes of diaphoresis. He denies any episodes of syncope or pre-syncope. He acknowledges occasional bouts of neurologic changes such as confusion and light-headedness that quickly resolve. He confirms regular alcohol consumption and has increased work stress over the last few months.

A 65-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent substernal chest pain that is exertional in nature and radiates towards the left arm  which started around 2 weeks ago. His chest pain lasts about 5-10 minutes and is relieved by rest. He also mentions experiencing episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional nausea. He has a 35 years history of smoking and confirms compliance with his antihypertensives and oral hypoglycemic agents. He denies any illicit drug use  recent trauma or injury. Information provided indicates angina pectoris  suggesting coronary artery disease.

A 63-year-old Caucasian male  retired professional  presents to the clinic with a 3-week history of intermittent  pressure-like chest discomfort. The discomfort typically occurs after physical exertion  such as walking his dog  and resolves with rest. He also notes dyspnea on exertion that resolves with rest. He describes experiencing fatigue over the past few weeks. He denies palpitations  syncope  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has 10-year medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  which is managed with Metformin  and a 15-year history of hypertension  managed with Lisinopril. He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago  but smoked a pack daily for 25 years. There is family history of coronary artery disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at age 68. He does not comply with a regular exercise routine and his diet is high in sodium and saturated fat. He appears anxious and restless. Vital signs are stable; physical exam is unremarkable except for obesity. BMI is calculated to be 31.2.

Patient Demographics: A 58-year-old African American male.  Medical History: The patient is a known hypertensive and diabetic  managed with medication for the past 8 years. He also has a 30-pack year history of smoking and a family history of early CAD (father had a heart attack at age 55).  Presenting Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing intermittent chest pain for the last two months progressively worsening in nature. The pain is described as squeezing  radiating to the left arm and occasionally associated with shortness of breath and causing him to wake at night. The pain appears to be precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest. He denies symptoms of fever  cough  recent illness  or palpation. Review of systems is otherwise negative.  Thus the problem representation would be: ""A 58-year-old African American man with a history of hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and familial CAD is presenting with a classic angina pectoris of two months duration.""

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-year pack history of smoking presents with complaints of exertional chest pain for the past two weeks. The pain is characterized as pressure-like  radiating to the left arm  and associated with mild shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The chest pain is relieved by rest and nitroglycerin. He is currently on atenolol  20mg QD for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg QD for his hyperlipidemia. His family history is significant for coronary artery disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at age 62. Robbins pathology exam presents no acute abnormalities. His blood pressure is elevated at 160/90 mmHg  pulse 90 bpm  and BMI comes out as 29.3  indicating overweight. These symptoms suggest stable angina due to coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile:  A 65-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History:  The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. He has a past history of moderate  regular alcohol consumption and a 30-pack-year smoking history though he quit smoking 8 years ago. His family history is significant with his father having had a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.  Presenting Problem:  He reports having experienced episodes of chest pain on exertion over the past 2 months. The pain  which he describes as a ""pressure"" in his chest  is not associated with cough or shortness of breath but is relieved by rest. He admits to feeling fatigued more easily over the past weeks. He denies any associated diaphoresis  nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or syncope.   Physical Examination Findings:  Upon examination  his blood pressure measures 145/95 mmHg  heart rate is 80 beats per minute  and body mass index is 30 kg/m2. He is alert  oriented  and appears in moderate distress. Cardiac auscultation reveals regular rhythm and no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   Summary: This 65-year-old male with hypertension  diabetes  and a history of smoking presents with chest pain that is consistent with angina given its relationship to exertion and relief with rest. His symptoms  accompanied by his medical history and physical exam findings  suggest significant likelihood of coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic evaluation and intervention are warranted.

Patient Information: A 65-year-old African American male.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension (for 15 years) and dyslipidemia (hypercholesterolemia for 10 years)  both managed with medicines. He has been smoking 10 cigarettes a day for 30 years and has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father passing away from a myocardial infarction at 58 years of age. He also has a history of sedentary lifestyle and a diet rich in high-fat foods.  Presenting Problem: The patient presents with a six-month history of progressive chest pain often radiating to the left arm  starting initially during exercise but now occurring at rest. The chest pain is often associated with symptoms of dyspnea  diaphoresis  and occasional nausea.   Review of systems is unremarkable except for significant weight gain (10 lbs) in the last year and insomnia. He denies experiencing fever  tinnitus  vertigo  vision changes  cough  wheezing  abdominal pain  or changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Physical Exam: Vital signs reveal BP at 150/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 80 bpm  a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Examination of the cardiovascular system reveals distant heart sounds. There is a suggestion of mild peripheral edema in the lower extremities.  Overall  the presentation is consistent with worsening of coronary artery disease  possibly resulting in unstable angina given the onset of chest pain at rest.

A 62-year-old African American man with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with complaints of recurrent  exertional chest pain that radiates to his left arm. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation. The episodes typically last around 5-10 minutes and are relieved by resting. He reports episodes occurring increasingly frequently over the past three months. Other relevant complaints include occasional shortness of breath on exertion and fatigue. He denies any recent trauma  fever  cough  palpitations  nausea  vomiting  or syncope. His father had a myocardial infraction at the age of 58  and his mother had a stroke at age 70. He has a 25-pack year smoking history and admits to a diet that is high in cholesterol and sodium. Physical examination reveals an overweight man in mild distress. Vital signs are notable for blood pressure 150/95 mm Hg. Cardiac auscultation reveals regular rate and rhythm without murmur; lung sounds are clear. No peripheral edema is evident.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old African-American male  who is retired and used to work in a stressful corporate environment.  Relevant Medical History: He has a known past medical history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago and has a family history of heart disease; his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Presenting Symptoms: He presented to the clinic complaining of a one-month history of gradually progressive chest pain. He describes the pain as a crushing feeling in the center of the chest  often radiating to the left arm. The pain usually occurs when he engages in physical activities like walking a few blocks or climbing stairs  lasting for 5-10 minutes and typically relieved by rest. No associated shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. However  he mentions the chest pain has become more frequent and severe  now occurring even at rest.  This clinical scenario is suggestive of coronary artery disease  presenting with symptoms of chronic stable angina  now possibly progressing to unstable angina given the rest symptoms. Immediate medical attention is required.

Patient Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hyperlipidemia  hypertension  diabetes mellitus type 2  and a 30-pack year smoking history who presents to the clinic with a two week history of progressive onset of chest pain. The pain is described as a central crushing sensation  radiating to his left arm  lasting for 10-15 minutes at a time  triggered by exercise and relieved by rest. He also reports associated symptoms of sweating and shortness of breath during these episodes. He denies any palpitations  dizziness  or syncope. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Simvastatin. His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at age 65. His physical examination is unremarkable with BMI of 30  blood pressure of 140/85 mm Hg  regular pulse rate of 80 and normal respiratory rate. A resting electrocardiogram shows no acute changes. His lipid panel from six months ago showed an elevated LDL-cholesterol of 155 mg/dL despite statin therapy. He has not followed up on his lipid profile since that time.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents with a 2-week history of intermittent chest pain usually after physical activity. The pain is described as a heavy pressure in mid-chest area  radiating to the left arm with associated shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The patient reports the pain usually subsides with rest. He denies associated symptoms of nausea or vomiting. Patient is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago. He is currently on antihypertensive medication and statins. His family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. On physical examination  he has no acute distress  blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg  heart rate is regular at 75 bpm with normal breath sounds. The patient has an appointment next week for an exercise stress test.

Patient Information: Mr. Jose Luis  68-year-old Hispanic male   Presenting Problem: Mr. Luis presents with increasing episodes of chest pain  characterized by a crushing sensation and radiating pain down the left arm  more frequent during exertion and alleviated by rest. The patient also reports experiencing shortness of breath  fatigue  and the occasional feeling of lightheadedness.   Medical History: Known history of hypertension (well-controlled with Lisinopril) and hyperlipidemia (managed with Atorvastatin). He is a former smoker (quit 20 years ago) with a 30-pack-year smoking history. His father reportedly died of a heart attack at age 72.  Medication History: Regularly takes Lisinopril for hypertension  Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and low-dose aspirin as a preventive measure.  Relevant Family History: Father died from a heart attack at age 72. Two younger brothers (age 65 and 63) are alive and well with no known heart disease.  Social History: Retired bank manager living with his wife; quit smoking 20 years ago; drinks alcohol socially  2-3 times per month; does not do regular exercise.   Problem Representation: A 68-year-old Hispanic male with a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia complaining of exertional chest pain  shortness of breath  and occasional fatigue possibly indicative of coronary artery disease  given his risk-factor profile which includes his age  sex  race  and family history.

Patient Information: Mr. Ortiz  a 64-year-old Hispanic male  retired construction worker  active smoker (1 pack/day for the last 35 years)  obese with BMI of 32.  Chief Complaint: He presents with complaints of chest discomfort especially on exertion  shortness of breath  and dizziness for about 3 weeks.  History of Present Illness: Symptoms worsen while climbing stairs or pushing his lawnmower  and began 3 weeks ago. They moderate with rest. Not associated with meals  cough  sputum  fevers  or chills. The shortness of breath has been increasingly worsening leading to difficulty in carrying out his daily activities. He denies symptoms at rest or during the night. No previous episodes. No syncope or presyncope.   Past Medical History: Patient has a 10-year history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. No known allergies. He had appendectomy in his 20s. No history of lung or cardiovascular disease.  Medications: Regularly taking Metformin for diabetes and Lisinopril for hypertension.   Social History: Smoker  alcohol intake occasionally  no drug addiction  lives with wife.   Family History: Father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65. His mother lived up to 78 years and died from natural causes.  Review of Systems: Recent weight gain of about 10 lbs. Denies any changes in vision  hearing  or difficulty swallowing. No nausea  vomiting or changes in bowel habits.   Physical exam: BP: 150/90 mmHg  Pulse: 80bpm regular  Temperature: 98.6°F. Body Mass Index of 32 implying obesity. Alert and oriented. The cardiovascular exam revealed regular rhythm  normal S1 and S2  no murmur  rubs or gallops. Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. Extremities warm with good peripheral pulses.  Conclusion: The typical exertional nature of the chest discomfort raises suspicion for coronary artery disease  particularly given his history of smoking  hypertension  diabetes  and family history. The patient's cholesterol levels  blood glucose level  BMI  liver  and kidney functions need to be reviewed. An exercise stress test or angiogram may be considered for further evaluation for coronary artery disease. Smoking cessation therapy  control of diabetes  hypertension  and weight reduction will be essential in the patient's management.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old Caucasian male   Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. There is a family history of heart disease - father had a heart attack at age 60. The patient is a smoker for the past 40 years and consumes alcohol moderately. He is not regular with his medication and rarely exercises.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient came in with complaints of intermittent chest pain for the last 6 months. Over the last week  the patient has noticed an increase in the duration and intensity of the pain. It is typically located in the central part of the chest and radiates towards the left arm. The chest pain is associated with shortness of breath  pallor  sweating  and nausea. The symptoms are more pronounced during exertions such as climbing stairs and are relieved to some extent by rest. On general physical examination  the patient is anxious  pale  and mildly dyspneic. His pulse is 90 beats per minute and blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg. His body mass index is 28kg/m2.   Given the patient's medical history and presenting symptoms  his profile is suggestive of angina pectoris secondary to coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile:  Mr. Gonzalez is a 67-year-old Hispanic male  former smoker with a medical history significant for type 2 diabetes and hypertension.   Presenting Problem:   Mr. Gonzalez presents to the clinic complaining of persistent  intermittent chest discomfort radiating to his left arm  typically precipitated by exertion and relieved with rest. Associated symptoms include dyspnea on exertion  fatigue  and diaphoresis. He denies symptoms of syncope  palpitations  and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.  Relevant Medical History:  Mr. Gonzalez has a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and a 10-year history of hypertension. He has been a non-smoker for 20 years  but smoked a pack a day for 30 years before quitting. He has a family history of early onset coronary artery disease with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. There is no history of hyperlipidemia or stroke. He has been non-compliant with medications and dietary restrictions.  Upon physical examination  his blood pressure was 155/92 mmHg  heart rate 78 beats/min  BMI 31  and exhibited decreased breath sounds at the lung bases. His glucose levels and lipid profile reveal poor control of his diabetes and high LDL cholesterol levels  respectively.   Impression:  This presentation is suggestive of underlying stable angina due to suspected significant coronary artery disease in the setting of his long-standing history of uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  smoking history  poor medication and dietary compliance  and family history of early-onset coronary artery disease.

Patient Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and high cholesterol presenting with recurrent substernal chest pain generally provoked by exertion and relieved by rest with episodes lasting for 5-10 minutes each time. Over the past week  the episodes have grown increasingly frequent.
