Today  the patient reports that the chest pain was more severe and persisted for 20 minutes  accompanied by shortness of breath and diaphoresis. Of note  he has been a 1-pack per day smoker for the past 40 years. His father died of a myocardial infarction at age 72. He has been successfully managing his hypertension and diabetes through medications  but has had difficulty controlling his high cholesterol despite medication adjustments. Despite regular advice regarding smoking cessation  he has been unable to quit. Physical exam reveals a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  pulse 84 bpm  a BMI of 32  and normal heart sounds with no murmur. Blood work shows elevated LDL and HbA1c levels. His EKG shows ST depressions indicative of possible ischemia. He is admitted to the hospital with a preliminary diagnosis of coronary artery disease with stable angina becoming more unstable.

Patient Information: Mr. Anderson  White male  62-years-old  retired construction worker.  Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension 5 years ago  controlled with medication. History of tobacco use (1 pack/day for the past 40 years)  quit smoking 2 years ago. No history of diabetes mellitus or lipid disorders.  Presenting Complaint: Recurrent episodes of chest pain over the past month especially during moderate exertion or extreme emotional upset. The pain is described as squeezing or tight  located at the center of the chest  radiating to jaw and left arm  associated with breathlessness  lasting approximately 30 minutes  and relieved with rest.  Physical Examination: BP - 138/88 mmHg  consistent with his usual readings  pulse regular  mild increase in weight compared with last year's records. Patient is attentive and in mild discomfort  but not in acute distress. Chest appears symmetrical with no deformities. Normal heart sounds  no murmurs. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Neurological exam is normal.  Lab Tests: Lipid panel test requested  results pending. EKG showed non-specific ST segment and T-wave changes.   Assessment: The patient's symptoms  risk factors (age  male sex  hypertension  previous tobacco use) suggest stable angina due to coronary artery disease. Further investigation with stress testing or coronary angiography may be needed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the extent of the disease.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presents with worsening exertional chest discomfort of six months duration. The patient describes the discomfort as a tight  squeezing sensation located in the substernal area that radiates down the left arm. The pain usually occurs after strenuous activity and is relieved by rest. In the previous week  patient notes that the chest discomfort has started to manifest after climbing the stairs in his home which previously would not provoke symptoms. He denies associated shortness of breath  palpitations  nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. He is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago. He admits to occasional alcohol use and a diet high in saturated fats. His father suffered a heart attack at the age of 62. He is currently on hydrochlorothiazide  metformin  atorvastatin  and aspirin which he takes religiously.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: Known hypertensive and diabetic for the last 10 years  smoker (1 pack/day for 30 years)  family history of early onset coronary artery disease (father had a heart attack at 60)  high cholesterol levels for 5 years  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with recent onset chest pain that is typically exertional  lasting for several minutes  radiates to the left arm  and relieves with rest. He defines this pain as ""pressure"" or ""squeezing"" in his chest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  light-headedness  and excessive sweating during these episodes. He further reports an episode of severe chest pain at rest that woke him up from sleep last night. His symptoms have been increasing in frequency and intensity over the past month.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with central chest pain radiating to his left arm. His chest pain is severe  described as crushing type  associated with sweating and shortness of breath. He has a 20 pack-year smoking history. There is also a relevant family history of early-onset coronary artery disease  his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 52. His meds include metoprolol  lisinopril  metformin  and simvastatin. His blood pressure is consistently ranging between 140-150/90-95 mmHg. His last cholesterol panel showed LDL 160 mg/dl  HDL 35 mg/dl  and triglycerides 200 mg/dl. Current symptoms may suggest a possible acute coronary syndrome.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia  who presents with complaints of intermittent chest pain for the past 2 months. The chest pain is described as a centrally located  squeezing-type pain that radiates to the left arm and is exacerbated by physical exertion. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. The patient also mentioned experiencing episodes of dizziness and fatigue more frequently than usual. He is a former smoker (quit 5 years ago) and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases. Comprehensive examination with EKG  troponin levels  and potential cardiac imaging pending. Probable diagnosis at this time is coronary artery disease.

Problem Representation:  A 56-year-old  African-American male  smoker with a family history of heart disease  presents with recurrent bouts of substernal chest pain that radiate to the left arm. The pain is typically exertional  lasting for about 10 minutes  and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He has a personal history of hypertension and dyslipidemia under treatment with ACE inhibitors and statins respectively  but admits to non-compliance with medications. His symptoms are suggestive of stable angina due to coronary artery disease. Further evaluation with cardiac stress testing and potentially coronary angiography may be required to confirm the diagnosis and to guide management  with an aim to prevent progression to myocardial infarction.

Patient: 62-year-old obese Caucasian male  non-smoker  with history of type II diabetes and hypertension.  Medical Problem: Patient presents to the clinic complaining of on-and-off chest pain usually upon exertion  associated with occasional shortness of breath  and discomfort in the left arm for the last three months. Symptoms have been progressively worsening. Patient has a long-standing history of poorly controlled type II diabetes and hypertension. His family history is significant with father having had a myocardial infarction at age 65. He admits non-compliance with his diabetic and hypertensive drugs due to financial constraints. He has no known allergies. Lifestyle includes minimal physical activity  high sodium diet  obesity with a BMI of 32  but no alcohol or tobacco usage. On examination  he is tachycardic but maintains normal blood pressure. His BMI is indeed elevated  he has an anxious expression but no acute distress. Further testing reveals elevated LDL cholesterol levels and HbA1c. Based on his history  risk factors  and symptoms  coronary artery disease is suspected.

Patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  who now presents with gradually worsening dyspnea on exertion and constricting chest pain radiating to the left arm during the past two weeks. The chest pain typically occurs during stressful times and physical activities  but is relieved with rest. There is a positive family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having his first myocardial infarction at age 59. The patient has a 35-year-pack history of cigarette smoking. Examination reveals the patient to be obese and his blood pressure to be elevated at 155/90 mmHg. Patient's ECG is suggestive of T-wave inversions in leads V1-V4  possibly indicating cardiac ischemia. Cardiac enzymes have been ordered and his risk factor control is suboptimal.

Patient is a 67-year-old African-American male with a medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is currently a smoker with a 30-pack year history. For the past three days  he complains of intermittent chest discomfort  characterized as a tightness  which increases in intensity on exertion and is relieved by rest. He also reports experiencing increased shortness of breath during his usual activities and an episode of diaphoresis during one of these chest discomfort episodes. He has had occasional lightheadedness but denied palpitations  dizziness or fainting spells. His symptoms are causing him significantly decreased exercise tolerance compared to his baseline activity level.

Patient Profile: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Problem: Chest pain  typically radiating to the left arm  with associated shortness of breath  typically exacerbated by activity or emotional stress.   Medical History: Past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack-year smoking history. The patient has a family history of premature coronary artery disease  with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at the age of 50. The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago  managed with diet and metformin.  Relevant Findings: On examination  the patient is found to have an elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg. A mid-systolic murmur is noted on cardiac auscultation and he appears slightly dyspneic. No edema or other signs of congestive heart failure are evident. The EKG shows ST depression and T wave inversion suggestive of myocardial ischemia.   Presumptive Diagnosis: Coronary artery disease with exertional angina. Based on risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  family history  and active smoking habit  there's a high index of suspicion for significant obstructive coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history and a family history of premature coronary artery disease (father had a myocardial infarction at 55 years old). He presents with recent onset substernal chest pain that is described as pressure-like and is exacerbated by exertion. He reports associated shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and nausea. The symptoms typically resolve with rest. He denies syncope  palpitations  and lower extremity edema. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. There are no known drug allergies. Upon cardiovascular examination  a normal S1 and S2 heart sound was noted with no accompanying murmurs  rubs  or gallops. BP is 145/90 mmHg  Pulse rate is 84 bpm  and BMI is 28.8 kg/m2. EKG shows non-specific T wave changes.

Patient Profile: A 63-year-old Caucasian male   Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 5 years  and high cholesterol for the past 10 years. History of smoking for 35 years  approximately a pack per day. No previous instances of cardiovascular diseases  no family history of coronary artery disease.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with a 2-week history of exertional chest pain. He describes the pain as a crushing sensation  radiating to his left arm and associated with shortness of breath  palpitations  and diaphoresis. These episodes usually last 10-15 minutes but have been increasing in frequency and intensity. The patient also reports mild nausea and fatigue during these episodes. He denies any syncope  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Evaluation revealed elevated levels of blood pressure and high cholesterol. An ECG shows signs suggestive of ischemia.

Patient is a 64-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  who presents with complaints of exertional chest pain. The pain is typically under the sternum  pressure-like  worsening with exercise and relieved with rest. Associated symptoms include exertional dyspnea and diaphoresis. He denies nausea  vomiting  or dizziness. Family history is positive for coronary artery disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at age 62. The patient is a former smoker with a 20-pack year history. Physical examination reveals an overweight male in apparent discomfort. Vital signs: BP-140/90 mm Hg  HR-90 bpm  BMI-30. Cardiac auscultation patterns are normal with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops. Pulmonary examination is clear to auscultation bilaterally. EKG shows T-wave inversions in leads V3-V5.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a significant past medical history of unsanctioned smoking (for 40 years) and untreated hypertension presents with 6-month history of intermittent angina  triggered by exertion and relieved by rest. Recently  the patient reports experiencing more frequent angina episodes that are also occurring at rest. He rates the pain as a 7 on a scale of 1 to 10  located in the mid-sternal region with radiation to his left arm. Other accompanying symptoms include episodic shortness of breath and fatigue. He denies symptoms of orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  cough or lower limb swelling. He has no known family history of coronary artery disease. His diet is high in cholesterol and sodium and he does not participate in regular exercise. Lately  he is also feeling distressed due to his persisting symptoms affecting his quality of life.

Problem Representation:  A 68-year-old male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus presents with intermittent chest pain described as ""pressure"" that radiates to his left arm  specifically during physical activity over the past 2 months. The patient also reports shortness of breath  excessive sweating  and feelings of fatigue during these episodes. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history and a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father experiencing a myocardial infarction at age 60. The patient denies nausea  vomiting  or palpitations but expresses concern about a history of early heart disease in his family. His medications include lisinopril  metformin  and simvastatin. Physical examination reveals an overweight male in moderate distress with a blood pressure of 160/92 mmHg  pulse 88 beats per minute  and BMI recorded to be 30 kg/m2. He has no abnormalities detected on cardiac or respiratory examination. Given his significant risk factors for heart disease and characteristic symptoms  there is a high suspicion for coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 65-year-old Hispanic male with a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia now presenting with recurrent episodes of chest pain and pressure  particularly upon exertion. His pain is described as a squeezing sensation in the center of his chest that radiates to his left arm. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  diaphoresis  fatigue  and intermittent episodes of dizziness. He has a 20-year history of smoking but quit 7 years ago. He reports poor adherence to prescribed antihypertensive  antidiabetic  and lipid-lowering medication. His family history is significant with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction in his late 50s. Physical examination is notable for elevated blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  increased heart rate of 90 beats per minute  obesity with BMI of 30 kg/m²  and absence of leg and ankle edema. Electrocardiogram performed at rest suggests possible left ventricular hypertrophy but is otherwise nonspecific. Patient's chest pain and associated symptoms  along with presence of multiple cardiac risk factors  suggest possible coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for heavy smoking (30 packs annum for 40 years)  hypertension  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  presenting with anginal chest pain of three weeks duration. The pain is described as a crushing sensation  rated 8/10 in severity  usually occurring with activities and relieved with rest. Additional symptoms include shortness of breath on exertion  associated fatigue and occasional dizzy spells. The patient reports poor compliance with prescribed antihypertensives and oral hypoglycemics. He has no known drug allergies. Family history is significant for a father who died at age 65 of a heart attack. Physical examination shows a blood pressure of 160/98 mmHg  heart rate 85 bpm with a BMI of 32.2. He can be classified as a high-risk patient because of significant risk factors  including advanced age  smoking  poor control of hypertension and diabetes  and positive family history of premature heart disease.

Patient Profile: A 62-year-old African American male with a past medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes.  Chief Complaint: Chest pain with exertion  but relieved by rest  over the past six weeks.  History: The patient has a 10-year history of hypertension  controlled with losartan  as well as hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 5 years ago  controlled with metformin. He has quit smoking 2 years ago but has a 30 pack-year smoking history until then. There is a family history of myocardial infarction in his older brother.  Current Presentation: The patient has been experiencing moderate  retrosternal chest pain which radiates down his left arm. The pain is associated with exertion and is typically relieved with approximately 10 minutes of rest. He has noted increasing frequency of pain episodes over the last 6 weeks. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath and episodes of diaphoresis with the pain. No associated nausea  vomiting or syncope.   Physical Exam: Blood pressure is elevated at 158/94 mmHg. Heart rate 76 bpm  respirations 18 per minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Upon cardiac auscultation  heart sounds were normal  without murmurs  rubs  or gallops.   This clinical scenario is suggestive of stable angina due to coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting with recurrent episodes of chest pain for the last 6 weeks. The pain is described as a heavy pressure-like sensation  located centrally in the chest  occasionally radiating to the left arm. The pain is usually associated with moderate to high physical exertion and resolves within 5 minutes of rest. He also reports associated symptoms of dyspnea and diaphoresis. Noted a decline in his exercise tolerance due to these symptoms. No history of nausea  vomiting  or syncope. Active smoker with a 20 pack-year history. Patient has not had any previous cardiac workup. Family history is significant for a father who had a myocardial infarction at age 62.

Patient Profile: Mr. Carlos Mendoza  a 67-year-old Hispanic male  retired civil engineer.  Past Medical History: Has been under treatment for Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years. He has a 20-year smoking history (10 packs per year).  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents with recurrent angina pectoris  characterized by chest pain that radiates to the left shoulder and arm. The chest pain usually gets worse with physical activity and improves with rest. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath and fatigue that have increased in frequency over the past month.  Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure reading shows 135/90mm Hg. Auscultation reveals normal heart sounds with no murmurs. His BMI is 28 indicating he is overweight.  This presentation is suggestive of advanced coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic testing  including cardiac stress testing or coronary angiography  might be warranted to confirm the disease and assess the extent of the artery blockage.

Patient Profile: A 68-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus. He was diagnosed with coronary artery disease 5 years ago and had undergone percutaneous coronary intervention and stenting of his left anterior descending artery at that time. Patient has a 20 pack-years history of smoking but successfully quit 5 years ago. His medication regimen includes daily aspirin  atorvastatin  lisinopril  and metformin.   Presenting Complaint: He presents to his general physician with a one-week history of exertional chest pain. He describes the pain as pressure-like in nature  located in the center of his chest and radiating to his left arm. He reports the pain gets better when he rests. The patient also reports episodes of shortness of breath and excessive fatigue  especially upon exertion. He denies symptoms of fever  cough  dizziness  syncope  palpitations  or lower extremity swelling.   Clinical Examination: Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 135/85 mmHg and a heart rate of 85 bpm. His body mass index is 29. Other physical examinations  including lung fields and lower extremities  are unremarkable.

Patient Representation:   A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type-2 diabetes mellitus presents complaining of a 2-week history of intermittent chest pain radiating to the left arm. The pain is described as a tightness  usually occurring during physical activities and is relieved with rest. Patient also reports experiencing associated symptoms of shortness of breath  palpitations  and feeling dizzy occasionally. He is a former smoker and has a family history of cardiovascular disease - father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70. Patient is currently on medications including amlodipine for hypertension  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and metformin for diabetes control. Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg and BMI of 29. Cardiac examination shows regular rhythm with no murmurs. Given the history and exam findings  the symptoms are suggestive of stable angina secondary to coronary artery disease.

Patient Information: A 72-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: Chest pain and shortness of breath  progressively worsening over the past few weeks.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports persistent  dull chest pain radiating to the left arm and shoulder. Difficulty breathing  especially during physical activity. He has occasional episodes of dizziness and fatigue related to moderate exertion or walking short distances.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled with oral medications for the last ten years. He has a thirty-year history of smoking  though quit five years ago. Formerly had high cholesterol treated with statin therapy. No prior cardiac disease diagnosis  though father had myocardial infarction at age 68.   Social History: Retired factory worker  lives with his wife  neither of them smokes or consumes alcohol.   Physical Examination: Vital stable  BMI: 29  blood pressure: 150/90 mmHg  heart rate: 88 bpm  respiration rate: 16 breaths per minute. Chest exam reveals diminished breath sounds. Cardiac exam shows irregular heart rhythm  no jugular venous distension or peripheral edema.  Relevant labs/imaging: EKG indicates subtle ischemic changes. Elevated troponin levels. Chest X-ray showed no signs of congestive heart failure. CT angiogram needed for definitive diagnosis.  Problem Representation: This is an elderly male with a considerable cardiovascular risk profile - including hypertension  type 2 diabetes  high cholesterol  past smoker  and family history of coronary artery disease - now presents with symptoms suggestive of chronic stable angina  likely secondary to underlying coronary artery disease. He needs urgent risk stratification  further diagnostic imaging  and treatment optimization for his risk factors.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Johnson is a 62-year-old African-American male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes with poor glycemic control  who presents to the outpatient clinic reporting chest pain for the past three weeks. He describes the pain as being a feeling of ""pressure” in the center of his chest  often coming on with exertion when he walks up an incline or stairs  lasting for 10-15 minutes  and relieved with rest. He also reports associated diaphoresis and a sensation of shortness of breath  but denies having any nausea  vomiting  or syncope. His symptoms are progressively increasing in their frequency and intensity. He is a former smoker  having used 1 pack/day for 25 years  but quit smoking 5 years ago. His medication regimen includes metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin. He is non-compliant with his diabetic and hypertension medications  particularly metformin due to his concerns regarding side effects. He has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having a history of a myocardial infarction at 55 years of age. His review of systems is negative except for occasional lower limb claudication  noticing difficulty in walking longer distances. His physical exam reveals a well-nourished male in no acute distress  BP of 155/95 mm Hg  HR: 86 bpm  RR: 20/min  BMI: 31 kg/m2. Auscultation of the heart shows no murmurs  gallops or rubs  and lungs are clear to auscultation. Vascular examination reveals decreased pulses in the lower extremities.

Patient Profile: Mr. X is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired banker.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. He has been diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD) previously and undergone PCI with stent placement 5 years ago. He is compliant with his medication regimen that includes Metformin  Atorvastatin and Clopidogrel. Mr. X also has a 30-pack-year smoking history  though he quit smoking 10 years ago.  Presenting Complaint: He presents with worsening exertional chest pain over the last week  usually relieved by rest. He also reports episodes of diaphoresis associated with the chest pain. The episodes seem to be more frequent and longer in duration in recent days.  Examination: Upon examination  he is afebrile with a BP of 140/90 mm Hg  a pulse rate of 90 bpm  and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. He appears anxious. Cardiac examination reveals no gallops  murmurs  or rubs. Lung fields are clear.  Assessment: Given the background of known CAD  the symptoms Mr. X is experiencing suggest a worsening of his CAD and potentially unstable angina. These symptoms signify an urgent need for cardiac evaluation and potential intervention. Immediate lifestyle modifications  change in medication regimen  or further revascularization strategies may be required depending on the progression of the disease.

Patient is a 66-year-old African-American male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He presents with progressive worsening of exertional chest pain over the last couple of weeks. The patient describes the pain as a squeezing discomfort located in the mid chest  which typically develops after walking about half a block and is associated with shortness of breath. The symptoms usually resolve with rest. The patient denies any associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis. He also denies any prior family history of heart disease. No known drug allergies. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking  but quit 15 years ago. On examination  blood pressure is 146/90 mmHg  heart rate is regular at 82 bpm  BMI 28. Rest of the physical examination is unremarkable. Initial lab work including CBC  CMP  thyroid function test are within normal limits. Lipid panel reveals elevated LDL cholesterol. Electrocardiogram shows T wave inversion in leads V1-V3. Further workup with stress testing and cardiac catheterization confirms significant coronary artery disease with 70% obstruction in the left anterior descending coronary artery.

Patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He presents with a chief complaint of intermittent chest pain that worsens with exertion and improves with rest. The pain has been associated with feelings of pressure in the chest  shortness of breath  and occasional lightheadedness. He has a 30-year smoking history of one pack/day and reports he has been less physically active in recent months. Family history is positive for coronary artery disease  his father died of a heart attack at the age of 60. Upon physical examination  the patient is overweight with a BMI of 30. Lab results reveal poorly controlled diabetes with HbA1C of 9% and elevated cholesterol levels. EKG shows evidence of previous silent myocardial infarction. These findings are indicative of coronary artery disease.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old African American male  retired truck driver and a resident of New York.  Presenting Problem: Mr. Johnson complains of recurrent  progressive episodes of chest pain  particularly during physical exertion that relieves after rest. The chest pain is described as a heaviness and tightness radiating to his left arm.  Medical History: Patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both controlled with medication. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years and has a familial history of heart disease. His Body Mass Index (BMI) records as 29 (overweight).  Relevant Symptoms: Patient's chest pain is associated with shortness of breath. He denies any nausea  vomiting  fever  cough  or any other gastrointestinal or respiratory symptoms. His blood pressure remains on the higher side.  This above presentation is suggestive of physical exertion-related  classic angina caused by coronary artery disease (CAD). The risk factors contributing to his condition include the long history of tobacco use  hypertension  diabetes  obesity  and genetic predisposition. Other investigations are warranted to confirm the diagnosis and manage the condition.

Patient Profile: Mr. Davis  a 63-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  Type 2 Diabetes  and obesity.  Medical History: Mr. Davis was diagnosed with hypertension and obesity six years ago and has been managing these through medication and lifestyle changes. However  he was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and Type 2 Diabetes two years back  which have been moderately controlled with statins and metformin. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit five years ago. No previous hospitalization or surgeries.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Davis reports that he has experienced intermittent chest pain over the last two weeks  brought on by exertion and relieved by rest. The chest pain is described as a pressure-like feeling located in the center of the chest with no radiation to other parts of the body. Episodes last about 10 minutes. Recent onset of dyspnea on exertion and fatigue noted. No other symptoms like dizziness  fainting  palpitations  cough  or peripheral edema. There is no known family history of coronary artery disease.  Clinically  Mr. Davis is overweight with a BMI of 32 kg/m2. On examination  his blood pressure was 145/95 mmHg  pulse rate was 88 bpm  and respiratory rate was 17 breaths per minute. His oral glucose tolerance test and lipid profile showed abnormal values.  Impression: This appears to be a case of stable angina in a patient suffering from multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease  including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type 2 diabetes  obesity  and a significant past smoking history. His BMI  abnormal glucose tolerance test  lipid profile  and the nature of chest pain strongly suggest coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic evaluation  like ECG and cardiac stress tests  are suggested in order to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Johnson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking (30 pack-years  quit five years ago)  and a sedentary lifestyle  presents to the clinic with chief complaints of chest discomfort and exertional shortness of breath over the past 3 weeks. He reports that the chest discomfort is a pressure-like sensation located centrally in the chest that typically occurs with physical exertion and lasts for several minutes. It is relieved by rest or with nitroglycerin administration. The shortness of breath accompanies the chest discomfort but has also been observed when climbing stairs or walking against the wind. No related diaphoresis  nausea  or syncope noted. Mr. Johnson also confesses that he's been trying to ignore these symptoms  attributing them to aging. Yet  his wife insisted that he see a doctor due to a family history of heart disease. Of note  Mr. Johnson’s father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His older brother was also diagnosed with coronary artery disease at the age of 55 and underwent angioplasty. He has no known drug allergies. He takes a daily aspirin and atorvastatin per his previous primary care provider and uses an occasional nitroglycerin for his chest discomfort.

Patient Profile: A 64-year-old Caucasian male.  Relevant Medical History: The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a smoker with over 40 years of tobacco use. He had a myocardial infarction seven years ago leading to the placement of a coronary stent. He has not been consistent with cardiac medication regimen as prescribed.   Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the clinic with chronic exertional chest pain that has been persistently deteriorating over the last 2 months. Pain is described as dull  pressure-like  primarily located in the substernal area  radiating to the left arm  and accompanied by shortness of breath  diaphoresis  and occasional lightheadedness. The symptoms are induced by moderate physical exertion and are relieved upon rest or with nitroglycerin use. He also reports reduced exercise tolerance  occasional restlessness  and easy fatigability. His appetite and sleep are normal. He has had no fevers  cough  or weight loss. He denies any recent stress or changes in his lifestyle. No symptoms suggest gastrointestinal  musculoskeletal  or neuropsychiatric disorders.

Patient Profile: A 63-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  who smokes half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He has been on regular medication for the last 10 years. His father died of a heart attack at age 70.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient reports intermittent chest pain  particularly when performing physical activities  that he describes as pressure-like. Accompanying the chest pain  he occasionally experiences shortness of breath  nausea  and sweating. These symptoms have been ongoing for the past six weeks.  Given his presenting symptoms  significant medical history  and risk factors such as smoking and family history of heart disease  this patient is suspect for coronary artery disease. Immediate evaluation is required to assess the severity  including assessing any potential myocardial damage  and to take necessary precautions to prevent any catastrophic events like an acute myocardial infarction (heart attack).

Patient Presentation: Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old African-American male  lifelong smoker with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a significant family history of heart disease.  Medical History: Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago and has been on Lisinopril. His hyperlipidemia was diagnosed 10 years ago and has been managed with Atorvastatin. He has a 30-pack year smoking history but still continues to smoke. His father died at the age of 62 from a myocardial infarction. In addition  he is overweight with a BMI of 29.  Current Presentation: Mr. Johnson presents with a consistent  dull central chest pain  radiating to the left arm. The pain is enhanced on exertion and relieved by rest. He additionally reports shortness of breath  particularly during activities and mild episodes of dizziness. There have been two episodes of nocturnal chest pain disturbing his sleep within the past week. His blood pressure at presentation is 155/93 mmHg.

Patient Profile: Mr. Rodriguez  a 67-year-old Hispanic male.  Presenting Problem: Takes frequent breaks during routine activities for past 2 months due to shortness of breath and chest discomfort often radiating to the left arm.  Medical History: Diagnosed hypertension managed with Lisinopril for 10 years  and type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin for 5 years. History of smoking  quit 10 years ago.  Family History: Father died from myocardial infarction (MI) in his late 50s.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure 155/90 mmHg; Resting heart rate 85 bpm; BMI 28 kg/m2; Slight wheezing identified on chest auscultation.  Laboratory Findings: Abnormal lipid profile with elevated total cholesterol (244 mg/dl) and low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol (156 mg/dl). Fasting blood glucose of 140 mg/dl.   Based on the above information  the patient likely has coronary artery disease (CAD)  presenting as unstable angina. The persistent chest discomfort  shortness of breath  abnormal lipid profile  hypertension  history of diabetes and smoking are all key factors contributing to this assessment. The patient's profile and symptoms warrant immediate diagnostic investigations including an ECG and cardiac enzyme testing. These findings also necessitate a review of the patient's current medication regimen  potential inclusion of anti-anginal medication  and implementation of diet and lifestyle modifications.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes presents with a complaint of progressive chest discomfort over the past 2 months. The discomfort is described as primarily central  pressure-like in nature  and often radiates to the left arm. The pain is usually induced by exertion  such as when climbing stairs  and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin use. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath and undue fatigue. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history and admits to a sedentary lifestyle. His father had a myocardial infarction at age 58. Physical examination is essentially normal at rest  with no signs of heart failure. The electrocardiogram shows T-wave inversions in leads II  III  and AVF. This presentation suggests stable angina due to coronary artery disease.

Patient Problem Representation:  Mr. K  a 62-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes  presents with chief complaints of intermittent  substernal chest pain that radiates to the left arm and is associated with shortness of breath and diaphoresis. The pain  which has been occurring over the past 1 week  is typically triggered by exercise and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin use. He admits to a 30-pack year of smoking history and an unhealthy diet rich in fats and red meats. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. His vital signs are within normal ranges  and physical examination is largely unremarkable save for a body mass index of 33 indicating obesity. Electrocardiogram demonstrates T wave inversions in the anterior leads  a possible sign of myocardial ischemia. Given the nature and pattern of his chest pain  the patient's preliminary diagnosis is exertional angina suggestive of underlying coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile:  A 63-year-old Caucasian male.  Medical History:  Long-standing history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes and hypertension. Current smoker with a 40 pack-year history. Previously diagnosed high cholesterol for which he has been irregular on statin therapy. Previous myocardial infarction about 5 years ago  treated with a drug-eluting stent to the left anterior descending (LAD) artery.  Presenting Complaints:  He reports a 2 week history of recurring chest discomfort. The discomfort is characterized as squeezing and pressure-like sensation predominantly in the mid-sternal region  radiating to his left arm. Symptoms usually get aggravated by exertion (particularly uphill walking) and are partially relieved by rest. He also complains of associated shortness of breath.  Physical Examination & Labs:  He is overweight with a BMI of 29. Blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg. Multiple scattered crackles observed on lung auscultation. The cardiac examination demonstrates a regular rhythm with no murmurs. Lower extremities showing +1 edema bilaterally. EKG shows T wave inversions in anterior leads. His lipid profile shows elevated LDL and triglyceride levels and HbA1c is 8.9%. His troponin levels are within normal limits but show dynamic changes on serial monitoring.

Problem Representation:  Mr. James Edwards is a 65-year-old Caucasian man with a known past medical history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  both well controlled with medications. He is a former smoker with a 20 pack-year history  stopped smoking about 10 years ago. He has a family history of coronary artery disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction in his late sixties.  For the past two weeks  Mr. Edwards has experienced exertional chest pain accompanied by profuse sweating that resolves with rest. In the past three days  however  the frequency of these episodes has significantly increased along with an increase in severity  prompting a visit to his primary care physician. On further enquiry  he reported occasional episodes of shortness of breath and mild palpitations  but no dizziness or syncope. He further denies symptoms of lower extremity edema or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea suggestive of heart failure. He has no other complaints and his general physical examination was within normal limits except for some tenderness on his precordium.  His EKG showed ST depressions and his echocardiogram revealed some areas of hypokinesia suggestive of ischemic heart disease. The patient's exertional angina  combined with his risk factors and significant family history  suggests that he likely has coronary artery disease. Further diagnostic modalities such as cardiac catheterization are recommended to confirm the diagnosis and assess the degree of coronary artery stenosis.

Patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  presenting with recent onset of chest pain. He reports intermittent substernal chest discomfort over the past 6 weeks  often brought on by exertion and relieved with rest. Also describes diaphoresis and shortness of breath associated with the chest pain episodes. He's a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit five years ago. His current medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. The patient is retired and lives with his wife; both are concerned about the recent symptom changes. The examination was unremarkable except for elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Given the history and presentation  the symptomatology is highly suggestive of unstable angina secondary to probable coronary artery disease.

Patient Description: Mr. Johnson is a 65-year-old African American male.  Relevant Medical History: He has had a history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia with inconsistent medication adherence. He has a family history of heart disease with his father passing away from a heart attack at an early age.  Presenting Problem: He presents with worsening chest discomfort described as a pressure sensation radiating to his left arm and jaw  that started while he was doing yard work. This discomfort is associated with shortness of breath  nausea  and excessive sweating.  Relevant Symptoms: His blood pressure is elevated at 160/100 and he has an irregularly irregular pulse. Physical examination revealed diaphoresis and a raised JVP. His BMI is within obesity range. Rest of the physical exam is unremarkable.  Presumptive Diagnosis: The patient's symptoms and risk factors suggest coronary artery disease  specifically presenting as unstable angina. Consideration should be given to assessing for possible myocardial infarction. An immediate cardiac evaluation  including EKG and cardiac enzyme blood work  would be warranted.

Patient Profile: A 60-year-old African-American male  Medical History: A known hypertensive and type II diabetic for 10 years; former smoker who quit 5 years ago but has a 30-pack year smoking history; family history of coronary artery disease with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at age 65. His physical activity is low  mostly sedentary activities such as watching TV. His older brother was diagnosed with coronary artery disease at 59.   Based on his demographic characterization  presenting issue  past medical history and family history  Mr. J is suspected of suffering from chronic coronary artery disease. Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure often measured around 150/90 mmHg and the last HbA1c was 8.5 percent. He also has mild chronic renal insufficiency  his last estimated glomerular filtration rate being 58 mL/minute/1.73 m2.  Medications:  The patient is on atenolol 50 mg daily for hypertension  metformin 1000 mg twice daily for diabetes and simvastatin 20 mg daily for hyperlipidemia.  Relevant Investigations and Results:  His electrocardiogram (EKG) shows minor non-specific ST-T wave changes and his echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy and mild diastolic dysfunction. His last lipids showed total cholesterol of 230 mg/dL  LDL of 140 mg/dL  HDL of 35 mg/dL and triglycerides of 160 mg/dL.   Conclusion:  The patient’s symptoms coupled with his risk factors - age  gender  race  former smoker  limited physical activity  poor diet  family history  hypertension  diabetes  high cholesterol  and chronic kidney disease  point towards a diagnosis of coronary artery disease (CAD). Further diagnostic tests like stress test  coronary angiogram  and possibly myocardial perfusion imaging may be required for evaluation and confirmation of CAD. The patient should be advised to make lifestyle modifications and his present medications might need to be adjusted  particularly to better control his blood pressure and diabetes.

Patient Profile:  Problem Representation: Mr. John Doe is a 63-year-old retired African-American living in downtown Chicago. He has been complaining about experiencing chest pain and discomfort when engaging in physical activity  which subsides with rest. Notably  the chest pain also tends to get worse during stressful situations. Moreover  he has been experiencing shortness of breath and unusually high levels of fatigue lately.   Demographic Data: He is married with three kids  all of whom live separately  but within the city. They visit him periodically. He lives in a small apartment with his wife. He is a retired school teacher and his wife is a nurse. He maintains a sedentary lifestyle and doesn't partake in regular physical activity. His diet largely consists of processed foods and he has a history of 25 years of light cigarette smoking.  Past Medical History: His past history includes:  1. Dyslipidemia: Diagnosed 5 years ago  on lipid-lowering medication (Statin).   Family History: His mother died at the age of 75 due to congestive heart failure. His father  on the other hand  had a history of stroke but lived till the age of 83. His younger brother  at age 55  was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   Laboratory Investigations: Recent blood tests suggest slightly increased cholesterol levels and Fasting Blood Sugar of 150 mg/dl. His BP readings over the last few readings have averaged 140/85. His BMI is 28  suggesting he is overweight.  Based on his symptoms  demographics  and history  there is a high suspicion of Ischemic Heart Disease  likely due to coronary artery disease. Appropriate medical intervention  including lifestyle modification  medication adjustment  and further diagnostic tests such as coronary angiography  may be required.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization: Mr. B is a 60-year-old male identification number 31267  of Caucasian ethnicity  residing at 118 Parkside avenue in a suburban community. He is a retired banker  has been married for 30 years. He is a current smoker with a 25 pack-year history  drinks alcohol occasionally  and does not partake in physical workouts or regular exercise.  Relevant Past Medical History: Mr. B has a history of hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago and is on regular medication. He was found to be diabetic (Type II) eight years ago; his diabetes has been poorly controlled with diet and medication interventions. His Body Mass Index (BMI) of 30 categorizes him within the obese range. His father passed away due to a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and his older brother underwent angioplasty at the age of 65.   Presenting Problem: He has been recently experiencing chest discomfort and breathlessness on exertion for the past month. The chest discomfort feels like ""pressure""  is located in the substernal region  and it radiates to his left arm. The episodes last for 10-15 minutes and are relieved by rest.   Preliminary Diagnosis: According to the symptoms  family history of heart disease  diabetes  long-term smoking habits  obesity  the nature of the pain  and the circumstances under which it occurs  the patient is likely experiencing chronic stable angina due to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).   Plan: The patient should be referred to a cardiologist for further assessment and testing  including electrocardiogram (ECG)  echocardiogram  and possible stress tests or cardiac catheterization to confirm the diagnosis. Smoking cessation  diet control for diabetes  exercise  and cholesterol profile examination need to be the mainstay intervention.

This represents a classic case of a patient with multiple risk factors for heart disease  including age  male sex  smoking  high fat diet  hypertension  diabetes  family history of heart disease  and presenting complaint of increasing chest pain on exertion. Such a case would likely warrant further diagnostic investigation  such as an electrocardiogram or stress test  to confirm the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

This case requires a thorough cardiovascular examination and diagnostic tests  along with necessary intervention.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: - Age: 62 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired corporate executive - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital Status: Married with three children - Lifestyle: Sedentary  smoker  and frequent alcohol consumption - Weight: Overweight (BMI 28.3) - Family History: Father died of heart attack at age 65  Past Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed 5 years ago. Taking antihypertensive medication irregularly. - Hyperlipidemia: High LDL cholesterol discovered during annual physical examination  4 years ago. Advised dietary modifications but did not adhere. - Type II Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 2 years ago. On oral hypoglycemic and lifestyle modification. - Gout: Occasional flare-ups in the past 7 years.   Current Complaint: - Chest pain: Described as tightness in the center of the chest  radiating to the left arm. Associated with shortness of breath and excessive sweating. Pain often follows physical exertion or emotional stress and is relieved by rest.  Summary: This is a case of a 62-year-old male retired corporate executive with a sedentary lifestyle  smoker  overweight  and with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  type II diabetes mellitus  and gout now presenting with exertional chest pain  shortness of breath  and excessive sweating. These symptoms suggest the possibility of underlying coronary artery disease.  Relevant Background: The patient's distinct risk factors include age  gender  family history  smoking  obesity  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes mellitus. Active symptoms fit the description of a stable angina pectoris  which is typical in patients with coronary artery disease. Problem Statement:  Mr. John Smith  a 60-year-old African-American male  presents with symptoms consistent with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Demographic Characterization:  The patient is a retired teacher who has been living in Boston for more years. He is married with three grown children. He leads a moderately active lifestyle and  according to him  follows a balanced diet. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily in his younger years but quit about 15 years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately but regularly.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a past medical history significant for systemic hypertension (controlled with amlodipine 10mg daily)  type 2 diabetes mellitus (controlled with metformin 500mg twice daily)  and hypercholesterolemia (controlled with atorvastatin 20mg daily). He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father succumbed to an acute myocardial infarction at the age of 65.   Present Complaints:  For the past few months  Mr. Smith has been experiencing intermittent chest pain  typically occurring during physical exertion and relieved with rest. He also reports episodes of shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional palpitations. He has recently noticed a decrease in exercise tolerance and has had to stop his daily morning walks due to these symptoms.   Physical Examination:  Heart examination revealed occasional extra heart sounds along with muffled heart sounds. The rest of the physical examination findings were within normal limits.  These symptoms and findings suggest a probable diagnosis of coronary artery disease in Mr. Smith which should be confirmed with further diagnostic testing including Electrocardiogram  stress test  and cardiac catheterization if necessary. The ongoing management of his chronic conditions will also need to be reviewed. His lifestyle including his diet  exercise habits  alcohol intake  and stress levels need to be reassessed to offer comprehensive care.

Problem Representation: Patient Profile: A 58-year-old  Caucasian male  an ex-smoker  with a job involving moderate physical activity.  Presenting Complaint: The patient complained of chest discomfort  especially during physical exertion  which seems relieved with rest.  Background Information and Demographics: The patient is 5'10'' tall  currently weighs 240 pounds  and has a sedentary lifestyle. He is a retired mechanical engineer  married with two children. He stopped smoking ten years ago after a 20-year pack-a-day smoking habit. The patient also reported moderate alcohol consumption of 3-4 beers twice per week. There is a prevalent family history of cardiovascular disease – his father underwent a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) at 55 years old and subsequently died from a myocardial infarction at 65. His older brother also had a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement 5 years ago at 60 years old.  Past Medical History: The patient had been treated for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His medications include lisinopril 10 mg daily and atorvastatin 40 mg daily. He was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus 8 years ago and is currently on metformin 1 g twice daily. The patient also has moderate osteoarthritis of the knees. His last annual check-up was nine months ago  and medical records suggest suboptimal control of his diabetes and hypercholesterolemia.  Relevant Laboratory Findings: A complete lipid panel revealed hyperlipidemia - Elevated LDL cholesterol and reduced HDL cholesterol levels. Elevated glucose levels suggest suboptimal diabetes control. Echocardiogram indicates decreased myocardial wall motion in the apex and distal anterior wall during stress test  suggestive of compromised blood supply.  Representative Problem Summary: We are dealing with a case of a 58-year-old  overweight Caucasian male  formerly a heavy smoker  with history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  uncontrolled diabetes  osteoarthritis  and strong genetics of coronary artery disease  presenting with exertional chest discomfort. Given his presenting symptoms  personal history  family history  echo findings  and his risk factor profile  this patient is highly suspected for progressing coronary artery disease.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization: Patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired banker  married with two adult children. He is a former smoker  having stopped smoking about 20 years ago but has a past history of heavy smoking (2 packs/day for 30 years) until that time. He consumes alcohol occasionally and leads a sedentary lifestyle with infrequent physical activity. His dietary pattern is normal per age. BMI is 28.2 kg/m2  showing overweight status. His father and elder brother both have history of coronary artery disease.  Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for about 10 years and diabetes mellitus type 2 for about 5 years. Both the conditions are moderately controlled using antihypertensives (Lisinopril) and antidiabetic medications (Metformin). He had a stroke 3 years ago with full recovery. High cholesterol levels were diagnosed about 8 years ago and he has been on statins (Atorvastatin). He has occasional symptoms of dyspnea and fatigue. Patient has also been suffering from intermittent chest pain for the last 6 months which is more on physical exertion and relieved by rest. The patient denies any history of drug allergies and surgical interventions.   Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  patient appears afebrile but anxious. Blood pressure readings are in the prehypertensive range (130/85 mmHg); pulse rate is a little high (88 beats per minute) and regular. He has bilateral pitting pedal edema.  Laboratory Results: Recent laboratory investigations show moderately elevated HbA1c (7.2%) and slightly raised LDL cholesterol (110 mg/dl).  Problem Identification: Given the patient’s clinical presentation  history of several risk factors such as age  male sex  family history of CAD  hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  stroke  obesity and a sedentary lifestyle  the primary problem could be suspected as coronary artery disease. His intermittent chest pain during physical exertion and releif by rest seem typical of angina pectoris  a sign of CAD. This needs further diagnostic confirmation  though and an effective management plan. Patient is also at risk of further cardiovascular events due to his uncontrolled diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.

His family history is significant with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62. His management is going to require a multidisciplinary approach including lifestyle modification  medications  and potentially invasive interventions.

Problem Representation:  Patient Profile:   Mr. X  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  with a BMI of 32  presents with typical coronary artery disease (CAD) symptoms. He is a heavy smoker with a history of smoking for about 30 years and a family history of coronary artery disease.  Presenting Symptoms:   He reports chronic angina-type chest discomfort  characterized as pressure-like  usually following physical activity or emotional stress  and is relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath after minor physical exertion. He has denied any syncing episodes  unusual fatigue  or excessive sweating. The pain doesn’t radiate and there’s no association with other symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or palpitation.  Past Medical History:   Mr. X has a documented history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His hypertension has been poorly controlled over the years  with promises to maintain a healthy diet and regular walks  but with little commitment towards these lifestyle changes. Diabetic condition was detected in his early 50s  the control of which has been moderate with oral hypoglycemic agents. His cholesterol levels have been consistently high  with an LDL above 200 mg/dL and an HDL below 40 mg/dL.  Social History:   He lives with his wife  is a retired truck driver  and has poor dietary habits with a preference towards high fat  cholesterol-loaded food. He has a 30-pack-year history of smoking cigarettes and has declined any alcohol or illicit drug use.  Family History:   He has a family history of heart diseases. His father had a heart attack at age 60  and his paternal uncle underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at age 62.  Conclusion:  This 65-year-old male with a significant history of cardiovascular risk factors: hypertension  diabetes  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and positive family history  presents with symptoms consistent with coronary artery disease. Given his age  gender  racial background  and lifestyle choices  this presentation is indicative of a typical patient with likely coronary artery disease  warranting further investigation and management.

Problem Representation: A 62-year-old Caucasian male  a former smoker  currently employed as a construction worker is exhibiting symptoms consistent with coronary artery disease. He reports frequent and gradually worsening chest pain  especially during physical exertion which gets relieved by resting  and shortness of breath. The patient also reports occasional dizziness and fatigue. He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  that have been managed with antihypertensive and antilipid therapy respectively for 7 years.   His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his older brother recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease at the age of 68. He is obese (BMI: 30) and consumes alcohol socially  however  he quit his 20-pack-year smoking habit 5 years ago. He has no history of diabetes. His current medications include Amlodipine for hypertension and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. His current diet is high in red meats and fried foods and he admits to limited physical exercise due to his work schedule.    This patient's concerning symptoms  combined with the risk factors such as family history of coronary artery disease  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity and previously being a smoker  makes him a typical presentation of a coronary artery disease patient.

Presenting Complaint:   - Has been experiencing increasing episodes of chest pain  happening more frequently during physical exertion  - Has also experienced some shortness of breath and fatigue during these episodes - Episodes last approximately 10 minutes  relieved by rest - Has noticed pain radiating to left arm during severe attacks  Assessment:  - The patient fits the typical demographic for coronary artery disease (CAD)  being male and over the age of 65.  - He has a history of several major risk factors for CAD  including hypertension  diabetes  high cholesterol  and a longstanding history of heavy smoking.  - He is also relatively sedentary with a high-fat diet and family history of heart disease. - His presenting complaint of chest pain triggered by exertion  radiating to left arm  and relieving at rest is typical of angina  a symptom of CAD. - His diabetes could be contributing silent ischemia  which means he might not feel the typical chest pain due to nerve damage caused by high blood sugar. - His shortness of breath and fatigue could be indications of heart failure  a complication of CAD. Patient Profile: Name: Patient X Sex: Male Age: 60 years  Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: A sedentary  desk-based job Living Status: Lives with wife Smoking Status: History of smoking for 30 years  quit 5 years ago Alcohol Intake: Moderate  occasional   Diet: High in saturated fats and sugars Exercise: Minimal  Problem Representation: Patient X presents with classic symptoms of coronary artery disease (CAD)  including periodic episodes of chest pain  which typically occurs during physical exertion or emotional stress  shortness of breath  fatigue  and dizziness.  The patient has several significant risk factors for CAD including his age  sex  history of smoking  sedentary lifestyle and diet high in saturated fats and sugars. He also has a family history of heart disease  with his father having died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 62.  Past medical history includes: - Mild hypertension managed with Lisinopril  - Hypercholesterolemia treated with statins  - Prediabetic (currently managed with diet)  The patient's symptoms  coupled with his demographic profile and medical history  strongly suggest CAD. Further diagnostic tests (i.e. EKG  stress test  coronary angiogram) would be necessary to confirm the disease and to assess the severity and extent of artery blockage.   Management of the patient's CAD would likely involve a combination of lifestyle changes (including  most importantly  dietary modification and an exercise program)  medication to manage symptoms and prevent disease progression  and potentially  if indicated by the extent of disease  revascularization procedures such as angioplasty or coronary artery bypass grafting.

Patient Problem Representation:  A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of chest discomfort and breathlessness on exertion. He has a history of smoking about 20 cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. His BMI is calculated as 30. His familial history is significant for premature coronary artery disease  with his father having undergone angioplasty at the age of 60.   Past medical history includes hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily). He also has type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago  inadequately controlled on Metformin 1000mg twice daily with a recent HbA1C level of 7.8%. His lipid profile shows raised LDL levels and reduced HDL levels despite being on statin (Atorvastatin 40mg nightly).   His physical examination reveals mild obesity  blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  and normal heart sounds with no murmurs. As per the initial evaluation  the ECG shows suspected ST-T wave changes in the inferolateral leads and the cardiac enzymes are pending.   In summary  the patient is a 65-year-old male with multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease including age  male sex  family history of premature coronary artery disease  chronic cigarette smoking  obesity  hypertension  dyslipidemia  and inadequately controlled diabetes mellitus. He now presents with chest symptoms suggestive of angina.   Based on this problem representation  next steps will be to confirm the diagnosis of angina and to assess the severity of coronary artery disease using appropriate investigations  and then to initiate an individualized management plan accordingly.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male known as Mr. Smith. He lives in a suburban area and is retired from business management occupation. He is married with three adult children. Mr. Smith is a former smoker and quit 10 years ago but has a 25 pack-year smoking history. His diet is high in fat and lacks in fruits and vegetables. Despite living in a community with accessible fitness facilities  he does not take part in regular physical activity. He has difficulty in managing stress and has a family history of heart diseases.  Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with stage II hypertension for which he had been on medication (ACE inhibitors and diuretics) for the past 20 years. He was diagnosed with type II diabetes mellitus 10 years ago and is managing it with oral hypoglycemic agents. He was also found to have high cholesterol levels around 8 years ago but is non-compliant with statins therapy. He has been showing signs of obesity with a BMI of 31. Additionally  he suffered a transient ischemic attack (minor stroke) about 5 years ago from which he completely recovered. He also complains of chronic gastritis for which he takes OTC antacid medications.  Presenting Complaints related to CAD:  Mr. Smith presents with symptoms of exertional angina characterized by a gripping or heavy pain in his chest which radiates to his left upper shoulder and neck. The pain usually occurs when he climbs stairs or walks uphill and is relieved by rest. He also experienced rare episodes of equivalent symptoms such as breathlessness and fatigue during exercise. The severity and frequency of these episodes have increased over the past few months. He also faces difficulty sleeping due to anxiety about his health  further worsened by episodes of nocturnal angina.  This problem representation with demographic characterization and past medical history provides a comprehensive background to further diagnose  manage  and treat Mr. Smith's probable coronary artery disease (CAD)  along with managing lifestyle factors and co-existing conditions.

Patient Problem Representation:  Demographics: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J. He is a retired engineer currently residing in Washington D.C. He is a former smoker who quit a decade ago and reports having 1-2 standard drinks per week. His diet is heavy in processed and fatty foods. He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his former desk job and enjoys watching the local baseball events.   Medical History: Based on his past medical records  Mr. J was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago  requiring medication management. His latest blood pressure check  a month ago  noted readings at 140/85 mm Hg.   He had experienced elevated cholesterol levels for the past 15 years  with his latest lipid panel showing a high LDL-cholesterol level of 150 mg/dL  low HDL-cholesterol of 35 mg/dL  and total cholesterol of 290 mg/dL. He was on low-dose statins which he took intermittently.   Four years ago  he was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes  managed with oral hypoglycemic medications. His recent hemoglobin A1c was 7.8%. He underwent a stress test two years ago due to chest discomfort that was attributed to acid reflux and changes in his diet.  Family History: Mr. J reported that his late father also had coronary artery disease and passed away from a heart attack at the age of 72 years old. Demographic Characterization:  Mr. Smith is a retired engineer who lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a former smoker with a 20-pack-year history and quit smoking 10 years ago. He enjoys occasional social drinking  usually 1-2 beers on weekends. His diet is moderately balanced  though he admits to liking fast food and sweets. He leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his retirement and suffers from overweight with a BMI of 27. As for family history  his father underwent bypass surgery at the age of 64.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with high blood pressure 15 years ago and has been controlling it with medication. His latest BP recording was 145/90 mmHg.  2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with diabetes 10 years ago and has been managing his condition with oral antidiabetic drugs and lifestyle modifications.  3. Dyslipidemia: He has elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels and is on statin therapy.  4. Obesity: Mr. Smith has a BMI of 27  signifying overweight.  5. He had a colonoscopy 5 years ago  which showed diverticulosis but no polyps.  Current Medication:   1. Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg daily for hypertension 2. Metformin 500mg twice daily for diabetes 3. Atorvastatin 20 mg daily for dyslipidemia  The combination of these symptoms and Mr. Smith's significant past medical history with risk factors including hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  obesity  and smoking history indicates a strong suspicion for coronary artery disease (CAD).

Patient Profile:  Mr. B  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  hails from San Francisco  CA. He has been a regular smoker for the past 30 years and moderately drinks alcohol. His regular diet is predominantly high in sodium content and saturated fats.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. B presented himself at our clinic complaining of severe and continuous chest pain often radiating to the left shoulder and arm  shortness of breath for the last one month. The pain increased in intensity  especially after physical exertion or emotional stress.  Past Medical History:  Mr. B was previously diagnosed with hypertension and Type II diabetes. He has been on regular medications  Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for his diabetes. Adding to this  Mr. B also had a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  with his father having succumbed to a myocardial infarction at an age similar to his present age.  Clinical and Diagnostic Findings:  On examination  his blood pressure read 155/95 mmHg  and his BMI was 29  indicating obesity. ECG showed ST-segment depressions and T wave inversions  suggestive of ischemia. Stress test induced the typical chest pain and caused ST-segment depressions. A coronary angiography was conducted  which revealed significant obstructions in the left anterior descending artery and left circumflex artery.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical findings  angiogram results  and considering the risk factors - hypertension  smoking  diabetes  diet  obesity  and family history  Mr. B was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Treatment:  Mr. B was immediately started on antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  statins  and beta-blockers to reduce the risk of a heart attack. Lifestyle modifications were heavily stressed  which included a healthy diet plan  regular physical exercise  cessation of smoking  and limiting alcohol. Plans were also laid for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) due to the presence of significant obstructions.  Outcome and Follow-up:  PCI successfully cleared up the obstructions. He was further advised to regularly follow up with routine check-ups and to strictly adhere to the medication regimen and lifestyle modifications. Education was provided about recognizing early signs of any impending heart problems. The patient also agreed to join a support group for patients with CAD  allowing him to better manage his condition.  This case emphasizes the importance of regular check-ups and leading a healthy lifestyle  especially for individuals with multiple risk factors and a family history of CAD.

Title: Case Report on Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) in an Elderly Male Patient   Demographics: Patient Initials: PB Gender: Male Age: 70-years-old Occupation: Retired accountant Ethnicity: Caucasian Residence: New York  USA Marital Status: Married  Presenting Complaint: PB presented to the cardiology clinic with symptoms that started six months ago including recurrent episodes of chest pain  shortness of breath  and occasional spells of dizziness. The pain is generally exertional and relieves with rest.  Medical History: Hypertension - Diagnosed 12 years ago  reasonably controlled on Amlodipine 10mg daily.  Type 2 Diabetes - Diagnosed 10 years ago  HbA1C 8.0% on Metformin 2g daily. Hyperlipidemia - Diagnosed 8 years ago  on Atorvastatin 20mg daily. PB is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 5 years ago. Moderate alcohol drinker up until 10 years ago. There is a family history of coronary artery disease; his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 65.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination was unremarkable except for a body mass index (BMI) of 30  indicating obesity. Blood pressure was elevated at the visit (160/85 mm hg). EKG showed T wave inversions in leads V1-V4.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the clinical suspicion of CAD  PB was advised to undergo diagnostic coronary angiography. The angiography revealed significant (>70%) stenosis in the left anterior descending artery (LAD) and circumflex artery (CX) with moderate (50%) stenosis in the right coronary artery (RCA).  Management: PB was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin 75mg and Clopidogrel 75mg)  along with medications to control his risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes). Following the coronary angiogram  he was considered for coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).   Follow-up: PB underwent successful CABG. After surgery  the patient was enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program. He was also counseled about the importance of lifestyle modification  including adopting a heart-healthy diet  quitting alcohol  and engaging in regular physical activity.   Summary: This case underscores the significant role of risk factor modification and control in patients with established CAD. It also highlights the importance of lifestyle changes in conjunction with medical therapies and surgical intervention in the management of CAD.

Case Report ---------- Patient Information  A 67-year-old African American male patient presented to the outpatient clinic with signs of chest discomfort and shortness of breath. The patient was a former smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history and recently stopped approximately 5 years ago. The patient has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are both under control with medications (amlodipine for hypertension and rosuvastatin for hyperlipidemia). He has a body mass index (BMI) of 29  borderline obesity  and a noted personal history of alcohol abuse in the past. The patient reported a family history of heart disease with his father suffering from a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Clinical Findings  The patient stated he had been suffering from intermittent chest pain that had been increasing in severity over the last 3 weeks  particularly during light physical activity. The pain was described as a squeezing sensation in the chest  sometimes radiating to his left shoulder and arm. He also reported episodes of unexplained fatigue and mild shortness of breath during daily activities.  Diagnostic Assessment  An electrocardiogram (EKG) was performed which showed nonspecific ST-segment and T-wave abnormalities. Results from blood work  including complete blood count (CBC)  were within normal limits except for mildly elevated total cholesterol (245mg/dL) and LDL (""bad"" cholesterol) levels (160mg/dL). His blood pressure was slightly elevated (145/86mmHg).  Based on the EKG findings  coupled with the patient's symptoms  a cardiac stress test was conducted  which indicated possible myocardial ischemia. The patient was referred for coronary angiography. Angiography revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery and left circumflex artery.  Therapeutic Intervention  The patient was diagnosed as having coronary artery disease (CAD) due to the presence of significant stenosis identified during angiography. Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was performed  and drug-eluting stents were placed in both stenotic segments. The patient tolerated the procedure well without any complications. He was prescribed aspirin and clopidogrel (antiplatelet agents)  as well as metoprolol (a beta-blocker)  to minimize the risk of future cardiac events.  Follow-up and Outcomes  During the follow-up period  the patient's symptoms of chest pain and shortness of breath substantially improved.
