His blood pressure was regulated  and LDL levels were decreased due to the up titration of rosuvastatin and enhancement of dietary control suggested by a dietitian. The patient was also advised to maintain a regular exercise schedule.  Patient Perspective  The patient expressed relief following the procedure and subsequent treatment. He reported better understanding of the importance of healthy lifestyle changes  such as balanced diet  regular exercise  and abstaining from alcohol and tobacco. Further  the patient also agreed to regularly monitor his blood pressure and cholesterol levels and prompt any abnormal findings.  Informed Consent  The patient gave his informed consent to share his case anonymously for educational and research purposes.

Patient Initials: M.H.   Age: 70 years   Sex: Male   Occupation: Retired engineer   Race: Caucasian  Presenting concerns:   The patient presented with complaints of ongoing chest discomfort  particularly during physical activity. He also expressed experiencing shortness of breath and occasional lightheadedness.   Medical History:   M.H. has a past medical history of hypertension and Type 2 diabetes for the past 10 years  both of which are managed with lifestyle changes and oral medications. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit 10 years ago after being diagnosed with hypertension and diabetes. He has a moderate alcohol intake. He does not practice regular physical activity citing fatigue as a concern.   Family History:  The patient reported that his mother died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 75 years and his father died of stroke at the age of 80 years. His elder brother was diagnosed with ischemic heart disease at the age of 67.  Clinical Findings:  Upon physical examination  M.H.’s blood pressure was found to be 150/90 mmHg and body mass index (BMI) was calculated to be 28  falling into the overweight category. Upon cardiac auscultation  no heart murmurs or abnormal sounds were detected.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Electrocardiogram (ECG) was abnormal showing ST-segment depression suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Laboratory tests showed an increased level of total cholesterol (220 mg/dL)  increased low-density lipoprotein (LDL  160 mg/dL)  reduced high-density lipoprotein (HDL  30 mg/dL)  and increased triglycerides (200 mg/dL). Fasting glucose level was elevated (180 mg/dL)  indicating poor glycemic control. The cardiac biomarkers (troponin I  CK-MB) were within normal range.  A coronary angiogram was subsequently performed  revealing triple vessels disease with significant stenosis in the left anterior descending artery (80%)  left circumflex artery (70%)  and right coronary artery (75%).  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the extent of his coronary artery disease (CAD)  the patient was managed with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) along with the placement of drug-eluting stents in all the three arteries. He was also prescribed aspirin  clopidogrel  atorvastatin  metformin  an ACE inhibitor  and a beta-blocker.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:  M.H. has been advised regular follow-ups and has been encouraged to make significant lifestyle modifications  including diet  physical activity and stress management. He is being regularly monitored for his lipid profile  blood pressure  and blood glucose levels. He was also instructed to consult immediately if he experiences chest pain  shortness of breath or any other concerning symptoms.  Teaching Points:  This case signifies the importance of considering CAD in elderly patients presenting with vague symptoms like chest discomfort  light-headedness  and shortness of breath. It also highlights the role of risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  smoking  sedentary lifestyle  and a family history of the disease in the development of CAD. Early detection and appropriate management with lifestyle modifications and pharmacotherapy could potentially prevent major adverse cardiovascular events.

Case Report - Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanic  with a body mass index of 27.5  residing in New York City. He is a smoker with a 40-pack-year history and consumes alcohol moderately. He is married  has two children  and lives with his wife. He has no allergies reported.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known medical history of hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes  all of which have been managed with medication. He has been utilizing antihypertensive drugs (hydrochlorothiazide and lisinopril)  oral hypoglycemic agents (metformin)  and statins for cholesterol control. The patient reports medication compliance is good. His last HbA1c check six months ago reported 7.4%.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain lasting for 3 hours. Initially  he described the pain as pressure-like  located in the substernal area  radiating to the left arm and jaw. Accompanying these symptoms were diaphoresis  and shortness of breath. The pain was not relieved by rest.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was afebrile  and his blood pressure was found to be 155/90 mmHg  heart rate 90 bpm  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. The cardiac examination revealed regular rhythm without any murmurs or gallops. Other systemic physical examination findings were within normal limits. His EKG showed ST-segment elevation in leads II  III  and aVF  suggestive of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).   Diagnosis: Given the typical history and EKG changes  a diagnosis of STEMI was made  consistent with a high probability of underlying significant coronary artery disease (CAD).   Treatment and Outcomes: The patient was immediately started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  high-intensity statin therapy  and was taken for an emergency coronary angiogram. The angiogram revealed significant stenosis in the right coronary artery  which was then successfully revascularized with a drug-eluting stent placement. The patient's post-procedure course was uncomplicated  and he was discharged on post-procedure day 3  with plans for outpatient cardiac rehabilitation and lifestyle modification counselling.  The patient was also prescribed a beta-blocker (metoprolol) and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (lisinopril) at discharge with an advice to continue them life-long  unless contraindicated. He was advised to quit smoking and limit the consumption of alcohol. The importance of a balanced diet  regular exercise  and the continuation of his usual medications was also emphasised.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the pivotal role of early recognition and management of CAD risk factors and the importance of immediate management of acute STEMI to prevent significant morbidity and mortality.

**Patient Profile:**  Initials: H.B Age: 62 years Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer Origin: Caucasian   **Clinical Presentation:**  Mr. H.B presented with a 2-week history of exertional chest pain and intermittent palpitations. The patient described the pain as ""sharp"" and ""located at the center of the chest""  accompanied by occasional bouts of shortness of breath. The pain reportedly lasts for approximately 1-2 minutes after rest.   **Past Medical History:**  The patient has a significant history of hypertension (15 years) and hyperlipidemia (12 years). He is a former smoker  having quit 5 years ago but had a 30-year smoking history prior. There is no family history of coronary artery disease. However  his father died from a stroke at 67 years of age  and his mother had diabetes.   The patient was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes and has been managing it using oral hypoglycemic agents for the past 10 years. He has a sedentary lifestyle and acknowledges a diet that is high in saturated fats and trans fats.   **Clinical Examination:**  Vital signs were within normal limits except for elevated blood pressure (158/95 mmHg). Body Mass Index (BMI) was 31  indicating he is categorized under obesity class 1.   The cardiovascular examination revealed no abnormalities  jugular venous pressure was not elevated and no heart murmurs were detected. However  the presence of xanthelasma and Achilles tendon xanthomas was noted  indicating dyslipidemia.  **Further Investigations:**  An ECG showed T wave inversion in leads II  III and aVF. The treadmill test showed positive results. Blood tests revealed elevated cholesterol levels (233 mg/dl)  HDL (30mg/dl) and triglycerides (230 mg/dl).   **Diagnosis:**  Based on clinical history  examination and investigation findings  a diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) was made.  **Treatment and Management:**  The management plan involved lifestyle modifications  symptom control  and risk factor management. The patient was advised on dietary changes  weight control  and gradual initiation of regular aerobic physical activity. Prescription medication includes aspirin for antiplatelet function  beta-blockers for angina control  and statins for hyperlipidemia.  **Follow-Up:**  The patient is scheduled for regular follow-ups every 2 months for clinical evaluation  monitoring symptoms and potential adverse effects of medication. He was also referred to a dietician and a physical therapist to assist with needed lifestyle modifications.  Currently  the patient remains under care and regular follow-up  with medications adjusted based on responses and emerging side effects. The management approach is efficient as the patient reported a significant reduction in symptoms.  **Prognosis:**  CAD is a chronic condition requiring long term control strategies and regular follow-ups. Early diagnosis  aggressive therapeutic strategies  and lifestyle changes have significantly reduced the morbidity and mortality associated with CAD. In this case  the prognosis depends primarily on the patient's commitment to medication regimen and lifestyle changes.  **Learning Points of This Case Report:** This case emphasizes the complexity of managing CAD in the presence of multiple risk factors. Lifestyle modifications are equally crucial as medications in managing CAD and reducing its associated complications. Early detection and intervention can significantly improve the quality of life in CAD patients.

**Patient Information:**   - Age: 64 years old  - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired engineer - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Current Residence: Texas  United States  **Clinical History:**   The patient has a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus that has been well controlled with a combination of Metformin and dietary changes for the past 10 years. He also has a history of hypertension  which has been controlled with Lisinopril. The patient was a smoker for 35 years but quit smoking ten years ago. His father passed away from a stroke at age 68  and his mother died due to complications of a heart attack at age 70. He is obese (BMI=30) and lives a sedentary lifestyle.  **Presenting complaints:**  The patient was admitted to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset chest pain. The pain was retrosternal  radiating to his left arm. It was accompanied by shortness of breath  fatigue and profuse sweating. There had been mild episodes of similar pain occurring during the past week.  **Clinical Findings:**  Upon examination  his vitals on admission were as follows: - Blood Pressure: 165/95 mmHg - Pulse Rate: 98 beats per minute - Oxygen Saturation: 90% on room air - Body Temperature: 98.6 degrees Fahrenheit   A 12-lead ECG showed ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads (V1-V4)  which is consistent with an anterior wall myocardial infarction.  **Therapeutic Intervention:**  The patient was urgently started on medical treatment for ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction. This included aspirin  clopidogrel  enoxaparin and nitroglycerin  along with continuous monitoring and supportive therapy. Given the presenting symptoms and clinical findings  he was subsequently taken for an urgent coronary angiogram.  **Follow up:**  The angiography result showed a 90% occlusion in the left anterior descending artery (LAD). The patient underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement. His post-procedure course was uneventful and his symptoms were completely relieved. He is adhering to dual antiplatelet therapy and has been referred to cardiac rehabilitation for lifestyle modification and risk factor management.  **Notes:**  This case illustrates the importance of early identification and aggressive management of coronary artery disease  particularly in patients with a history of smoking  family history of cardiovascular diseases  hypertension and diabetes. Regular follow-ups with cardiology and medication adjustments were recommended for this patient. Moreover  managing modifiable risk factors such as obesity and maintaining a sedentary lifestyle are crucial components of comprehensive CAD management.

Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson  a 63-year-old African-American male  performs routine small-scale farming. He presented with a 2-week history of intermittent chest discomfort localizing to the left side  which started as a burning sensation but has slowly progressed towards a pressing pain. The pain usually occurs after exerting himself in his farming activities and subsides with rest. The patient also complained of associated shortness of breath during the episodes  decreased exercise tolerance  fatigue  and recent significant weight loss.  Medical History:  The patient has a documented medical history of hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled with hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  managed with metformin. Both conditions are fairly controlled  but the patient has been non-compliant with the medication and diet at times. Additionally  he also has a history of hyperlipidemia managed with statins for 5 years. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  indicating a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD). The patient is an active smoker who smokes around 10 cigarettes per day for the past 35 years and has a moderate alcohol consumption history.   Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient was in distress with vital signs showing BP: 145/90 mmHg  HR: 110 beats per minute  RR: 22 breaths per minute  Temp: 98.6°F  SpO2: 95%. He was afebrile  regular pulse  and his chest examination revealed no abnormalities  such as abnormal heart sounds or murmurs. There were no peripheral signs of chronic vascular disease. Rest of the general and systemic examination did not reveal any significant findings.   Diagnostic Assessment:  ECG showed ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion suggestive of myocardial ischemia. His lipid profile was deranged with high LDL and low HDL levels. Fasting blood sugar was moderately high. The patient was referred for coronary angiography  which revealed obstruction in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery  confirming the diagnosis of CAD.   Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was admitted to the cardiology department. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  beta-blocker (metoprolol)  statin (atorvastatin)  and an angiotensin-converting-enzyme inhibitor (ramipril). He was also prescribed nitroglycerin for angina relief  advised for strict blood pressure control  and glycemic management. Given the significant LAD obstruction  the patient was scheduled for percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The patient was also strongly advised to quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption.   Follow-up and Outcomes:  At follow-up visits post-PCI  the patient showed significant relief from his chest pain and shortness of breath. He was counseled on lifestyle modification  including diet  and continues his prescribed medication regimen. He has been successfully convinced to join a smoking cessation program and reduce alcohol intake drastically. He is being referred for cardiac rehabilitation and regular follow-ups in the cardiology outpatient department.

Title: Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease in a 62-year-old Male  Background:  Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  being the leading cause of mortality worldwide  is of great clinical concern. The case focuses on understanding the course of CAD in a 62-year-old male having a significant past medical history.  Patient Information:  The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian male  a retired banker  with an average built and a BMI of 27. Living in New York City  he is a non-smoker but has a moderate alcohol consumption habit. The patient has a family history of CAD  with his father having died at the age of 67 due to a massive myocardial infarction.  Past Medical History:  This patient was diagnosed with type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and Hypertension at the age of 53. In 2014  he underwent cholecystectomy for gallstone disease. Over the past 8 years  his blood glucose levels and blood pressure have been routinely checked and are fairly controlled through medications including Metformin and Amlodipine respectively. He has no known drug allergies. A significant finding for the patient includes a mildly elevated cholesterol level which was identified 6 years back. Statin therapy was recommended but not followed up diligently by the patient.  Presenting Complaints:  He was brought to the emergency department complaining of severe  unrelieved retrosternal chest pain radiating towards the left arm. The pain was accompanied by shortness of breath  palpitations  and excessive sweating and had been ongoing for the past 3 hours.  Clinical Findings:  On evaluation  his BP was found to be 150/98 mm Hg  pulse 98 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 20/min. He showed signs of mild distress due to pain and was partially relieved with sublingual nitroglycerin.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An ECG demonstrated ST-segment elevation in the anterolateral leads and T wave inversion suggestive of acute anterior wall myocardial infarction. His troponin I was found to be elevated. Coronary angiography performed later revealed significant obstruction in the left anterior descending artery. These findings corroborated with the diagnosis of CAD.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient underwent a successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) where a drug-eluting stent was placed in the left anterior descending artery. He was prescribed Aspirin  Clopidogrel  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and high-dose statins.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  One month follow-up showed considerable improvement in the patient's symptoms. He was advised to limit his alcohol consumption  regulate his diet  and undergo moderate-intensity exercise. He was also urged to maintain adherence to the prescribed medications.  Learning Points:  The case emphasizes the importance of regular monitoring and effective control of risk factors in patients predisposed to CAD. It also underlines the significance of the early recognition of CAD symptoms leading to timely intervention and improved patient outcomes. Lastly  it highlights the crucial role of lifestyle modifications and compliance to medication in CAD management.

Patient Information: Mr. Edward S.  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer with height 5’8” and weight 225 lbs.  Chief Complaint: He presented himself at the emergency department on October 15  2022  with chief complaints of a persisting discomfort in the center of the chest lasting more than 30 minutes  accompanied by shortness of breath  sweating  and sudden onset weakness.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient appeared sweaty and in distress. Vital signs at admission were temperature 36.9 °C  blood pressure 145/95 mmHg  pulse 90 bpm  and respiratory rate 16/min. Chest auscultation was normal. No significant peripheral oedema was appreciated.  Past Medical History: Mr. Edward is a known case of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 10 years  controlled with Metformin 500 mg twice daily. He is also known to have hypertension for 15 years  which has been managed on Amlodipine 5mg per day. He has a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years but quit 5 years ago.  Diagnostic Assessment: The initial ECG showed signs of ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads  suggestive of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Blood reports showed elevated levels of cardiac biomarkers including troponin and CK-MB. The lipid profile indicated a high level of LDL cholesterol and low HDL cholesterol. Glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1C) showed poor control of diabetes.  Therapeutic Intervention: Immediately  the patient was started on a treatment protocol for STEMI including sublingual nitroglycerin  chewable aspirin  intravenous heparin along with oxygen therapy. Further  the patient was immediately taken to the catheterization lab for coronary angiography which revealed a significant blockage in the right coronary artery. The patient underwent successful coronary angioplasty with the placement of a drug-eluting stent.  Follow-ups and Outcomes: The patient’s chest discomfort significantly improved following the angiotherapy. He was advised to continue medication including dual antiplatelets (aspirin and clopidogrel)  statins  beta-blockers  and ACE inhibitors. His diabetes and hypertension were managed with an optimized regimen and consideration of his new heart disease diagnosis.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the importance of prompt recognition and management of coronary artery disease  particularly in a high-risk patient with a history of smoking  diabetes  and hypertension. The patient continues under care with cardiology and primary care physicians for secondary prevention for coronary artery diseases. He has been advised for regular cardiac rehabilitation and a healthier lifestyle  including controlled diet  regular exercises  and strict adherence to medication.

Case Report:   Patient Information:   The patient is a 68-year-old African-American male  living in an urban area. He is a retired general worker and is a lifelong smoker with a 40 pack-year history. He also has a history of heavy alcohol consumption but stopped 5 years ago. He is now non-alcoholic. The patient is currently living alone since his wife passed away  and reports have been physically inactive for the past few years. There is no family history of coronary artery disease (CAD).  Presenting Concerns:  The patient presented with complaints of recurrent chest pain and tightness that typically occurs with exertion or emotional stress and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin  suggestive of stable angina. The pain has been gradually increasing in severity over the past few months. He also reported occasional episodes of breathlessness and fatigue.   Past Medical History:  The patient is known to have type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 20 years and hypertension for the past 15 years which are reasonably controlled with medications. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia. There is no history of stroke  transient ischemic attack  peripheral artery disease  or renal disease. There is no documented history of previous myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 145/90 mm Hg  pulse rate 75 bpm  and BMI of 28. No significant carotid bruits  jugular venous pressure  ankle edema  or valvular heart murmurs were noted.   Diagnosis:  Given the classical angina symptoms and multiple risk factors  a diagnosis of stable CAD was considered. An electrocardiogram showed non-specific ST-T wave changes. A stress test was positive for inducible ischemia. Therefore  coronary angiography was performed which confirmed severe stenosis in the left anterior descending coronary artery and moderate stenosis in the right coronary artery. Overall  these findings were consistent with significant CAD.   Treatment:  The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel)  a beta-blocker (metoprolol)  an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (lisinopril)  and a statin (atorvastatin). Following multidisciplinary discussions  it was decided to proceed with revascularization using percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) considering his symptoms and angiographic findings.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the classical clinical features of CAD  especially in high-risk individuals. Optimal control of underlying risk factors in addition to revascularization can improve clinical outcomes. Prompt diagnosis and management may prevent complications such as acute myocardial infarction and sudden cardiac death. Further studies are warranted to understand better the interplay and management of multiple risk factors in CAD.

Patient Information:  Mr. A  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  weighing around 80 kilograms  was reported to have been suffering from shortness of breath  frequent episodes of chest pain  particularly upon exertion  and fatigue during the last three months. He was a former smoker with a past smoking history of 40 years  which he quit about two years ago. He had a persistently unhealthy diet high in cholesterol and fat content  and he has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia for the past 15 years.  Medical History:  Mr. A has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled with Lisinopril 20 mg once daily and Atorvastatin 40 mg once daily  respectively. He also had an emergency appendectomy in his 40s and received treatment for a minor stroke seven years ago  but had no other significant hospital admissions or surgeries. Mr. A's father had died in his early 60s due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother had lived to her late 80s with hypertension and diabetes.   Current Medications:  Lisinopril 20 mg daily  Atorvastatin 40 mg daily  and baby Aspirin 81 mg daily as stroke prophylaxis.  Presenting Symptoms and Examination:  The patient reported progressive chest pain  typically provoked by exercise and relieved by rest. He also complained of episodes of shortness of breath and generalized fatigue progressively worsening over a three-month period. Physical examination revealed an elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg and irregular pulse of 85 beats per minute. He had no peripheral edema. Cardiac auscultation revealed no murmurs or gallops.  Diagnostic Assessments:  A 12-lead EKG showed signs of previous anteroseptal infarct but no acute changes. Lab results show a cholesterol profile with an LDL of 160 mg/dL and an HDL of 35 mg/dL. Troponin levels were slightly elevated. He was referred for a stress test which revealed significant ST-depressions in the anterior leads suggesting inducible ischemia.  Diagnosis:  The clinical presentation  risk factors and stress test findings suggested that the patient is suffering from Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Therapeutic Intervention:  Mr A. was immediately advised to make considerable lifestyle changes such as adopting a low-cholesterol diet  moderate physical exercise  and regular medical follow-ups. His aspirin dose was increased to a full dose  and his lipid-lowering medication was switched to Rosuvastatin 40 mg daily for better LDL control.  Follow-up:  Mr. A. is scheduled to have a coronary angiogram for further evaluation and treatment planning. He was strongly advised to maintain a healthy lifestyle  attend regular follow-up appointments for the management of coronary artery disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. His family was encouraged to learn CPR and look for signs of an impending heart attack given his high-risk condition.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 67-year-old African American male from New York  presented to the clinic on the account of recurring chest pain  fatigue  and breathlessness  especially after physical activities.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a recorded history of hypertension which is managed with Lisinopril 10mg and Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily for the past 10 years. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago  which is currently controlled by Metformin 1000mg twice daily. He is an ex-smoker  quit smoking around 12 years back after a smoking history of almost 30 pack-years. He consumes alcohol moderately  2-3 beers on the weekend. No known allergy to any drugs. His body mass index (BMI) is 27 kg/m2  which is within the overweight limit.  Family medical history is also significant  his father passed away in his early 60s due to myocardial infarction and his older brother has recently been diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient was experiencing intermittent chest tightness and shortness of breath  especially post physical exertion from cleaning his house or after walking a few blocks. His chest pains were described as squeezing and pressure-like  located in the center of the chest not radiating anywhere  typically lasting for 5-10 minutes and relieved by rest.   Clinical Findings  Diagnostic Assessment:  Physical examination revealed normal vital signs: BP 132/76 mmHg  HR 76 bpm  SpO2 96%  and RR 14 breaths/minute. Heart sounds were normal with no murmur heard. Pulmonary sound revealed no wheezing or crackles.   The ECG showed T-wave inversion in the precordial leads suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Further investigations including coronary angiography confirmed severe coronary artery disease (CAD) with 80% blockage in the left anterior descending coronary artery. Lipid profile also showed raised LDL levels and total cholesterol.  Therapeutic Approach & Follow-up:  Mr. Doe was started on statin therapy (Atorvastatin 40mg). Dual antiplatelets - Aspirin 81mg and Clopidogrel 75mg were initiated along with a beta-blocker (Metoprolol 50mg) and nitroglycerin as needed for chest pain relief. A referral to a cardiothoracic surgeon was made for possible coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) as per guideline-directed management and therapy (GDMT).   Patient was advised about the risks of CABG and the importance of lifestyle modifications. A plan was made for him to see a nutritionist and physiotherapist for cardiac rehabilitation which includes educating on low cholesterol diet  weight management program  and aerobic conditioning exercise. He was also advised to maintain strict control of his BP and blood sugar levels.   Conclusion:  The patient  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with severe CAD  considering his socio-demographic features  lifestyle  initial clinical presentation  father's medical history  and diagnostic findings. He has been put on appropriate treatment and further investigations are ongoing to decide the course of treatment. This case reflects the significant impact of cardiovascular risk factors including hypertension  diabetes  smoking history  and familial predisposition in the development of CAD. It underscores the importance of early recognition  timely intervention  aggressive risk factor management  and lifestyle modification for better clinical outcomes in CAD patients.

Patient Information:  A 62-year-old African American male patient  retired from an office job  non-smoker  presented at the clinic with complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  and easy fatigability.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  the patient revealed that he had been experiencing an increasing frequency of chest pain over the past three months  often described as a pressure-like discomfort with radiation to both arms. The pain worsens with physical exertion and alleviates with rest. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  occasional bouts of dizziness  and extreme fatigue.  Diagnosis:  The initial diagnosis of the condition indicates potential Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The suspicion was confirmed with tests including an electrocardiogram (ECG)  which showed significant ST-segment depression  indicating possible ischemia. Further diagnosis was confirmed following an exercise stress test and a coronary angiogram  which revealed significant blockages in the left anterior descending (LAD) and right coronary arteries (RCA).  Past Medical History:  The patient has a documented history of hypertension  diagnosed 8 years ago  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 15 years ago. His hypertension is generally well-controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20mg daily)  but has occasional episodes of elevated blood pressure during routine check-ups. His diabetes is not well-controlled  with a recent HbA1c of 8.5%  despite taking Metformin 1000mg twice daily.  Family History:  The patient's family history is positive for heart disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at 65 years and an older brother having undergone a coronary artery bypass graft at the age of 58.  Treatment and Outcome:  The patient underwent a successful percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placements in LAD and RCA. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin 81mg and clopidogrel 75mg). He was also prescribed Atorvastatin 40mg daily to manage his LDL levels. The plan also includes closer management of his diabetes and hypertension and lifestyle changes including a heart-healthy diet  regular aerobic exercise  and weight management.   Follow-Up:  The patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit in one month post-PCI. It is recommended to monitor his symptoms  adherence to prescribed medications  blood pressure  and glycemic control. The cardiologist also advised the patient to report any chest pain  dizziness  or any other new symptoms immediately. If the patient remains stable and adheres to recommended treatment  annual follow-ups are suggested  with diagnostic testing for CAD repeated every 2-3 years.

Patient Information:   Mr. X  a 69-year-old African American male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe chest pain which he rates at 8 on a scale of 1-10. The pain was described as a crushing sensation radiating towards the left arm which started while he was at rest. Mr. X is an ex-smoker with a history of smoking 1 pack a day for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He is also a known hypertensive for 25 years and diabetic for approximately 10 years. He works as a cab driver and lives with his wife.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X's hypertension and diabetes are both well-controlled on treatment. He has been using Amlodipine 5mg per day and Metformin 500mg twice per day. He has no known drug allergies. Mr. X reported that his father had a heart attack at the age of 60 and his mother has hypertension. His BMI falls in the obese category. He also has mild intermittent asthma  which is managed as required with Salbutamol inhaler. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.  Presenting Complaints:  The pain was sudden in onset  severe  and was associated with shortness of breath  profuse perspiration  and light-headedness. These symptoms triggered severe anxiety leading him to seek immediate medical attention. He denies having any similar prior episodic pain  significant weight changes  or dietary changes.  Examination and Investigation:  Initial vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate of 90 bpm  and respiratory rate of 22 per minute with oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Inspection of the chest did not show any abnormalities. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal S1 and S2 heart sounds without any murmurs.   An EKG performed demonstrated ST-segment elevations in leads V2 to V5. Blood tests  including a full blood count  were within normal range but cardiac enzymes including Troponin T were elevated. The Echo Doppler study suggested wall motion abnormalities  indicative of myocardial infraction. On the basis of the above findings  Mr. X was diagnosed with a coronary artery disease  specifically  an ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).  Conclusion:  Mr. X was immediately started on a regimen of aspirin  clopidogrel  low molecular weight heparin and intravenous nitroglycerine in the emergency department. Subsequently  he was shifted for coronary angiography after obtaining informed consent. The procedure revealed significant left anterior descending artery stenosis and he was further managed by percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement. He was adequately counseled about the lifestyle modifications  management of risk factors  need for regular follow-up and importance of medication compliance. The patient was finally discharged in a stable condition on dual antiplatelet therapy along with beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  statins  and lifestyle advice including diet control and daily exercise.

Patient Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  living in a suburban area of New Jersey. His marital status is married; he lives with his wife and is the father of two adult children. He's a non-smoker; however  his medical history does indicate he smoked moderately from the age of 18 until the age of 45. His alcohol intake is minimal  consuming only socially during gatherings and events. There's a strong family history of heart diseases  with his father passing away at the age of 52 due to a myocardial infarction and his elder brother diagnosed with angina at 55.  Past Medical History: The patient has been under medication for Type 2 diabetes for the past ten years  only managing to control his glucose levels via insulin shots for about five years. He was diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  currently managed with a daily dose of beta-blocker and ACE inhibitor. He has also been dealing with obesity and was diagnosed with high cholesterol two years ago but does not take medication due to side effects. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 30  and his lipid profile showed an elevated LDL level of 160mg/dl and decreased HDL level of 35mg/dl.  Present Complaint: The patient presented with complaints of chest pain and discomfort which  according to him  was a sensation of tightness and heaviness in the chest with pain radiating down the left arm. The pain was graded 8/10 in intensity  which was exacerbated with physical activity  particularly after climbing stairs and relieved by rest. The patient also reported episodes of shortness of breath  dyspnea on exertion  extreme fatigue and occasional dizziness.   Diagnosis and Management: Based on the above clinical presentation and the patient's medical history  a diagnosis of stable Coronary Artery Disease was made. The patient underwent an elective coronary angiography that revealed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending coronary artery. He was immediately referred for a cardiac catheterization and subsequent percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stent placement  which was successful without any complications.  Post-Discharge Plan: The patient has been advised to adhere to lifestyle changes that include a low-sodium  low-cholesterol diet  regular exercise  weight management and blood pressure control. He's currently prescribed a daily regimen of aspirin  a beta-blocker  an ACE inhibitor  and a statin to manage his cholesterol levels. The patient is scheduled for a 6-month follow-up to evaluate the effectiveness of his current management plan.  The patient's family has been recommended to consider screening for heart diseases due to the strong family history. Nationwide heart health awareness programs can help in early detection and risk factor mitigation  improving the outcomes for CAD.  Educational Objectives: This case highlights the importance of managing risk factors like hypertension  diabetes  obesity  high cholesterol level  smoking and family history in preventing the development of coronary artery disease. Primary care providers should have a high index of suspicion for CAD in patients with similar profiles and encourage healthy lifestyle modifications.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. J. Milton  a 68-year-old African American male  presented himself in the emergency department (ED) with complaints of severe chest pain and breathlessness. He has resided in Boston  Massachusetts for the past 30 years  working as a high school teacher  now retired.   Medical History: Mr. Milton has a 10-year history of Hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and is overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28.2. He followed a treatment plan consisting of Metformin for T2DM and Lisinopril for hypertension but admits having been inconsistent with his medication adherence over the past year. Mr. Milton has a sedentary lifestyle and a poor diet; he reports Regular Alcohol Use but denies smoking or other substance abuse. There’s a notable family history of Cardiovascular Disease (CVD); notably  his father succumbed to a Myocardial infarction at age 69.  Current Episode: Approximately 48 hours prior to presentation in the ED  Mr. Milton began experiencing dull  central chest pain  initially attributing it to indigestion. However  the persistent pain  along with increasing breathlessness and profuse sweating  prompted him to seek immediate medical attention. On presentation  he was visibly distressed with a pallor and cold  clammy skin. The pain did not subside with rest or sublingual nitrate administration.   Clinical Findings: Upon examination  vital signs showed a blood pressure of 165/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  respirations at 22 per minute and oxygen saturation at 94% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed a soft S1 and S2 with no extra sounds or murmurs. There was slight bilateral pitting edema up to the ankles. Chest auscultation noted bibasilar crackles.  Emergency ECG was completed which showed significant ST-segment elevation in II  III  aVF and V1-V4 leads  confirming the presence of an ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Subsequent Blood tests showed significantly elevated cardiac enzymes (Troponin I: 1.8ng/mL  normal: ≤0.04ng/mL). Lipid profile revealed a cholesterol level of 250mg/dl  LDL: 180mg/dl  HDL: 35mg/dl  and Triglycerides: 220mg/dl confirming hyperlipidemia.  Diagnosis: The clinical presentation along with the ECG changes and serum marker levels confirmed the diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease resulting in an acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (Heart attack).  Discussion: As is seen in Mr. Milton's case  in CAD patients  risk factors include genetic predisposition  age  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  obesity  and lifestyle factors like sedentary habit and excessive alcohol use. Early diagnosis  prompt treatment  management of underlying risk factors  and patient education regarding lifestyle changes are essential in managing Coronary Artery Disease to prevent fatal complications as Myocardial infarction.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Richard Thompson  a 59-year-old African American male  came to our medical attention with complaints of progressive chest pain. He reports that the chest pain is provoked by physical exertion and relieved by rest. The patient resides in an urban settlement and his lifestyle is classified as sedentary. He is a non-drinker  but he has been a chronic smoker for the past 35 years  smoking up to 15 cigarettes daily.   Medical History: The patient's past medical history reveals hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago and is currently being managed with antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). He has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes about 5 years ago and has been on Metformin (500mg BID). There is no history of previous cardiac disease.   His father had a history of myocardial infarction and passed away at the age of 65 years. His mother had hypertension and passed away from stroke at the age of 77.   Physical Examination: On examination  his blood pressure was 150/95mm Hg  pulse rate was 86 per minute  and BMI was 28.5 kg/m2. A chest examination revealed no abnormalities – his heart sound S1 and S2 were normal with no murmur  rubs  or gallops. His lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally  without wheezing  rales  or rhonchi.  Investigation: Electrocardiogram (ECG) showed T wave inversion in the inferolateral leads indicating a possibility of coronary artery disease. Consequently  a coronary angiogram was executed revealing a 70% stenotic lesion in the left anterior descending artery (LAD). Blood tests reveal a lipid profile with high levels of LDL cholesterol at 170 mg/dl and Hemoglobin A1c of 8.9% indicating poor glycemic control.  Diagnosis: Based on the angiographic findings and clinical presentation  he was diagnosed with stable coronary artery disease.  Management: The patient was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel)  statins for lowering cholesterol levels  and a beta-blocker (Metoprolol) to control his heart rate. Glycemic control was optimized by adjusting the dose of Metformin and introducing a basal insulin regimen. Dietary modifications and physical therapy were recommended.  This case highlights the importance of recognizing potential risk factors for coronary artery disease such as hypertension  diabetes  smoking  and family history. Managing these risk factors effectively may help prevent coronary artery disease and its potential complications. It also underscores the need for regular checkups and monitoring for patients with these risk factors.  Following writing this report  the patient gave written informed consent for publication of his case details.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 62-Year-old Male with a History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Patient Presentation:  Mr. J is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the outpatient clinic with a chief complaint of chest discomfort and exercise intolerance. Prior to this episode  the patient was in good health with the exception of controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Demographics: Mr. J is a retired engineer who lives with his wife in a suburb area. As a lifelong smoker  he has a 45-pack year history of smoking. His diet can be characterized as high-sodium and high-fat  with minimal exercise in his daily routine. He has a family history of heart disease and stroke: his father died in his 60s from a myocardial infarction and his older sister has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J has been treated for hypertension for the past 10 years and takes lisinopril 20 mg daily. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia for which he has been taking atorvastatin 40 mg nightly. No known drug allergies have been documented. He had a hernia repair 15 years ago but otherwise has no other surgical history. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He has no previous diagnosis of diabetes  kidney disease  or liver disease.  Clinical Findings: On examination  his BMI was noted to be 30.2. His blood pressure was 145/92 mmHg  pulse 82 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 95% on room air. The patient's cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs or gallops. His lungs were clear to auscultation.   Investigations: Laboratory studies showed a lipid panel with total cholesterol of 244 mg/dL  HDL 36 mg/dL  LDL 162 mg/dL  and triglycerides of 230 mg/dL. His fasting glucose was 106 mg/dL. EKG showed T-wave inversions in leads V4-V6. Given his high-risk factors  a subsequent coronary angiogram revealed an 80% stenosis of the left anterior descending artery.   Diagnosis: Mr. J was diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD). The diagnosis was made based on findings from the patient's history of consistent chest discomfort  his cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  smoking  and family history)  and invasive coronary angiography.  Treatment and Progress: Mr. J was immediately started on dual-antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel and referred for a percutaneous coronary intervention. Post-procedure follow-up indicated successful stent implantation with the restoration of blood flow in the LAD. He was advised to incorporate lifestyle modifications such as smoking cessation  diet modification  weight reduction  and regular exercise. His antihypertensive medication was optimized to better his blood pressure control.  Conclusion: This case underscores the significance of early detection and intervention in advanced cases of CAD. Enhanced emphasis on lifestyle changes and strict adherence to pharmacotherapy is crucial for patients with CAD in preventing cardiovascular events. Comprehensive management including lifestyle modification and optimal medical therapy is necessary for better prognosis.

Patient Information:  Mr. R.K.  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the clinic with complaints of recurrent chest discomfort and shortness of breath particularly on exertion. The patient is a retired school teacher who has been living with his daughter and her family since the death of his wife two years ago. The patient has a known history of chronic tobacco use but quit five years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately and has a sedentary lifestyle. There is no known family history of heart disease.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus for the past 15 years  controlled with metformin. He also was diagnosed with hypertension approximately ten years ago and is on a regimen of lisinopril for the same. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia for which he takes rosuvastatin. The patient also has a history suggestive of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  for which he uses a salbutamol inhaler as needed.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient started experiencing chest pain about six months ago. The pain was initially mild and used to occur while climbing stairs or walking a significant distance. Over the past two weeks  the intensity and frequency of the pain have increased  also occurring at rest at times. The pain is described as 'squeezing' or 'pressure-like ' radiating to the left arm and associated with sweating. He also complained about fatigue and occasional episodes of dizziness.   Clinical Findings:  Physical examination reveals an obese male with a BMI of 31. His blood pressure is 170/95 mmHg. His heart rate is regular but rapid at 95 beats per minute. Chest inspection revealed decreased chest expansion on both sides and vesicular breath sounds with prolonged expiration and occasional wheezes.   Laboratory Investigations:  EKG shows ST depression and T-wave inversion in leads II  III and aVF indicative of myocardial ischemia. Blood tests are as follows: Random blood sugar is elevated at 220 mg/dl  cholesterol levels are high with LDL-160 mg/dl and HDL -30mg/dl  serum creatinine at 1.5 mg/dl  serum potassium at 5 meq/l  serum sodium at 135 meq/l. His HbA1c is 8 percent. Serum Trop-T levels were raised  which supports the diagnosis of Acute Coronary Syndrome (ACS).  Treatment Initiated:  The patient was diagnosed with Unstable Angina  a type of Acute Coronary Syndrome and was immediately started on a conservative management strategy that included antiplatelet drugs like Aspirin and Clopidogrel  low molecular weight heparins  nitroglycerin  atenolol  and statins. His blood pressure and diabetes medications were continued and optimized. The patient was also referred to Cardiology for further evaluation and management including the possibility of coronary angiography.  Follow-up and Planning   Smoking cessation therapy was recommended. Health education including dietary recommendations to lower cholesterol intake and lifestyle modification for weight loss  aiming at a healthier lifestyle was provided. The patient was advised to follow-up regularly to monitor his blood glucose levels  blood pressure  cholesterol levels and for any new symptoms.

Patient Information:  Mr. D  a Caucasian male  is a 67-year-old retiree who resides in a semi-rural area. He is a widower with three adult daughters. He had a 43-year professional career in heavy machinery operation. He is a non-smoker and doesn't drink alcohol; however  he discloses a history of tobacco use for nearly 20 years but quit 25 years ago. He has a family history of heart disease on his maternal side with his mother having died at 74 of a myocardial infarction.  Presenting Concern:  The primary concern at presentation was recurrent episodes of chest pain over the past six months. The episodes are generally associated with exertional activities like gardening and are promptly relieved with rest. Lately  the episodes have increased both in frequency and intensity forcing him to seek medical attention. He voluntarily disclosed that he has avoided seeking timely medical assistance due to fear surrounding the COVID-19 pandemic.  Past Medical History:  Mr. D has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he is on standard medication - Lisinopril 10mg od for hypertension and Rosuvastatin 10mg nocte for hyperlipidemia. He has a previous history of no other significant illnesses.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination showed normal vitals with a blood pressure of 140/80 mm of Hg  body mass index was elevated at 30.6 kg/m^2. ECG changes were suggestive of possible ischemia. High-sensitivity troponin was normal. A resting transthoracic echocardiogram showed a ejection fraction of 55% with no regional wall motion abnormality.  Diagnosis:  Based on his clinical presentation  positive ECG findings  past medical history  and family history  a diagnosis was made of Angina Pectoris secondary to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).  Management:  He was immediately initiated on medications like Aspirin (75 mg/d daily)  Nitroglycerin (0.4 mg SL for chest pain)  and Metoprolol (25mg/d). Secondary prevention strategies were emphasized including diet modification  exercise  and weight reduction strategies. He was referred to the cardiology department for further investigation and management  including coronary angiography.  Discussion:  This case underlines the importance of maintaining regular health checkups and challenges the perceived avoidance of medical facilities due to the pandemic. It brings focus to the broader issue of delayed presentations and treatment in patients with chronic conditions requiring regular follow-up during these unprecedented times  which may lead to poorer health outcomes.  Further  it emphasizes the need to reinforce secondary prevention strategies in CAD patients as lifestyle modification aids greatly in disease management. Considering the long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  in this case  it is a reminder that good control of these risk factors is compulsory for preventing disease progression.

Patient Profile: A Caucasian male  66 years old  retired police officer  presented with recurrent chest pain over the past 2 weeks. He is married with 3 grown children and currently lives in North Carolina. He does not smoke and has no known drug allergies  but he has a long history of poor diet and sedentary lifestyle.   Medical History: The patient has been overweight since his 40s when he was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus. He was then put on Metformin to control his glucose levels. He also has hypertension for about 14 years and is currently on Losartan to manage his blood pressure. Six years ago  he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and was prescribed statins for treatment. He has a family history of his father having a myocardial infarction around a similar age. No history of surgeries or major illnesses.  Presenting Condition: Recently  he has been experiencing episodes of angina  especially after physical activity or intense emotions  which generally relieves after rest or ingestion of nitroglycerin (prescribed previously for symptomatic relief). The pain was described as heavy pressure in the mid to left chest area that sometimes radiates towards his left arm. He denied associated symptoms like shortness of breath  dizziness or fainting. Of late  these episodes have increased in frequency  raising concerns.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination suggested mild obesity (BMI: 30). Vital signs were: blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse 72 bpm  respiratory rate 18 bpm. Cardiovascular examination revealed normal S1 and S2 with no additional heart sounds or murmurs. Lung fields were clear. There was no peripheral oedema.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations revealed a fasting blood glucose of 135 mg/dl  elevated LDL cholesterol level of 148 mg/dl. Rest of the lab parameters including kidney functions and electrolytes were within normal limits. An EKG was performed which showed T wave inversions in leads V1 to V4. A coronary angiogram was suggested which revealed three-vessel disease with significant blockage in the left anterior descending  right coronary artery and left circumflex artery  confirming coronary artery disease.  Treatment Plan: The patient was initiated on Aspirin  a beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  and high-intensity statin along with his regular antihypertensive and antidiabetic medication. A consult with cardiology was provided for potential coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) due to the extent of his coronary artery disease.   Patient Education:  We counseled the patient regarding the importance of dietary modification  weight loss  increased physical activity  and optimal control of his blood pressure and diabetes.  He was advised to seek immediate medical attention if his chest pain persisted beyond 15 minutes despite rest and Nitroglycerin usage.   A follow-up consultation after two weeks was scheduled to reassess his symptoms and make a definitive decision regarding the revascularization strategy. His family was encouraged to participate in his lifestyle modifications for optimal outcomes.

Patient Details: Mr. Smith  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  retired lawyer  residing in Austin  Texas.   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presented with symptoms of intermittent chest discomfort  shortness of breath and fatigue  especially during exertion.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a medical history of type 2 diabetes diagnosed 10 years ago  hypertension for 15 years  and high cholesterol levels. He follows proper medication compliance for all conditions. Both his parents suffered from heart diseases in their late sixties. The patient is a former smoker  having quit 25 years ago and admits to an alcohol intake of around 15 units per week. Mr. Smith is overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 30. He has been resistant to lifestyle modifications and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Investigations: Routine blood tests were normal apart from elevated cholesterol and high blood glucose levels. An Electrocardiogram (ECG) revealed unspecific ST-T wave changes. Stress testing was positive for inducible myocardial ischemia.  Treatment and Progress: A coronary angiogram revealed significant narrowing of the left anterior descending artery. Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). He underwent successful Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI) with stent placement to the affected artery.   Post-procedure  medications including low-dose Aspirin  a statin  a beta-blocker  and an Angiotensin-Converting-Enzyme (ACE) inhibitor were continued. He was also prescribed rapid-acting Insulin before meals and intermediate-acting Insulin at bedtime for better control of his diabetes. Drug therapy for hypertension was adjusted accordingly.  Mr. Smith was encouraged to adopt a healthier lifestyle. This included a low-sodium and low-cholesterol diet  regular exercise under the supervision of a cardiopulmonary rehabilitation specialist  and weight management strategies. He was referred to a dietitian to help manage his weight and diabetes.   Follow-up:  Mr. Smith was scheduled for routine follow-ups every six months to monitor his symptoms  manage medications  and evaluate his commitment to lifestyle modifications. He also attends diabetes and hypertension clinics on a regular basis. The case was discussed in a multidisciplinary team meeting for comprehensive care.  Outcome: Patient demonstrated understanding of his condition and its management. He showed motivation towards improving his lifestyle and managing his weight. Regular monitoring will be done to track his progress and adjust treatment strategies if needed.   Conclusions: This case highlights the importance of early detection and comprehensive management of risk factors for coronary artery disease. It also emphasizes the need for lifestyle modification as an integral part of therapy and preventive strategies.

Patient Information:  The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant. He has been a lifelong resident of Colorado and a smoker for 50 years. He is married with three grown children. The patient was referred to our clinic because of persisting fatigue and exertional chest discomfort.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a relevant past medical history of hypertension (HTN)  diagnosed 10 years back and managed with beta-blockers (Metoprolol). He is also a diabetic (Type 2 DM) and on Metformin  diagnosed about 5 years before the present encounter. He had a partial left nephrectomy secondary to renal cell carcinoma 6 years ago  and he is currently free from cancer.  He has a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  as his father passed away at the age of 59 due to myocardial infarction.  Presenting Complaint & Diagnosis:  The patient presented to the clinic complaining of recurrent episodes of exertional chest discomfort that improved with rest and shortness of breath. A physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg and resting heart rate of 75 beats per minute.  Given his past history of smoking  family history of CAD and symptoms  a preliminary diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) was made. This was confirmed by performing an Electrocardiogram (ECG) which showed significant ST-segment depression. A Coronary Computed Tomography Angiography (CCTA) was then ordered which confirmed the presence of atherosclerotic plaques blocking 70% of his right coronary artery.  Plan:  Given his higher-than-average coronary artery calcium score  presence of symptoms and significant disease burden on CCTA  the patient was initially started on antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin and Clopidogrel)  Statin (Atorvastatin) and an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor (Lisinopril).  Because of the significant blockage in the right coronary artery  the patient was recommended for Percutaneous Coronary Intervention (PCI)  and the decision was made to place a drug-eluting stent (DES) in the right coronary artery.  Discussion:  This case highlights the importance of considering CAD as a possible diagnosis in older adults exhibiting possible angina symptoms  particularly in individuals with a history of smoking  diabetes  hypertension  and a family history of premature CAD. Early detection and management of CAD can significantly increase the quality of life and longevity in patients. The eventual management plan depends on the severity of stenosis and symptoms  among other factors.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease Case Report in 58-Year-Old Male with History of Hypertension  Patient Information: Mr. Jensen  a 58-year-old Caucasian male was presented at our cardiology clinic. He resides in Phoenix  Arizona  and works as an engineer. He has a positive familial medical history of coronary artery disease (CAD). His father died suddenly from a heart condition at the age of 62.  Medical History: Mr. Jensen was diagnosed with hypertension ten years ago but has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medication for the last five years. He has a 30-year history of smoking one pack of cigarettes daily but has quit smoking just one year ago. Additionally  he has unhealthy lifestyle behaviors  including physical inactivity and high-fat food consumption leading to obesity (BMI – 32kg/m2). He denies alcohol abuse or any psychoactive substance use. He has no history of diabetes  high cholesterol levels  or any other chronic diseases.  Presenting Complaints: The patient complained of persistent chest pain for the past month  more severe during physical effort and somewhat relieved by rest. The pain was retrosternal  of pressing character and occasionally radiating to the left shoulder. Along with chest pain  he also reported episodes of shortness of breath following strenuous activity.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  he appeared anxious but not acutely distressed. His weight was 240lbs (108.8 kg) and height 5’9” (175 cm). Vital signs were blood pressure 160/90mmHg  pulse rate 78 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 per minute  and body temperature 98.6 F. The cardiovascular system examination revealed a regular rhythm.  Diagnostic Assessment: Electrocardiogram showed T-wave inversion in the inferior leads suggesting ischemia. The lipid profile showed elevated LDL cholesterol (160 mg/dL). Further investigations by coronary angiography revealed a significant 70% obstruction in the right coronary artery.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received medicine for acute pain management and was immediately started on aspirin  statin  and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. A beta-blocker was added to control his hypertension. The patient underwent successful angioplasty with stent placement in the right coronary artery. Mr. Jensen was also referred to a dietitian for nutrition counseling and was encouraged to enroll in a cardiac rehabilitation program.  Follow-up and outcomes: Since the intervention  Mr. Jensen has reported major relief from the chest pain. Control of his hypertension has improved with medication compliance. He quit smoking and started incorporating physical activity into his daily regimen. Furthermore  he has made significant dietary changes in line with his dietitian’s advice and has lost 10 lbs during a 3-month follow-up.  Patient Perspective: Mr. Jensen is thankful for the medical intervention and has expressed a strong desire to implement lifestyle changes to improve his overall health and prevent further complications from his heart condition.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for this case report.  Conclusion: This case report emphasizes the importance of medication compliance and lifestyle modifications in managing chronic conditions like hypertension and coronary artery disease. It is vital to offer comprehensive cardiovascular care including medical  dietary  and lifestyle interventions for patients with CAD.

Case Report  Patient Information:   The patient is a 68-year old Caucasian male named Mr. A. He is a retired school teacher living with his wife in a suburban area. He is non-smoker and does not consume alcohol. However  he has a sedentary lifestyle with a history of unhealthy dietary habits. Mr. A. stands 5'8"" tall and weighs 220 lbs  indicating obesity (BMI: 33.5kg/m2). He has been treated for hypertension with medications over the last ten years and was diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. His family history involves his father who died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. A. was referred to the hospital by his GP for consultation  following complaints of recurrent episodes of chest discomfort and shortness of breath  particularly with exertion  over the past two months. Pertinently  he noticed an increasing trend in the frequency and severity of these episodes. He has also mentioned occasional episodes of diaphoresis and left arm discomfort.   Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  his blood pressure was found to be 150/90 mmHg and heart rate of 88 beats per minute. His cardiovascular examination revealed no murmurs  gallops or rubs. His respiratory  abdominal  and neurological examinations were unremarkable. His blood glucose levels were poorly controlled  and lipid profile showed high LDL and low HDL levels.  Diagnostic Assessment:  The ECG suggested left ventricular hypertrophy and ruled out a current acute coronary event. A stress test indicated predictive of cardiac ischemia and subsequent angiography revealed severe three-vessel coronary artery disease.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Based on his medical history  clinical findings  and results of diagnostic assessments  Mr. A. was commenced on aspirin  a beta-blocker  a statin  and medication to manage his diabetes better. Lifestyle modifications were strongly emphasized  encompassing a diet plan  exercise regimen  weight reduction  and regular follow-ups for controlling diabetes and hypertension.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  Reassessment after two months showed that Mr. A. had lost some weight and reported fewer symptoms. His symptoms of chest discomfort and shortness of breath were better managed. Subsequent visits highlighted a need for enhanced diabetic control and better hypertension management.  Patient Perspective:  Mr. A. realized that he needed to take his health seriously and comply with the given medical and lifestyle advice to maintain his quality of life. He appreciated the efforts of the medical team and intended to continue with the prescribed treatment strategy.  Conclusion:   This case highlights the need for careful evaluation and management in patients with multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease. It emphasizes the importance of lifestyle changes alongside medicinal therapy to improve overall health outcomes.

Title: Coronary Artery Disease in a 67-year-old  Non-smoker Male with Controlled Diabetes Mellitus   Patient Information:  The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) who presented to the clinic with dull chest pain radiating to the left arm. The patient’s body mass index is 28 kg/m2  he is 5’9” tall and weighs 190lbs. The patient does not smoke  drink alcohol or consume caffeine. He is married and recently retired from his job as a bank executive.  Clinical Findings:  The patient complained of intermittent chest discomfort  mostly during physical exertion  which generally subsides at rest. He reported the chest pain to be center-located  pressing  and radiating to his left arm and jaw. The patient mentions that the discomfort worsened over the past two weeks. He also noted shortness of breath  weakness  and dizziness.  Past Medical History:  The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 15 years back  which he manages with a controlled diet and medication (Metformin  500 mg twice daily). The patient also experienced hypertension for which he has been stable on Lisinopril  20 mg daily  for a decade. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on Atorvastatin (20 mg per day) for 5 years. There is no known history of heart disease in his immediate family. The patient is not allergic to any medications.  Diagnosis:  On physical examination  the patient appeared anxious but vital signs were stable. EKG revealed ST-depression and T-wave inversions suggestive of myocardial ischemia. Cardiac troponin levels were within normal limits. Echo revealed a reduced ejection fraction (45%). Coronary Angiography confirmed significant stenosis in the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and circumflex artery  thus  CAD diagnosis.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Considering significant LAD stenosis  percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) was recommended. A Drug-Eluting Stent (DES) was successfully deployed in the LAD. Post-PCI  dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin and clopidogrel) along with statin therapy was initiated as secondary prevention. The patient was also advised for cardiac rehabilitation and regular follow-ups.  Follow Up:  One month after the intervention  the patient reported feeling significantly better with no episodes of chest pain  breathlessness  or dizziness. Rehabilitation is in progress and medication adherence is confirmed.   Prognosis:  Coronary artery disease is a lifelong condition. However  with the patient’s commitment to medication  lifestyle modifications like a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  stress management  and regular follow-up  the prognosis is expected to be favorable.

Patient Information: A 68-year-old Asian male.  Chief Complaint: Chest discomfort during physical activity.  History of Present Illness: Patient presented with recurring episodes of chest discomfort while performing physical activities such as climbing stairs or lifting heavy objects. Occurrences have increased in frequency over the last six months. The discomfort is typically relieved by rest or nitroglycerin.  Past Medical History: The patient has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  controlled with oral medication  and hypertension  managed by a combination of diet and antihypertensive medication. He quit smoking 15 years ago following a 30-year history of heavy smoking but continues to consume alcohol socially. The patient underwent an appendectomy at age 24 but reports no other major surgery or significant injuries. He denies any history of myocardial infarction or stroke. He is allergic to penicillin.  Family History: His father died at 70 from a myocardial infarction. His mother  age 89  is still living and has hypertension. One of his three brothers has coronary artery disease and underwent a bypass operation at age 65. No other significant family history was reported.  Physical Exam: The patient is a well-appearing male in no apparent distress. Vital signs are stable; BP 140/85 mmHg  Pulse 75 bpm  RR 16 breaths per minute  Temp 37°C. Cardiac exam showed normal rate and rhythm  no murmurs  rubs or gallops. No jugular venous distention. Lungs were clear to auscultation. The remainder of the exam was unremarkable.  Lab Results: Lipid panel revealed elevated LDL cholesterol (164 mg/dL) and total cholesterol (237 mg/dL)  with normal triglycerides. Fasting glucose was slightly elevated at 125 mg/dL. Hemoglobin A1c was 7.2%. Complete blood count  liver panel  and kidney function tests were within normal limits.  Diagnostic Tests: An exercise stress test was performed and demonstrated ST-segment depression in leads V4-V6. Subsequently  a coronary angiogram was recommended and completed  which showed a 70% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery.  Treatment and Follow-up: The patient underwent successful percutaneous coronary intervention with stent placement in the left anterior descending artery. He was started on dual antiplatelet therapy (aspirin plus clopidogrel) and a statin drug. He is also recommended to continue his antihypertensive meds and should further manage his diabetes with necessary lifestyle changes and medication. The patient has been enrolled in a cardiac rehabilitation program.  This case underlines the importance of recognizing the signs of coronary artery disease in patients with multiple risk factors  such as this individual with a history of smoking  diabetes  hypertension and a family history of heart disease. The early detection and aggressive therapeutic intervention likely improved this patient's prognosis.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Demographic Information: Patient is a 66-year-old African American male with a BMI of 30.6  presenting as overweight. He has a history of light smoking during his mid-twenties to thirties  but has been smoke-free for over three decades. He's retired with a previous occupation as a career electrician and is a widower with three adult children.   Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His medications include Hydrochlorothiazide and Metformin. Other medical records reveal that his hypertension has been well controlled  with his last recorded blood pressure at 128/82 mmHg. However  he has demonstrated poor glycemic control with an Hba1c of 8.4% three months prior.   Presenting Issue: The patient has been exhibiting symptoms of shortness of breath and unexplained fatigue for two months  primarily upon exertion. Recently  he has also complained of chest discomfort and tightness  especially under stress. Physical exam is largely unremarkable  with the exception of a high BMI.  Further diagnostic tests were requested  including complete blood count (CBC)  lipid profile  and ECG. CBC was normal  but the lipid profile revealed elevated LDL cholesterol levels. The ECG indicated ST-segment depression consistent with ischemia  which warranted immediate attention.   Diagnosis: This male patient with comorbidities of hypertension and diabetes  presenting symptoms of acceleration angina was diagnosed with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). Given his age  lifestyle habits  and the presence of multiple risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and a high LDL cholesterol level (found in the lipid profile)  the diagnosis was fairly straightforward.   Management: The patient was started on an ACE inhibitor  a beta blocker  dual antiplatelet therapy  a statin for his high LDL cholesterol  and sublingual nitroglycerin as needed to manage angina symptoms. Lifestyle changes  including a low-sodium and low-saturated-fat diet  increased physical activity  and regular monitoring of blood glucose levels  were also discussed and recommended. Despite his age  the patient is an ideal candidate for potential angioplasty or bypass surgery due to his symptomatic CAD  which will be evaluated further by a specialist.   The patient will be followed closely with appointments scheduled to assess his nutritional and physical progress  monitor symptoms  side-effects of new medications and any improvements in clinical measures such as blood pressure and lipid levels.   This case emphasizes the importance of early identification and treatment of modifiable risk factors (like hypertension and high LDL cholesterol levels) to prevent coronary-artery disease in vulnerable populations–such as elder adults with multiple comorbid conditions.

Case Report: Patient With Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  The patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith who is a retired engineer. He is a long-term resident of New York  NY.  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith presented with an episode of acute chest pain associated with shortness of breath that lasted for approximately an hour. The chest pain was central  pressure-like  and non-radiating. He has had intermittent episodes of similar  although less severe  chest pain over the past month.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: The patient has a ten-year history of hypertension  controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg/day).   2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Mr. Smith was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus eighteen years ago  which he controls with Metformin (1500mg per day) and dietary modifications.   3. Smoking: Patient admits to a 40-year smoking history of a pack of cigarettes a day  he quit smoking ten years ago.  4. Family History: His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and his mother has a history of hypertension.  Clinical Examination:  On inspection  the patient appeared distressed. Vital signs were notable for blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  heart rate of 90 beats per minute. Auscultation of the heart revealed muffled heart sounds without any audible murmurs. The lungs were clear to auscultation bilaterally. The abdomen was non-tender without any organomegaly. Peripheral pulses were palpable in all four limbs.  Investigations:  An electrocardiogram (ECG) showed ST-segment elevation in leads indicating an acute anterolateral myocardial infarction. Mr. Smith's lab investigations were notable for elevated cardiac enzymes.   Hospital Course & Treatment:  Mr. Smith was diagnosed with acute ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) secondary to presumed coronary artery disease.
