No history of severe chest trauma or surgery  The above facts suggest that this patient could have coronary artery disease (CAD)  with symptoms being potentially due to the physical activity-related demand-supply mismatch of oxygen in the heart. Further evaluation via diagnostic tests like electrocardiogram (ECG)  exercise stress testing  and potential coronary angiography may be necessary for diagnosis confirmation.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 65-year-old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired office worker  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension diagnosed about 10 years ago. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago  poor compliance with medication. 3. Past smoker: 30-pack-years; quit smoking 4 years ago 4. Family history of heart disease: Father died of myocardial infarction at age 70.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson presents to the clinic with a three-week history of recurrent chest pain. He describes the pain as a heavy crushing sensation that usually occurs with moderate exertion  such as while brisk walking up a slope or carrying groceries  typically relieved with rest.  He noted an increase in the frequency of these episodes showing a trend: the same level of exertion now induces chest pain that he could previously perform without symptoms. The severity of pain during these episodes has remained stable.  Mr. Johnson also reports shortness of breath following the chest pain episodes and occasionally at rest. He denies any palpitations  syncopal episodes  or swelling of legs.  Mr. Johnson reports feelings of light-headedness and fatigue in the recent few weeks. He also mentions a few restless nights due to difficulty in getting comfortable  needing multiple pillows to sleep.  He denies any previous episodes of similar chest pain or any similar previous hospital admissions.   Through this case  medical students should learn about the classic symptoms of stable angina pectoris caused by narrowing of the coronary arteries due to atherosclerosis (Coronary Artery Disease/CAD). Being able to recognize these signs and symptoms is crucial for early diagnosis and treatment  reducing the risk of a more serious condition such as myocardial infarction (heart attack).

Patient Information:  Name: John Doe Age: 58 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Accountant Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed 4 years ago - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 2 years ago - Childhood asthma - Sedentary lifestyle - Heavy smoker for 30 years  quit 5 years ago - Family history of heart disease (Father died of myocardial infarction at age 60)  Presenting Complaints: John Doe presents with:  - Chest pain  described as a heaviness situated in the center of the chest  which has been ongoing for the last two hours.  - Pain radiates to the left arm and jaw. - Shortness of breath increasing over the last month  exacerbated recently - Fatigue and weakness  Discussant: John's clinical presentation aligns with angina or myocardial ischemia  likely as a result of coronary artery disease. Given his hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  heavy smoking history  and familial risk  he is at high risk for this disease. This case study hence serves to educate about the risk factors  manifestations  and potential complications of coronary artery disease.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics  Name: Mr. X Age: 65  Sex: Male Occupation: Retired accountant Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History Cardiovascular: No history of heart disease.  However  patient has previously exhibited borderline hypertension (blood pressure usually around 140/90 mmHg) under stress. Endocrine: Type II diabetes  well-controlled with oral hypoglycemics. Others: Mild osteoarthritis in both knees  Disturbance in lipid metabolism (high LDL levels  low HDL levels).  Family History Father and a paternal uncle both had myocardial infarctions in their late sixties.  Current Medications 1. Metformin 500mg twice a day orally (for diabetes) 2. Atorvastatin 20mg at bedtime (for high LDL levels) 3. Aspirin 81mg once a day (as a preventive measure) 4. Multivitamin supplements  Key Complaints Mr. X presents to the clinic with complaints of discomfort in the center of his chest. The discomfort feels like a pressure  squeezing or fullness. It has been coming and going for the last month  lasting a few minutes each time. Activity seems to precipitate the discomfort  and rest relieves it. Over the last week  he has also been feeling unusually fatigued. He denies any associated symptoms such as palpitations  sweating  nausea  or shortness of breath.   Lifestyle  Smoking: Has a 20 pack-year history of smoking. He quit 5 years ago. Drinking: Drinks socially  less than a standard drink a week. Physical Activity: Engages in brief walks around the neighborhood.  This case showcases the common presentation  risk factors and comorbidities associated with coronary artery disease. The complaint of chest discomfort that is both exertional and relieved with rest  in addition to his health and family history  creates a high index of suspicion for coronary artery disease.

Subject: Training Case - Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  Mr. Jones is a 58-year-old Caucasian male  working as an insurance broker  lives with his wife in a suburban setting. He is a former smoker (quit 15 years ago)  drinks alcohol moderately (2-3 times a week)  and lives a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to the nature of his work.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension diagnosed at age 50  for which he takes Lisinopril (ACE inhibitor). He has a family history of coronary artery disease as his father had his first heart attack at 60 years of age. He is also a type 2 diabetic  managed via Metformin and lifestyle modification for the past 5 years. Mr. Jones is overweight (BMI 31) and has dyslipidemia controlled with statins.   Key Complaints: Mr. Jones presents with recurring discomfort in the center of his chest that usually begins with intense physical effort and has been increasing in frequency and severity over the past six months. He describes it as feeling ‘tight  like a heavy band around the chest.’ The discomfort sometimes radiates towards his left arm. These episodes usually last about 10 minutes  and they resolve with rest.   Over the past week  he has two incidents of the same chest discomfort when he was at rest. The most recent episode occurred last night and was more intense  lasting about 30 minutes. Moreover  he mentioned becoming increasingly fatigued and experiencing shortness of breath during moderate physical exertion  such as during house chores  which was unusual for him. No related symptoms such as palpitations  sweating  or nausea were registered.   Based on the above clinical presentation  Mr. Jones may be suffering from coronary artery disease (CAD). The key features reinforcing this impression include age  gender  lifestyle  family history of CAD  and typical symptoms. His chest discomfort is characteristic of angina pectoris  which is a common symptom of CAD. In addition  his multiple risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  obesity  and a sedentary lifestyle) increase the likelihood of CAD. Further diagnostic confirmation is needed.  Assessment and Plan: Workup and Management would include a thorough physical examination  an EKG  lipid profile  stress test  echocardiogram  and possibly a coronary angiography if needed. If CAD is confirmed  the management would be oriented towards modification of the risk factors  medical therapy  and maybe coronary revascularization.

Patient Information: - Name: Mr. John Doe - Age: 50 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Accountant - Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: - Smoking history: 20 pack-years - Family history: Father died of myocardial infarction at 55  mother diagnosed with hypertension - Hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago - History of Dyslipidemia - No history of Diabetes  Stroke  or other cardiovascular diseases  Reported Key Complaints: - Chief complaints of intermittent chest pain for the past 2 months - Chest pain often occurs during exertion and relieved with rest - Has been feeling stressed and overwhelmed at work lately - Recently experiencing shortness of breath after mild physical activity like climbing stairs  which was not the case earlier - Other associated symptoms: Dizziness and cold sweats - No reported symptoms of Nausea  vomiting  or palpitations - Usually comfortable at rest with no complaints of nocturnal chest pain or shortness of breath  The above case is designed to present a typical patient with critical risk factors who is likely showing symptoms of Coronary Artery Disease. Various factors such as age  family history  smoking  and a history of hypertension  dyslipidemia along with typical symptoms like chest pain and shortness of breath should prompt the students to consider CAD. The case also includes aspects of differential diagnosis  for instance  ruling out gastrointestinal  pulmonary  or musculoskeletal causes of the chest pain.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. James Martin (Fictitious) Age: 58 years  Gender: Male Occupation: Works as an accountant in a local firm Location: Lives in a suburban neighborhood Marital Status: Married Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History:  Mr. Martin has a history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus which he has managed for about ten years now. His only other significant medical history involves hypertension  diagnosed about five years ago. He has occasional episodes of dyslipidemia as well.  Current Medications:  1. Metformin 1000mg twice a day for his diabetes id. 2. Lisinopril 10mg once daily for hypertension. 3. Atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia.  Family History:  His father had a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 60  and his mother has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His older brother  aged 63  has a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and had angioplasty two years back.  Social History:   Mr. Martin is a former smoker  though he quit 15 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially  perhaps two to three times a month. Limited physical activity due to work hours.  Present Complaints:  Mr. Martin came to the clinic with complaints of recurrent chest pain that had been bothering him for the past few weeks. The pain  often located on the left side of his chest  felt like tightening or squeezing in nature and would typically last for a few minutes. He noticed this pain especially occurs during evening walks post-dinner or during stressful situations at work. He also reported shortness of breath on exertion and recent episodes of fatigue.  Upon investigation  you want to be considering coronary artery disease in your differential diagnosis based on age  personal and family history. This case allows students to understand the presentation  risk factors  and management of CAD.   Outcome:  Students will need to decide on the appropriate next steps  including diagnostic tests (such as an electrocardiogram and potentially an exercise stress test or other cardiovascular imaging)  treatment plans  and lifestyle education to help Mr. Martin manage his symptoms and control risk factors.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Richard Lee Age/Sex: 62-year-old male  Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired engineer Living situation: Living with a wife  one dog  non-smoker  occasional alcohol drinker  Past Medical History: - History of hypertension controlled with medication (Lisinopril) - High cholesterol managed with lifestyle modification and Statin therapy (Rosuvastatin) - Pre-diabetic  managed diet and exercise - No known allergies  Presenting Complaints: 1. Mid-sternal chest discomfort  described as pressure-like sensation lingering for 30-40 minutes. The pain seemed to radiate to the left arm and was associated with shortness of breath. 2. Profuse sweating during the episode. 3. The pain seemed to get worse with physical activity (gardening)  which he usually enjoys. 4. Two similar episodes over the past week  each lasting about 10 minutes and resolved by rest. 5. No associated nausea  vomiting  heart palpitations  or dizziness. 6. No previous history of similar chest pain.   Additional notes: Given the nature of the symptoms  age  gender  medical history  and risk factors (hypertension  high cholesterol  and pre-diabetes)  this case will lean toward the diagnosis and management of coronary artery disease (CAD) which might be presenting as stable angina or possibly unstable angina given the increasing frequency and duration of episodes.  This case is designed to teach students about the typical presentation  differential diagnosis  and management of coronary artery disease. It should prompt discussion about the importance of early recognition and management of CAD in preventing serious complications such as myocardial infarction and sudden cardiac death. Additionally  the case hones in on the lifestyle factors  including diet and physical activity.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe  Age: 68  Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Civil Engineer  Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:   The patient has been diagnosed with Type II Diabetes Mellitus since the age of 50 which is currently under moderate control. Other medical history includes hyperlipidemia and hypertension for the past 10 years. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history  having quit 8 years ago. He reports occasional alcohol consumption but no illicit drug use.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe came into the ER complaining of constant  deep  and pressing chest discomfort over the past few days. The pain seems to radiate to his left shoulder and down the arm  becoming more intense while walking and improving while at rest. He also reported multiple episodes of shortness of breath  sweating  and lightheadedness. There have been no episodes of fainting or palpitations. Because of his increasing discomfort  his wife called the ambulance.  Medications:  Mr. Doe's home medications include metformin 1000mg twice daily  lisinopril 40 mg once daily and atorvastatin 80 mg once daily. He reports adherence to these medications.  Family History:  His father had a history of CAD and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at the age of 63. His mother lived into her 80s and had cirrhosis of the liver. He has two siblings  one of whom has been diagnosed with CAD and the other with hypertension.  Social History:  He lives with his wife and enjoys gardening. He is a former smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Review of Systems:  Cardiovascular: positive for chest pain  shortness of breath Endocrine: positive for Type II Diabetes Psychiatric: negative for depression or anxiety Respiratory: negative for cough or wheezing Gastrointestinal: negative for nausea  vomiting  diarrhea or constipation Neurological: negative for headache  dizziness or seizures  Musculoskeletal: negative for joint pain or swelling Integumentary (Skin): negative for rashes or itching Hematologic/Lymphatic: negative for easy bruising or bleeding Allergic/Immunologic: negative for allergies or drug reactions.  This case presentation has been designed to provide a brief overview of a typical presentation of a patient with likely coronary artery disease. Further examination  investigation  and management should  however  be based on the most current and relevant evidence and guidelines.

Patient Information: Mr. Anthony Robbins  a 65-year-old African-American male.  Presented Complaints: Mr. Robbins presents with a progressive history of chest pain  particularly when exerting himself. The pains are described as heavy and are located centrally  often radiating to his left arm. These episodes last from 5 to 10 minutes and are relieved by rest. He also reports instances of breathlessness following minimal exertion over the past two months.  Medical History: Both of Robbins' parents had heart conditions in their late 60s  his father having passed away from a heart attack. Himself  he has been diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago - under control with the help of Amlodipine. He was also diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago  managing it through Metformin. He has an unhealthy relationship with food  with a BMI of 30. He also has a 30-pack-year history of smoking but quit around the same time he was diagnosed with diabetes.  Day-to-Day Habities: He lives alone  has retired  and maintains an inactive lifestyle. He eats foods high in saturated fats and low in fruits and vegetables  doesn't exercise since he retired from his job.  Medication: He regularly takes Amlodipine 5mg daily for his hypertension and Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes.  Allergies: The patient has no known drug allergies.  This case provides a prototypical presentation of a patient at high risk of coronary artery disease (CAD)  given his demographics  clinical presentation  and medical history (i.e.  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  high-fat diet  and strong family history of CAD). Consequently  the signs and symptoms he is experiencing (i.e.  exertional angina and breathlessness) could suggest the development of CAD.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Anderson  a retired banker.  Past Medical History: Mr. Anderson has been a smoker for the past 35 years and has a sedentary lifestyle with a history of poor dietary habits (high fat  high cholesterol). His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and type 2 diabetes 5 years ago  both of which have been poorly controlled with lifestyle modifications and medications. He does not have a history of prior surgeries.  Key Complaints: Mr. Anderson complains of intermittent chest pain for the last 3 months that is gradually becoming more frequent. The pain often radiates to his left arm and is usually accompanied by shortness of breath  mild palpitations  and nausea. He usually experiences these symptoms upon physical exertion like climbing stairs or walking a couple of blocks  but they tend to resolve with rest.   He also noticed an increase in fatigue over the past few weeks and occasional episodes of lightheadedness  but he hasn't lost consciousness. He reported no changes in bowel or urinary habits. The symptoms are causing him a deal of anxiety and interfering with his daily activities.  Please note: To be considered complete  an actual case study should also include a physical examination  diagnostic tests  and a management plan done by healthcare providers. Always consult with a healthcare professional in case of health concerns.

Patient Case Report  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. John Smith - Age: 62 years old - Sex: Male - Occupation: Construction worker - Race: Caucasian - Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of mild hypertension for which he takes Atenolol 25 mg once daily  occasional high cholesterol but not on any medication currently  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  although he quit smoking five years ago.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith visited the clinic complaining of growing discomfort in the center of his chest. He describes the feeling akin to having a heavy object placed upon his chest. The pain seems to worsen upon physical exertion  for instance when lifting heavy objects at work or when going up a flight of stairs  and tends to fade during rest periods.   The discomfort episodes have grown more frequent over the past few weeks  manifesting 3 to 4 times a week  lasting about 5 minutes each time. Additionally  Mr. Smith reported a sense of fatigue and shortness of breath during these episodes.   No associated symptoms were reported  such as nausea  vomiting  palpitations  or syncope. Mr. Smith also denied any pain radiation to arms  neck  jaw  back  or abdomen. He did not report any symptoms during sleep or at specific times of the day.   In light of Mr. Smith’s age  risk factors  profession involving manual labor  and presentation of angina-like symptoms  he should be assessed for coronary artery disease. His ailment's description and characteristic relief of pain at rest align with stable angina associated with Coronary Artery Disease (CAD).

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Information:   Mr. George Smith  a 63-year-old male  comes to the emergency department. He is a Caucasian retired school teacher  married with two children and three grandchildren.  Medical History:   His past medical history reveals that he has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years and type 2 diabetes for the last 10 years. Both conditions have been reasonably well controlled with medication. His father died from a heart attack at the age of 67 and his older brother underwent angioplasty at age 60. Mr. Smith has been a smoker for 40 years and admits to not exercising regularly  having a high-fat diet  and not managing his stress well despite his retirement.  Primary Complaints:   Mr. Smith complains of experiencing severe  crushing chest pain  which he describes as being similar to a heavy weight on his chest. The pain started suddenly while he was shoveling snow. He has also been experiencing shortness of breath  profuse sweating  nausea  and lightheadedness. Symptoms got progressively worse over the last two hours. He also reports feeling pain radiating down both arms and admits to having milder  similar pains over the past few weeks  generally associated with physical exertion and stress  which went away with rest.  On the basis of his risk factors (sex  age  family history  smoking  hypertension  diabetes  inactivity  diet  and stress)  symptoms  and their onset  which is typical of coronary artery disease  Mr. Smith requires immediate attention and further diagnostic measures. The case should prompt medical students to consider immediate interventions and long-term treatments  including ways to hep Mr. Smith address his risk factors.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. John Davis  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  married with 2 children  non-smoker  social drinker  living in suburban Maryland.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of hypertension for 20 years  mildly controlled with medication (Lisinopril 10mg per day)  and Type 2 diabetes for about 10 years managed with Metformin (500mg twice daily). He admits to a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in processed foods. His mother had a stroke at age 75 and his father died of myocardial infarction at age 67. No previous surgical history is noted.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Davis presents to the clinic with concerning symptoms that have progressively worsened over the past few weeks. He reports having intermittent chest discomfort that he describes as a ""tight feeling""  generally occurring on exertion (especially after climbing stairs or walking his dog). The discomfort usually subsides when he rests. He also mentions occasional shortness of breath and increased fatigue. He noticed these symptoms are progressively getting worse and now also appear sometimes while he is at rest.   Note: This is just a brief history and presentation of the patient's complaints. It should be explored further with a detailed physical examination  investigations (Blood tests  EKG  Chest X-ray  Stress Test  etc.)  proper diagnosis  and a treatment plan.

Case Report:  Patient Profile: Patient's Initials: J.S  Sex: Male Age: 65 Race/ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with primary complaints of recurrent chest pain radiating to the left arm and associated with shortness of breath. He reported that these episodes typically last for about 15-20 minutes and are often induced by physical exertion or emotional stress. The patient also complained of sweating excessively during these episodes.   Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes for the past ten years and is on metformin. He was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago and has been on an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor. In addition to this  he used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily for about 30 years but quit 5 years ago. He consumes alcohol occasionally and admits to not following a consistent exercise regimen. He denies any history of allergies.   Family History: The patient's father passed away at age 70 due to MI. His mother is 88 years old and has hypertension. He has two older brothers  one of which had a stroke at age 63.  Review of Systems: Cardiovascular system: Positive for chest pain and shortness of breath. Endocrine system: He complains of frequent urination and increased thirst  which he attributes to his diabetes. The rest of the review of systems is negative.  This case is designed to guide learning towards a diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease. Further diagnostic evaluation and management will be guided by the clinical course.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient's Demographics:  - Name: Mr. James Thompson - Age: 67 years - Sex: Male - Occupation: Retired Bank Manager - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Body Mass Index: 28 (overweight range)  Past Medical History:  - Diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  approximately controlled on Losartan. - Family history of cardiovascular disease (Father died from myocardial infarction at 72 years old  older brother underwent coronary bypass surgery at 68) - Non- smoker but had smoking history for about 10 years during his youth. - Mild Type 2 Diabetes  controlled on diet modification and Metformin. - Was advised a low cholesterol diet as his lipid profile report five years ago showed elevated LDL levels. - He has moderate alcohol intake (about two drinks per day). - His stress levels are usually high since his retirement due to financial reasons.   Key Complaints:  - The patient presented with intermittent chest pain of a month’s duration. He described his pain as 'crushing' in the center of his chest that sometimes radiates to his left arm and jaw. - The pain usually happens after climbing the stairs or walking around his apartment block. The resting or use of nitroglycerin usually relieves such episodes. - Mr. Thompson also mentioned experiencing episodes of shortness of breath on exertion in the last two weeks. - He reported a feeling of fatigue and mild lightheadedness during high-stress situations. - An episode of severe sweating accompanied his most recent chest pain.  This case report aims to give medical students a perspective on recognizing classic angina symptoms. It will also encourage the contrivance of diagnostic workup for coronary artery disease and development of a management plan including lifestyle modifications in a patient with risk factors.

Patient Information:  Gender: Male Age: 65 Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Police Officer  Medical History:  The patient has been hypertensive for the last 10 years and on medication for the same. He has been a smoker for the past 30 years but quit five years ago. He has a family history of heart disease  his father having died from a heart attack at the age of 57. He has been moderately active with irregular exercise patterns. He has a history of hyperlipidemia. He has had occasional complaints of heartburn  which he has usually attributed to spicy food.  Key Complaints:  1. Chest pain: The patient describes a sensation of pressure and tightness in the center of his chest  which sometimes radiates to the arm. This pain is often precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest. The episodes of chest pain have become more frequent and more severe over the past month.     2. Shortness of breath: He has been experiencing episodic breathlessness  especially after walking for 10-15 minutes or climbing stairs. Recently  he also noticed this symptom occurring even during rest.  3. Fatigue: The patient reported feeling unusually tired after doing routine daily activities for the last two weeks. He claimed this was a recent change and felt tired more quickly than before.  4. Nausea and Indigestion: He reported episodes of indigestion and a nauseous feeling  often correlating with the episodes of chest pain.  These symptoms suggest that the patient has coronary artery disease (CAD)  and the worsening symptoms may indicate the progression towards unstable angina or myocardial infarction. Further diagnostic testing including EKG  stress test  and angiogram may be required to confirm the diagnosis and plan the treatment.

Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: Name: John Smith Demographics: 58-year-old African American male.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed at age 45 controlled with medication (lisinopril) - Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed at age 53 controlled with medication (metformin) - 30 pack-years smoking history; quit smoking 2 years ago - Father suffered a myocardial infarction aged 62  Key complaints: Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with a 3-month history of intermittent chest tightness and shortness of breath  especially while walking up stairs or doing any strenuous work around the house. He denies experiencing these symptoms at rest. However  over the past week  he has experienced an increase in the frequency and intensity of these episodes.   He also reports being increasingly fatigued in the past few weeks. He indicates he gets ""more winded than usual"" walking on flat surfaces  something that has never happened before. He denies having symptoms of dizziness  palpitations  or syncope. He has slight unease in the middle of the chest occasionally but no sharp or stabbing pains. His appetite and weight have remained stable.   He has not sought medical advice for these symptoms previously and has no recent medical investigations done. He comes to the hospital on the insistence of his wife who is worried about his symptoms given his family history.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Eric Smith Age: 65 years  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Bank Manager  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension for the past 20 years - managed with Lisinopril. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 10 years ago - controlled by Metformin. 3. History of smoking - quit 5 years ago. 4. No known allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with: 1. Chest pain: He described it as a crushing type of pain in the middle of his chest. 2. Shortness of Breath: Episodes of gasping for breath  especially when walking short distances or climbing stairs. 3. Fatigue: Experienced constant tiredness for the past few months. 4. Dizziness: Reported feeling lightheaded and faint occasionally  especially during episodes of chest pain. 5. Nausea: Occasional bouts of nausea.  The symptoms intensified over the last week  with the pain in his chest occurring even at rest  lasting for more than 15 minutes at a time.  Additional Notes:  Mr. Smith has a family history of coronary artery disease: his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 58. He is obese with a BMI of 30. Despite his diabetes and hypertension  Mr. Smith's diet control and exercise are suboptimal. He lives alone since his wife passed away 5 years ago.  This case presents several important risk factors associated with coronary artery disease  including age  gender  hypertension  diabetes  personal smoking history  family history of CAD  and obesity. The patient's symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  fatigue  dizziness  and nausea also match the typical clinical presentation of CAD. It provides an opportunity for students to understand the condition and formulate appropriate investigation and management strategies.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information:  Name: John Smith  Age: 65 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired construction worker  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with a three-week history of intermittent chest pain  which he describes as a radiating pressure towards his left arm. He also reports that the pain seems to worsen with physical exertion  such as walking  but does seem to lessen somewhat with rest. He has also experienced breathlessness on occasion  specifically during episodes of chest pain.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension for which he has been prescribed Amlodipine 5mg daily. He is also a type 2 diabetic  controlled by dietary adjustments and oral hypoglycemic drugs (Metformin 1000mg twice daily). No known history of heart disease  though he does have a family history of cardiac issues – his father died of myocardial infarction at age 72. He has ceased smoking 5 years ago after a 30-year history of a pack-a-day smoking but continues to engage in moderate alcohol use.   Current Medications:  1. Amlodipine 5mg daily for hypertension management 2. Metformin 1000mg  twice daily for diabetes management   Upon assessment  he appeared tired and moderately distressed. His vitals revealed a blood pressure of 160/95 mm of Hg  a pulse rate of 88 beats per minute  regular rhythm  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  maintaining oxygen saturation of 96% in room air  and he is afebrile. Auscultation of chest was normal with no added sounds.  This case has been designed to introduce medical students to a common presentation of coronary artery disease. The discussion should focus on how the symptoms relate to the pathophysiology of the condition  and how lifestyle factors and comorbid conditions might contribute to this presentation.  Note for case discussion: This case is a good opportunity to talk about patient-centered care  taking into account the individual's lifestyle habits  socio-economic status  and needs  and how these factors might affect disease progression  management options  and patient outcomes. Potential problem-solving discussions might include determining the most appropriate diagnostic tests and management plan for this patient.

Patient Information ------------ Patient Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 60 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Ex-Salesman Insurance: Medicare  Presenting Complaints --------------- Mr. Doe reports experiencing intermittent chest pain over the past three months  usually occurring during physical activity like climbing stairs or lifting heavy items. The pain is often described as tight  squeezing  and heavy in nature  typically subsiding when he rests. Over the past week  he also noticed the pain starting earlier and with less exertion than before. Additionally  he has been feeling more fatigued than usual.  Medical History --------------- Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history which includes Type II diabetes mellitus (for which he takes Metformin)  hypertension (managed with a Calcium Channel Blocker - Amlodipine)  and hypercholesterolemia (maintained on Statins - Rosuvastatin). He has been a smoker for the past 40 years  with an average consumption of 15 cigarettes per day. He reported ceasing alcohol consumption 10 years ago. His father died of a myocardial infarction at 65  and his mother is a hypertensive and diabetic.  Physical Examination ------------------- Physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  a heart rate of 80 beats per minute  and a body mass index of 28. Standard auscultation is normal  with regular heart rate and rhythm without murmurs  rubs  or gallups.  Assessment ------------ Given the patient's age  sex  risk factors  presenting complaints  and physical examination results  there is a high suspicion for coronary artery disease (CAD)  which should be further investigated via appropriate diagnostic tests like electrocardiogram  exercise stress testing  or coronary angiogram.  Learning Objectives  ----------- - Understand the risk factors and clinical presentation of coronary artery disease. - Evaluate the relationship between diabetes  hypertension  and coronary artery disease.  - Use the case above to formulate differential diagnoses. - Determine relevant diagnostic tests based on clinical suspicion. - Discuss the management plan including both pharmacologic and lifestyle modifications.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics:   The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith. He is a retired high school physics teacher  has a height of 5'10''  and weights 210 lbs. He is a lifelong resident of New York City  living with his wife of 40 years in a small apartment. Mr. Smith is a nonsmoker and nonalcoholic but has a lethargic lifestyle rarely involving any physical exercise. His diet is described as ""variable"" with occasional high-fat fast food.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history including Type 2 diabetes diagnosed 8 years ago. His blood sugar levels are not always satisfactorily controlled. He also suffers from hypertension diagnosed 5 years ago  which he manages with prescribed medications. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia and his current lipid profile shows elevated levels despite him being on statins for 2 years. His mother had a heart attack in her late sixties and his father died due to stroke. Mr. Smith is non-compliant with his prescribed medication regimens and has admitted to occasionally skipping his diabetes and anti-hypertensive medications.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith presented to the clinic reporting persistent dull  heavy chest pain radiating to the left arm for the past few days. He described it as a feeling of ""having a weight on his chest"". He also reported shortness of breath  especially upon carrying out routine activities like household chores  and fatigue. He has experienced episodes of lightheadedness but denied any episodes of fainting  palpitations  orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He is also experiencing some anxiety due to his symptoms.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith is potentially a high-risk candidate for coronary artery disease  considering his consistent chest pains  complications due to diabetes  hypertension  dyslipidemia  family history  lifestyle  and non-adherence to drug regimen.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. John Wilson  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired schoolteacher who is currently living with his wife. He has been a non-smoker for 30 years  moderate alcohol consumer but leads a sedentary lifestyle due to his profession and hobby of reading and writing.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Wilson has been treated for hypertension for the past ten years and is currently taking medication for the same (amlodipine 10mg daily). He has a history of dyslipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus (well-controlled on metformin) for the past five years. There is a family history of premature heart disease; his father had a heart attack at age 58.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Wilson presented with a two-week history of intermittent chest pain  usually upon exertion  which was relieved with rest within 10 minutes. The pain  described as a squeezing or heavy pressure at the center of his chest  occasionally radiated towards his left arm. He also reported accompanying dyspnea on exertion and episodes of diaphoresis but denied any nocturnal chest pain  chest pain at rest  palpitations  or syncope. On one instance  he experienced severe chest pain  which lasted longer than usual but resolved on its own.  On examination  he was found to be overweight with a body mass index of 28 kg/m2. Cardiovascular examination reveals a blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. All other systemic examination findings were unremarkable.  The presenting complaints and history for Mr. Wilson suggest typical angina  possibly due to coronary artery disease  which needs to be further investigated.  Learning Objective: Understand the clinical presentation  risk factors  investigation  and management of coronary artery disease.

Patient Information:   Mr. Benjamin Anderson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired lawyer  non-smoker  and non-alcoholic  hailing from a semi-urban area.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Anderson has a pertinent history of Type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin for the past four years  and controlled hypertension on Lisinopril for the past six years. He also has a family history of heart disease – his father succumbed to a heart attack at age 70.  Key Chief Complaints:  Mr. Anderson presents to the clinic complaining of recurrent episodes of chest pain on exertion – usually climbing stairs or brisk walking for the past two months – which is relieved by rest; the episodes last about 10-15 minutes. He also reports feeling fatigued and experiencing shortness of breath more frequently  particularly over the last three weeks. Mr. Anderson mentioned that he had been dismissive about the symptoms earlier  attributing them to old age and general weakness.  Summary:  Mr. Anderson is a well-managed  hypertensive  and diabetic patient who has started to experience recurrent chest pain on exertion  shortness of breath  and fatigue. Given his age  cardiovascular risk factors - diabetes  hypertension  and family history of heart disease  and the classic description of his symptoms  a strong case for suspecting coronary artery disease needs to be considered.

Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. Ronald Thompson Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Accountant Smoker: Yes (40 years  1 pack a day) Alcohol: Social drinker (1-2 times per month) Family History: Father died from myocardial infarction at age 70  mother has hypertension.  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension (controlled with medication - Amlodipine 5mg daily) 2. Hyperlipidemia (on medication - Atorvastatin 10 mg daily) 3. Type 2 diabetes mellitus (controlled with Metformin 500mg twice daily) 4. Mild obesity with BMI of 30.5  Key Complaints:  Mr. Thompson was previously very active but has recently noticed increasing shortness of breath on exertion and intermittent episodes of chest tightness over the last six months. These symptoms have worsened over the past week. He notices the chest discomfort predominantly while walking his dog in the morning  especially in colder weather. He needs to stop and rest every few minutes when it happens. He denies experiencing the pain when at rest  and the discomfort resolved quickly on resting. The pain is centrally located in the chest and radiates to the left arm. There is associated nausea but no vomiting or diaphoresis. He also denies any episodes of dizziness  fainting  or palpitations.   This case  thus  presents a classic scenario of a patient with multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease (CAD) and stable angina symptoms  highlighting the exercise-induced  relieved-by-rest chest discomfort characteristic of angina pectoris. Through this case  the students will learn about taking a targeted history  identifying risk factors for CAD  understanding the clinical presentation  and initiating appropriate diagnostic workup and management plans.

Patient Details:    Mr. James  a 64-year-old Caucasian male  weighing about 220lbs  with a height of 5'9""   Past Medical History:   Mr. James has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus for which he takes Metformin and Lisinopril. He recently quit cigar smoking a year ago after smoking for almost 30 years. He cycles occasionally but confesses to a generally sedentary lifestyle and his diet  though not specifically unhealthy  does possess high quantities of red meat. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father passed away from acute myocardial infarction at 72.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. James has visited the office today due to a recurring discomfort in his middle to left side of the chest for the past three weeks. He describes it as a “tight and heavy pressure” that radiates to his left arm  occurring predominantly when he carries his groceries up a flight of two stairs to his apartment  and the discomfort subsides when he rests. He admitted to occasionally being short of breath during these episodes. He has experienced about 6 similar episodes  each lasting around 10 minutes. He has also been feeling unusually fatigued after mild physical exertion  which is a new symptom.  Analysis:  The training focus will be on recognizing the signs and symptoms of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD) and handling the initial evaluation and management of a patient with suspected angina pectoris  which might be an indication of CAD. The students should consider the significant risk factors such as age  diabetes  hypertension  smoking  physical inactivity  poor diet  and family history  through this case.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  65-year-old male  retired engineer  smoker for 40 years  BMI of 30. Lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood.   Past Medical History: Hypertension managed with medication  history of high cholesterol  on a statin for the past 10 years. His father suffered from a heart attack at the age of 70.  Key complaints: Mr. Doe has been experiencing episodes of chest discomfort over the past three months. The discomfort primarily occurs during physical activities like climbing stairs  mowing the lawn or carrying heavy items  but also sometimes during periods of stress. He describes the discomfort as a squeezing sensation or pressure behind the chest bone  sometimes radiating to the left arm and occasionally accompanied by feelings of indigestion. The discomfort usually subsides with rest and/or nitroglycerin  which was prescribed by his primary care physician.  Most Recent Episode: Mr. Doe’s most recent episode of chest discomfort occurred yesterday while he was doing yard work. The discomfort was more intense than usual and lasted beyond the usual few minutes  even with rest and nitroglycerin. His wife took him to the Emergency Room. Upon arrival  he was sweaty and pale but the pain had subsided.  Subsequent steps in the case study should include the student conducting a physical examination  interpreting the EKG  understanding laboratory tests such as cardiac enzymes  determining the diagnosis  and reviewing appropriate management strategies.

Patient Case:  Demographics: 62-year-old African-American male   Past Medical History: Hypertension  high cholesterol  type 2 diabetes mellitus. Ex-smoker who quit 15 years ago with a 20 pack-year smoking history. No known family history of coronary artery disease.  Chief complaint: The patient is presenting with a 2-week history of exertional chest discomfort  described as a ""heavy"" sensation  which lasts approximately 10 minutes before resolving completely. The discomfort is provoked with exercise and is relieved by rest. He also complained of experiencing shortness of breath while carrying out his regular activities which was unlike him.  Over those two weeks  the symptoms have increased in frequency and occurred recently while he was at rest. He also mentioned associated symptoms like light-headedness and sweating during these episodes. The patient denies experiencing palpitations  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  orthopnea  and lower limb swelling.   No incidence of frank chest pain  loss of consciousness  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or edema. His symptoms have severely limited his physical activities and continues to express concern over his dwindling ability to carry on with his regular work.

Patient Demographics: Mr. John  a 62-year-old African American male  a blue-collar worker  presents himself at the clinic. He lives with his wife and has two children who are both married and living separately. Along with English  the patient  hailing from the southern United States  speaks a bit of Spanish.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of high blood pressure  managed by medications (Lisinopril) for the past five years. He also has type 2 diabetes managed through Metformin and lifestyle changes for about ten years. He is a former smoker  having quit smoking ten years ago after a 30-year-long history of one pack a day. He admits to moderate alcohol consumption. There is also a history of premature heart disease in his family; his father had a heart attack at 55.  Key Complaints: Mr. John came to the clinic reporting increasing episodes of shortness of breath  occasionally accompanied by a persistent dull  uncomfortable chest pain radiating to his left arm for the past four weeks. The chest pain  according to him  typically comes on when is he is physically active  and eases within few minutes of rest. Recently  he even experienced one of these episodes of chest pain one early morning while at rest. This was associated with profuse sweating and he describes it as his most severe episode yet.   Summary: A 62-year-old African American male patient with a background history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and smoking  experiences exertional chest pain radiating to the left arm  and shortness of breath that has been progressively worsening over the last month  potentially indicative of coronary artery disease.

Patient Case: Mr. Richard Marks  Demographics: Age: 55 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Computer Systems Analyst Lifestyle: Sedentary  Medical History: • Hypertension  well-controlled with medication for the past 10 years • Hyperlipidemia • Obesity (BMI - 32) • Lifetime non-smoker • No history of illegal drug use or alcoholism • No previous surgeries • Both parents had coronary artery disease  Chief Complaints:  Presented in the clinic with central chest pain  rated 7/10 in severity  tight band-like sensation  accompanied by shortness of breath. Both complaints started while he was mowing the lawn. The pain radiated to his left arm. The patient also reported episodes of palpitations  unusual fatigue over the past week  and occasional dizzy spells.  Note: Students should focus on the identification of risk factors in the patient (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  family history) along with the classic symptoms of CAD (chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations). A thorough approach to differentials for chest pain (angina  heart attack  GERD  anxiety  and musculoskeletal pain) should be discussed. Appropriate investigations (ECGs  stress tests  echo) and management (life-style modifications  medication  angiography) should be explored as part of this case. Consider involving in debates on risk stratification and primary prevention strategies. Useful topics would be statins  aspirin  and lifestyle interventions.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Brown Age: 58 years  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired police officer Marital Status: Married Residence: Urban  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - diagnosed 8 years ago 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 6 years ago 3. Dyslipidemia - diagnosed 5 years ago 4. Previous smoker - quit 3 years ago after a smoking history of 30 years  Key Complaints: Mr. Brown presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of intermittent chest pain that has been occurring over the last six months. The pain is severe in intensity  located in the center of his chest  described as a pressure or squeezing sensation that often radiates to his left arm and neck. Pain episodes usually last for 2 to 5 minutes and are often triggered by exertion  like mowing the lawn or climbing stairs  but are relieved by rest. Moreover  he has experienced episodes of shortness of breath with minimal exertion and reported occasional episodes of dizziness and mild nausea during these episodes. He also acknowledged experiencing occasional night sweats.  These episodes have been increasing in frequency over the last month. He has also noticed that it takes less exertion to trigger the pain and the pain is progressively becoming intense. He denies any episodes of fainting  palpitations  ankle swelling  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He has not sought medical attention for these symptoms previously.  Both Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus have been relatively well controlled with medication (Metformin 1000mg twice daily and Lisinopril 20mg daily). His latest HbA1c is 6.8% and the latest BP measurement was 130/85mmHg. The patient is compliant with his medication and ongoing dietary and lifestyle modifications.  Conclusion: Given the patient's age  gender  past medical history including uncontrolled dyslipidemia  diabetic status  hypertensive status  previous smoking history and the presenting symptoms  there seems to be a clear clinical suspicion of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). In concordance with the appropriate guidelines  necessary investigations and management need to be planned for.

Patient Information:   Mr. Robert Brown  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  presents himself at the healthcare facility.  Medical History:   The patient reports a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both controlled with medication for the past 8 years. His father died of heart disease in his early sixties and his sister was just recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease. Mr. Brown has a 30- year history of smoking but quit 6 years ago. He admits to moderate daily alcohol consumption and a diet that largely includes high-fat meals. Regular physical activity is not a part of his routine lifestyle.  Chief Complaints:  For the past three weeks  Mr. Brown has been experiencing episodes of chest discomfort on exertion. This is often relieved by rest. He reports that these episodes are becoming more frequent  lasting longer  and even appear with less-intensive activities than before. He also experiences shortness of breath  fatigue  and dizziness. He denied any episodes of diaphoresis  nausea  or vomiting. He is becoming worried as he had to stop and rest four times while mowing his lawn recently due to chest discomfort.  Interpretation:  Given the patient history  exertional chest pain  diabetes  and a family history of heart disease  a strong suspicion of coronary artery disease should be considered. Physical examination  lab tests  electrocardiogram  chest X-ray  or other diagnostic tests like stress testing or angiogram might be carried out to confirm the diagnosis. Lifestyle modifications  medications  and possibly surgical interventions will be discussed based on the test results. In the meantime  routine activities that exert Mr. Brown should be avoided until clear diagnostic results are obtained.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. D  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired accountant  having a history of regular smoking and sedentary lifestyle. He lives with his wife and cats. No known drug or food allergies are reported.   Past Medical History:   The patient has a history of hypertension controlled with long-term medication (Losartan 100 mg/day). He was diagnosed with type II diabetes five years ago and takes Metformin (1000 mg twice a day). His BMI is 29.3  indicating obesity. Additionally  he encounters dyslipidemia for which he is prescribed Rosuvastatin (10mg/day).   Key Complaints:  Mr. D visited the clinic on a Tuesday afternoon complaining of recurrent chest discomfort that was intermittently present during the past 1 month but has recently increased in severity and frequency. The discomfort typically lasted 10-15 minutes and was associated with exertion or emotional stress. He described the pain as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest that sometimes radiates to his left arm. He informed that the pain usually relieved on taking rest.   He also reported feeling unusually fatigued with mild shortness of breath during simple daily activities such as walking from his car to the house. He mentioned experiencing episodes of dizziness and nausea over the past week. He hasn't yet experienced an episode of fainting  but the increase in symptoms started to worry him prompting the visit to the clinic.   This case aims to help medical students incorporate the patient's history  associated risk factors  and presenting symptoms to formulate a differential diagnosis. Their ultimate diagnosis should lead them down the path of suspecting coronary artery disease.

Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  63-year-old Caucasian male about 5'9"" tall  weighing approximately 215 pounds.  Past Medical History: - Hyperlipidemia diagnosed seven years ago  managed with Atorvastatin.  - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed four years ago  controlled with Metformin.  - Hypertension diagnosed five years ago  treated with Lisinopril.  - Ex-smoker  quit smoking approximately 20 years ago.  - Chronic lower back pain  managed with conservative management.  - Family history includes a father who had a myocardial infarction at age 62.   Key Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the clinic with a 3-week history of intermittent chest discomfort that has gradually become more frequent. The discomfort was usually experienced in the center of his chest  with a crushing sensation radiating to his left arm and sometimes to his jaw. The discomfort was typically associated with physical activities such as carrying groceries or climbing up the stairs and eased with rest within 10 minutes.   He also reported episodes of shortness of breath on moderate exertion and some episodes of feeling a sudden racing and irregular heartbeat. He reported noticing increasing fatigue over the past few weeks  having to stop to catch his breath while walking his dog  a task he previously performed without any difficulty.   He denied symptoms of lightheadedness  vertigo  fainting  or swelled ankles. He also had poor sleep due to frequent night-time urination and occasional nocturnal chest discomfort.  - John also noted an increased need for his Nitrostat (nitroglycerin tablet) over the last couple of weeks.  Current Medications:  - Atorvastatin 40mg daily  - Metformin 500mg twice daily  - Lisinopril 10mg daily  - Nitroglycerin 0.4mg PRN (as needed)  - Acetaminophen PRN for back pain  Social History:  The patient lives with his wife of 38 years  who is a retired nurse. He retired from his job as an accountant last year. He quit smoking 20 years ago and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has a sedentary lifestyle and admits to indulging in high carbohydrate and high fatty foods. He does not have any known drug allergies.

Case Title: Coronary Artery Disease - A Clinical Scenario   Patient Information: Mr. Robert Marsh  a 62-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: Mr. Marsh has a history of hypertension for 20 years  Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years  and hyperlipidemia for over a decade. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. He quit smoking approximately seven years ago but had a 30-pack year history prior to quitting. He also reports a family history of early heart disease  with his father having a myocardial infarction at age 45.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Marsh presented to the clinic complaining of intermittent chest discomfort  particularly on exertion  over the past two weeks. Discomfort seems to be relieved by rest. He also mentions feeling dizzy and short of breath during these episodes. He also complained of unfairly rapid fatigue while carrying out daily activity. There was no nausea or sweating.   Examination at the clinic showed elevated blood pressure of 160/90 and an irregular heartbeat. The rest of the physical examination including respiratory and other systemic examination was within normal limits.   This case presents an instance of suspected stable angina due to coronary artery disease  as evidenced by Mr. Marsh's risk factors such as age  gender  elevated blood pressure  type 2 diabetes  hyperlipidemia  and a strong family history. The presentations of chest discomfort on exertion and ease of pain on rest are defining features of stable angina  a manifestation of coronary artery disease.   Further investigations including an electrocardiogram (ECG)  stress test  and angiography can be done based on clinical judgment to confirm this diagnosis and decide on the line of treatment. It's instructional for medical students to recognize the symptoms of coronary artery disease and understand appropriate diagnostic and management strategies.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Information: Mr. Samuel Johnson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented to his primary care provider.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both of which are currently managed with medication. He also has a 35-year history of smoking  although he quit approximately ten years ago. Mr. Johnson has a family history of heart disease; his father experienced a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Johnson reports experiencing recent bouts of chest discomfort  particularly when engaging in physical activities such as climbing stairs or gardening. He describes the discomfort as a ""squeezing"" or ""tearing"" sensation in the center of his chest  occasionally radiating to his left arm. The discomfort typically subsides after a few minutes of rest. He also mentions feeling unusually fatigued recently  even with minimal exertion. In addition  he has noticed episodes of shortness of breath; these occur more frequently at night  often waking him from sleep. He denies any other symptoms such as lightheadedness  fainting  palpitations  or recent weight changes.  Summary: This case involves an older male patient with multiple cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension  diabetes  history of smoking  and family history of heart disease) who is presenting with classic symptoms of stable angina- a key feature of coronary artery disease. This case encourages medical students to consider this critical diagnosis and how patient lifestyle  medical history  and symptomatology can indicate different risk levels for cardiovascular disease.

Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Demographics: - Name: John Smith - Sex: Male - Age: 68 - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired  previously worked in construction - Social History: Smoker for 45 years (1 pack per day)  moderate alcohol consumption (3-4 drinks per week). - Family History: Father died of myocardial infarction at 72; sister diagnosed with hypertension.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  actively managed with Lisinopril 20 mg OD - Type 2 diabetes mellitus  diagnosed 10 years ago  controlled with Metformin. - Overweight with a BMI of 28 - Hyperlipidemia  managed with Simvastatin 40 mg once daily - Prior history of transient ischemic attacks  for which he is on Aspirin 81 mg daily.  Presenting Complaints:  1. The key complaint is ongoing central chest pain that radiates to the arm (more on the left side). The pain is described as a pressure or squeezing sensation and is moderate to severe in intensity. 2. The pain usually starts after mild to moderate exertion (like walking or climbing stairs) but is increasingly coming on during rest over the last week. 3. There are associated symptoms of shortness of breath  diaphoresis (sweating)  mild nausea  and a sense of unease. 4. He also experiences occasional episodes of dizziness. 5. Patient noticed the pains are relieved by rest or nitroglycerin (which was given to him by his primary care physician for emergency use) 6. His wife has noticed that he seems to be more fatigued lately.   This case is designed to focus on a typical presentation of chronic stable angina leading to unstable angina  a common manifestation of coronary artery disease. Subsequent history  examination  and investigations should be directed towards confirming the diagnosis  assessing the severity of the disease  and planning treatment. The students should be guided to understand the pathophysiology of the disease  its typical and atypical presentations  relevance of risk factors  and the available treatment options based on updated guidelines.

Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Information: Name: John Smith Age: 59 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Operations Manager Smoking Status: Ex-smoker (quit 15 years ago)  Presenting Complaints: 1. Persistent chest pain  described as a heavy weight on the chest  often radiating towards the left arm. 2. Difficulty in doing physical activities  getting winded easily even with light exercise. 3. Complaints of occasional breathlessness. 4. Episodes of dizziness and lightheadedness.   Past Medical History: 1. Diagnosed with type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  currently managed with Metformin. 2. History of hypertension  controlled with Lisinopril and Hydrochlorothiazide. 3. Elevated cholesterol levels controlled with Atorvastatin. 4. Mild obesity with a body mass index (BMI) of 30. 5. No known allergies.  Family History: 1. Father died of myocardial infarction at age 65. 2. Mother has hypertension and type 2 diabetes. 3. Younger brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease at 57.  Social History: 1. Mr. Smith is an ex-smoker  he quit smoking 15 years ago and used to smoke a pack daily. 2. Drinks alcohol socially  about 2-3 drinks per week. 3. Sedentary lifestyle with limited exercise.  Review of Systems: Unremarkable  apart from the above-stated complaints.  Summary of Key Points: Mr. Smith is a 59-year-old male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia. He presents with symptoms characteristic of coronary artery disease  including exertional chest pain  breathlessness  and occasional lightheadedness. His family history suggests a potential genetic predisposition for cardiovascular conditions. His lifestyle and past habits pose additional risk factors for the development of coronary artery disease.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 59 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Corporate Office Job Lifestyle: Sedentarism  High stress  Smoker  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has been diagnosed with hypertension and Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus for which he has been under treatment for the past 10 years. He also has a 20 pack-year history of smoking. He has reported to maintain a high-stress job and follows an unhealthy diet  high in saturated fat. No known allergies were reported. Family history reveals his father was diagnosed with coronary artery disease at the age of 65.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Doe presented to the clinic with recent episodes of chest pain radiating to the left arm  occurring predominantly on exertion  and improved with rest  along with episodes of dyspnea on moderate exertion. These symptoms have been ongoing intermittently over the past month but have progressed in severity over the past week.  Clinical Finding:  Physical examination revealed a blood pressure of 145/90 mmHg  heart rate of 80 beats per minute  and body mass index (BMI) of 28 kg/m2. Slight crackles were found on auscultation at the lung bases and the cardiac exam was without murmur  although a gallop rhythm was noted. Blood glucose levels and lipid profile also showed abnormal levels.  This case scenario is focused to help medical students identify and manage a typical case of coronary artery disease with other associated comorbid conditions. The students should be ready to discuss the pertinent investigations  diagnostic methods  possible complications  and treatment options for the same. Further  they need to underline the lifestyle modifications necessary in such scenarios. They should also be able to discuss the pathophysiology of coronary artery disease and understand its link with other comorbidities.

Patient Information -------------------------------- Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 57 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Bank Manager Race: Caucasian  Case Description -------------------------- Mr. John Doe  a 57-year-old bank manager  presented to the clinic with a chief complaint of frequent chest pain often precipitated by physical activity or stress over the past few months. Each episode usually lasts for 5-15 minutes. He sometimes feels the pain radiating to his left arm and experiences shortness of breath along with it. He also reported experiencing bouts of dizziness occasionally with the attacks and feeling fatigued more often than before. He noted that the symptoms usually improve with rest.  John is a smoker with a 30 pack-year history and has been experiencing moderate alcohol usage. He doesn't exercise regularly  and his diet primarily includes high-fat  high-salt processed foods. He admits to being under regular stress due to work. His father had a history of heart disease and died from a heart attack in his early 60s.  Past Medical History --------------------------- John has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  diagnosed five years ago  for which he has been prescribed antihypertensive and statin therapy. However  he admits that his compliance with his medications or follow-up appointments has been irregular due to his busy schedule.  Upon physical examination  he was found to be overweight with a BMI of 28. Initial vital sign assessment reveals a blood pressure of 156/95 mmHg  a heart rate of 85 beats per minute  and normal respiratory rate and temperature.  The initial diagnosis based on the patient's symptoms and risk factors would be a suspicion of coronary artery disease. However  further cardiovascular examinations and diagnostic tests such as an ECG  stress test  and coronary angiography could be necessary to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of disease. The plan could potentially include smoking cessation education  exercise encouragement  a healthier diet plan  and stricter assessment of medication adherence.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Patient's Information Name: John Doe  Gender: Male  Age: 65 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retiring teacher Smoking Status: Past smoker  quit 15 years ago  Medical History  The patient is known to have hypertension for which he is taking a calcium channel blocker and an ACE inhibitor. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus five years ago; his most recent HbA1c at a routine medical check-up six months ago was 7.2%. He is also on low-dose aspirin for primary prevention of cardiovascular disease. He has no known allergy to drugs or food.  Key Complaints He presented to his primary care physician with a complaint of dull chest pain that started two weeks ago. He describes it as a “pressure” or “heaviness ” located in the middle of the chest. The pain usually starts after he does physical work like mowing the lawn or climbing up stairs in his home and typically subsides within 10 minutes of resting. More recently  he has also felt this chest pain when he walks briskly during cold weather.   The pain doesn’t radiate  there’s no association with meals  and it’s not relieved by belching or antacids. He hasn't reported any associated palpitations  syncope or pre-syncope  but has felt short of breath on occasion. He has no history of heart disease  surgical interventions or conditions that could have affected heart health. He was a smoker for 20 years but quit 15 years ago. His father died of a heart attack at 75  and his older brother underwent a stenting procedure for coronary artery disease at the age of 63.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics:  Mr. G  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  working as a senior executive in a corporate firm  non-smoker  BMI 29  presenting to the office for routine evaluation.  Past medical history:  Mr. G has carefully controlled hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years and hypertension for 5 years  both effectively managed on medications. He has a family history of coronary artery disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 60 years. He has no known allergies  is physically inactive  and follows a high-sodium  high-fat diet.  Key Complaints: The patient has recently started experiencing unusual fatigue during normal daily activities  especially on climbing stairs or walking  which before he used to perform without difficulty. He also reports instances of intermittent chest discomfort that seems to lessen with rest  particularly noted over the last six weeks. He has noticed discomfort in his left arm  which he describes as a dull ache  and a vague feeling of uneasiness and indigestion. Upon further probing  Mr. G mentioned experiencing sleep disturbances  excessive sweating  and shortness of breath on exertion.   He denied any episodes of syncope  palpitations  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or orthopnea. He has not noticed any changes in his weight and has no associated fevers  chills  or recent illnesses. There is no history of diabetes or other cardiac diseases.  He claims to lead a high-stress lifestyle  attributing the symptoms to stress and age. Despite his wife's insistence  he hesitated to seek medical attention due to concern about possible implications for his professional life.  This clinical case focuses on the essential aspects of a typical coronary artery disease presentation  including clinical history  symptomatology  risk factors  and the importance of seeking timely medical advice. It provides medical students a practical foundation of knowledge for the investigation  diagnosis  and management of such patients.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: Age: 60 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American  Occupation: Transport driver Lifestyle: Smoker and physically inactive.  Lives: Lives alone and experiences moderate levels of stress.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus (Type 2) for the past 10 years and hypertension for the last 7 years. Both conditions are under control with oral antidiabetic and antihypertensive medications. The patient also had dyslipidemia diagnosed 5 years ago  treated with statins. He has a history of smoking 20 cigarettes a day for the last 25 years. There is also a family history of coronary artery disease; his father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 55.  Key Complaints: He presents with a 2-month history of recurrent chest pain  with an increasing frequency in the last two weeks. This discomfort is described as heaviness in his central chest  usually lasting for 10-15 minutes. The pain sometimes radiates to his left shoulder and arm and is often accompanied by shortness of breath and excessive sweating. The discomfort mainly occurs on exertion  such as climbing stairs or during his job as a transport driver and is usually relieved by rest. However  he has experienced an episode of pain at rest in the last week. He also reports of feeling increasingly fatigued over the last few weeks. There is no associated nausea  vomiting  or palpitations.  Given the patient's age  lifestyle  and significant risk factors - namely diabetes  hypertension  dyslipidemia  smoking  family history  race and the pattern of his pain  a diagnostic workup for coronary artery disease is strongly indicated.

Case Report on Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Carter  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired police officer  non-smoker with a family history of heart disease (father and grandfather both suffered heart attacks in their 60s).  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  both conditions primarily managed with metformin 500mg BD and hydrochlorothiazide 25mg OD. He occasionally takes Ibuprofen for lower back pain  but otherwise has no remarkable medication history. Mr. Carter is noted to have a BMI of 29.8 kg/m2  making him classified as overweight. His cholesterol level was found to be 225 mg/dL during his last general check-up 6 months ago. He does not adhere to a consistent exercise schedule and admits to having a diet high in salt and saturated fats.  Key complaints: Mr. Carter visited the outpatient department complaining of recurrent chest pain for the past two weeks. He describes the pain as a dull  heavy discomfort located in the center of his chest  with occasional radiation to his left arm and jaw. The pain often occurs after meals or when he engages in physical exertion such as climbing stairs or lifting heavy items. Episodes generally last between 5 to 10 minutes and subside with rest. He also mentioned feeling abnormally fatigued lately and experiencing episodes of shortness of breath.   Two days ago he had a particularly severe chest pain episode that lasted for about an hour  which was unlike his usual symptoms. He reports the pain did not alleviate upon rest  which concerned him and prompted his visit. He stated he felt sweaty and nauseated during this episode but denied syncope  palpitations or other associated symptoms.   No previous episodes of such chest discomfort  no history of prior cardiovascular diseases  no history of stroke or renal diseases.   The case thus focuses on symptoms suggestive of stable angina  initially  with a progression to a more severe episode of probable unstable angina or myocardial infarction  warranting further evaluation and intervention. This case underscores the importance of recognizing cardiovascular risk factors and understanding the clinical progression of coronary artery disease.

Case Report  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 54  Sex: Male Occupation: Software Engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Location: Boston  Massachusetts  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 6 years ago  under control with medication. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 7 years ago  diet controlled. 3. Hypercholesteremia: Diagnosed 5 years ago  under treatment with statins. 4. Ex-smoker: Quit smoking 5 years ago. History of 20 pack-years. 5. Obesity: BMI 32 6. Family history of heart disease: His father suffered a myocardial infarction at the age of 56.  Key Complaints: Mr. John Doe presented to the outpatient department with a history of intermittent chest pain for the past 3 months. The chest pain is generally located in the central chest region and often radiates towards his left shoulder and arm. He describes the pain as a feeling of ""tightness"" or ""pressure""  which usually occurs after physical exertion like climbing stairs or carrying heavy loads  and is relieved by rest. He also reported experiencing shortness of breath and episodes of diaphoresis during these episodes of chest pain. Recently he noticed two episodes of chest pain at rest  which caused him to seek medical attention.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Demographics: Name: John Doe Age: 65 Sex: Male Occupation: Retired teacher Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has been treated for hypertension for the past 10 years and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago. He had been a heavy smoker  but quit about a year ago. His family history is significant as his father suffered from coronary artery disease (CAD) and his mother was diabetic. He has a BMI of 28  is mildly dyslipidemic  and does not exercise regularly.  Current Complaints: The patient came in complaining of chest pain  particularly over the left side  which he described as a squeezing or crushing sensation  especially pronounced when doing physical work. He noticed that this pain could ease off with rest but is persistent and has been going on for the past a week. He also complained about discomfort in other areas  including his left shoulder and arm  jaw  neck  and back. He noticed mild shortness of breath during a normal walk but reported no dizziness  palpitations  or syncope. He has noticed increasing chronic fatigue over the past few months.
