Summary:  In this case scenario  our patient is a 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes  family history of CAD  and a former smoking habit. He presents symptoms of chest pain and discomfort  along with shortness of breath and fatigue. His risk factors  namely his family history of CAD  hypertension  diabetes  smoking  lack of exercise  and his age and gender  all point towards a potential diagnosis of coronary artery disease. This case would benefit from prompt investigation and management  including lifestyle modifications  pharmacotherapy and possibly invasive procedures  after a thorough cardiac evaluation.

Patient Information:  - Name: John Doe - Gender: Male - Age: 68 - Race: Caucasian - Marital Status: Married - Occupation: Retired Bank Manager - Past medical history: Hypertension  hyperlipidemia - Smoking history: Smoker for 40 years  quit 10 years ago. - Family history: Father died of heart disease at 60  mother diagnosed with type 2 diabetes.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Doe presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of gradually worsening left-sided chest pain over the last 48 hours. The pain seems to radiate to his left shoulder and has been increasing in intensity. It particularly bothers him when he goes for his morning walk. He also mentions that he experienced a shortness of breath and mild dizziness following one of these episodes earlier in the week.   He is particularly worried because his father died of a heart attack at a relatively early age. He is adhering to his hypertension and hyperlipidemia medications but admits that his dietary habits could be improved.  Similarly  he notes that he has put a pause on his morning walks because of the discomfort but otherwise continues with ordinary activities.  Aliases and other identifiable information in patient cases are typically used for representation and teaching purposes only  the above patient ""John Doe"" does not pertain to any real individual.

Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe  a 58-year-old African American male  works as a software developer  and is a father of two.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension for which he has been off medications for the last year. He also has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is controlled through metformin. Mr. Doe is a former smoker with a 15 pack-year history but quit 10 years ago. His father died of a myocardial infarction in his early 60s  and his mother has a history of stroke.   Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe came in because he has been experiencing an increased level of discomfort in the center of his chest  described as a feeling of ""pressure"" that radiates down his left arm. These symptoms have intensified over the past month. The discomfort generally lasts around 10-15 minutes and is often triggered by physical work or emotional stress  but it subsides after resting. He also reported shortness of breath upon exertion  occasional episodes of dizziness  excessive sweating  and noticeable fatigue  all of which have been worsening over the last few weeks. There is no reported history of fever  cough  or weight change. He also denies any recent alterations in his diet or physical activity patterns.  Socioeconomic status:   He lives in a suburb and has a moderate income. He reports occasional alcohol use. He consumes a diet rich in fats and carbohydrates and has an irregular exercise routine  often citing a lack of time due to work demands.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease   Patient Information: Mr. Howell  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  works as a corporate lawyer living in an urban area.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia- all managed with medication for the past decade. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit smoking 5 years ago. Family history includes a father who died from a myocardial infarction in his late sixties and a mother currently managing hypertension and diabetes. The patient admits to a sedentary lifestyle due to his job demand  revealing intermittent engagement in physical exercise. Also  he admits being overweight and consumes a diet rich in saturated fats.   Chief Complaints: Mr. Howell presented to the emergency department with a chief complaint of chest pain of 7 hours duration. He describes it as a heavy  squeezing pain in the center of his chest  radiating to his left arm. The pain was aggravated with exertion and partially relieved by rest. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath  nausea  diaphoresis  and a feeling of impending doom. There was no report of loss of consciousness  dizziness  or palpitations.   Discussion: This case focuses on coronary artery disease (CAD). Considering Mr. Howell's risk factors including advanced age  male sex  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking history  sedentary lifestyle  obesity  high saturated fat diet and family history of CAD  this case provides a rich background to discuss the pathophysiology  diagnosis  and management strategies for CAD.  The teaching session should explore how these risk factors influence CAD. It is also worthwhile to compare typical symptoms (as presented by the patient) and atypical presentations  especially in different populations. The scenario lends itself to discussions around effective lifestyle modifications and evidence-based treatments - both pharmacological and procedural - for CAD.   (Specific laboratory findings  electrocardiogram and imaging results  as well as specific treatment approach would be tailored depending on the level and learning objectives of the medical trainees.)  Clinical Skills Objective: The students are expected to conduct a thorough patient interview  perform a careful cardiovascular examination  and interpret clinical data to confirm the diagnosis of CAD. They should be able to identify and manage immediate life-threatening conditions and design a long-term management plan including living lifestyle modification.

Title: A Case of Coronary Artery Disease in a 62-Year-Old Male  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Edward Harris Age: 62 Gender: Male Occupation: Retired military officer Marital Status: Married Ethnic Origin: African American  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Harris has been suffering from a gradually increasing dull  heavy chest pain for the last six months that seems to radiate towards his left arm. He also reports shortness of breath upon exertion  fatigue  lightheadedness  and episodes of indigestion. He complains of occasional rapid heartbeat and has experienced nocturnal sweating episodes. He has been increasingly limited in his daily activities due to these symptoms.  Medical History:  Mr. Harris has a past history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both of which he manages with medications (Lisinopril and Metformin  respectively). He has hyperlipidemia for which he takes Simvastatin. He was a heavy smoker but quit 20 years ago and has a history of heavy alcohol consumption but has significantly reduced intake over the past decade.   Family History:  His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 67  and his mother had a stroke at the age of 70.  Lifestyle: Mr. Harris is sedentary since his retirement. His diet primarily includes processed and fast foods  lacks adequate fruits and vegetables  and is high in saturated fats and sodium.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Harris had a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg Heart rate was irregular (tachycardia). His BMI was 30  indicating obesity. Remaining systemic examination was unremarkable.  This case is designed to provide the learners with insights into the risk factors  pathophysiology  clinical manifestation  investigation  and management of coronary artery disease (CAD). After going through this  students should be able to identify CAD symptoms  risk factors and understand the necessary diagnostic process and treatment options.

Patient Case: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: Name: Mr. Williams  Age: 61 years Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Bank Manager Race: Caucasian  Present Complaints:  Patient has presented to the clinic complaining of persistent chest discomfort and decreasing exercise tolerance. He described symptoms as 'tightening' in his chest and being easily fatigued when performing usual activities like climbing stairs  lifting heavy items  or brisk walking  which were earlier manageable. He also reported occasional shortness of breath and episode of dizziness in the past week.  Past Medical History: Mr. Williams has been a diagnosed hypertensive for 15 years  maintained on medication (Losartan 50 mg daily). He has a 20 year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  managed through Metformin (1g twice a day) and diet control. He is also diagnosed with Dyslipidemia for past 10 years  under treatment with Atorvastatin (20mg daily). His past records indicate ongoing management with regular follow-ups  but sub-optimal control of hypertension and diabetes.  Family History: His father had coronary artery disease and underwent a coronary bypass surgery. His elder brother died from a myocardial infarction at age 56.  Lifestyle:  He is an ex-smoker  quit smoking 12 years ago; used to smoke approx. 20 cigarettes per day. He drinks alcohol occasionally. His diet mostly comprises meat and dairy products with rare fruit/vegetable intake. He acknowledges occasional indulgence in high-sugar foods. Physical activity is minimum  as the patient prefers a sedentary lifestyle.  This case gives students a chance to understand components of history taking  symptom analysis  and risk stratification in coronary artery disease. Students should be able to identify the significance of patient’s complaints  appreciate the relevance of past and family history  and incorporate lifestyle factors into their understanding  thus informing potential intervention strategies.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: Mr. Roberts is a 64-year-old Caucasian male. He is a lifetime non-smoker and occasional drinker who lives with his wife in the urban area. Mr. Roberts works as an accountant and leads a moderately sedentary lifestyle. He is known to have high-stress levels due to his work.  Past Medical History: Mr. Roberts is hypertensive for the past 10 years  controlled with medication. He has Type II diabetes for the past five years  which is relatively well controlled with Metformin. He is obese with a BMI of 30. He also suffers from moderate sleep apnea. There is a family history of heart disease; his father had a heart attack in his late fifties.  Key Complaints: Mr. Roberts presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of experiencing chest discomfort over the last three weeks. He describes the discomfort as a sharp  pressing pain behind the sternum  which sometimes radiates to his left arm. He has also noticed an increase in shortness of breath with minimal exertion and occasional bouts of fatigue. He reflects that his symptoms often appear after eating  when going for his evening walk  or when under high stress at work. It usually improves with rest  but lately it's becoming more frequent and intense. He also mentions having episodes of heart palpitations and a recent episode of light-headedness that he hasn't ever experienced before.  He has been treating his chest discomfort with antacids as suggested by a pharmacist friend thinking it is heartburn due to his gastroesophageal reflux disease  but the pain is not completely alleviating. His symptoms increased over the last three days which led him to your clinic. On inquiry  he claimed there is no case of fever  cough  or sweating.   This case study can be beneficial for exploring topics with medical students such as risk factors for coronary artery disease  interpreting patient symptoms  differential diagnoses  and outlining a proper treatment plan that considers the patient's overall health condition  lifestyle  and symptoms.

Case Report:   Patient Information: The patient is Mr. Rodriguez  a 65-year-old Hispanic male from Los Angeles  California. He is married  retired  and has two adult children. His body mass index sits at 29.   Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has a long-standing history of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  Hypertension  and Hyperlipidemia. He has been treating these conditions for the past 15 years. He had a smoking habit of 10-pack years but quit 5 years ago. Despite his health conditions  his adherence to dietary modification and exercise is inconsistent. He currently takes Metformin 500mg twice daily for his diabetes  Lisinopril 20mg once daily for his hypertension  and Atorvastatin 20mg once daily for his hyperlipidemia.  Key Complaints: Mr. Rodriguez presents to the emergency department with severe central chest pain that he describes as ""crushing"" in nature. The pain started while he was watching television and has been ongoing for the past 4 hours. The pain radiates towards his left shoulder and down his left arm. Accompanying symptoms include profuse sweating  shortness of breath  and a feeling of impending doom.   Additional details:  He also mentioned a decrease in exercise tolerance over the past few weeks due to increasing episodes of what he thought were indigestion or heartburn. Mr. Rodriguez has tried to self-manage these symptoms by reducing spicy foods from his meals  but the symptoms have not abated. He also reported feeling brief periods of irregular heartbeats occasionally over the last two months.   Rad flags/significant indicators: Central chest pain  radiation of pain to left arm  and shortness of breath alongside a history of hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia could indicate a typical presentation of myocardial ischemia or even a myocardial infarction  both of which are commonly associated with coronary artery disease.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Rafael Smith  58-year-old African-American male  living in suburban Philadelphia  Pennsylvania with his wife  working as an accountant. Moderate smoker for 40 years  social drinker  exercises semi-regularly. No known drug allergies.  Past Medical History: Known hypertensive for the past 10 years  currently controlled under medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). Family history of coronary artery disease - Father had CAD and passed away at the age of 64. The patient also has Type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily  diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient has high cholesterol which is managed with Atorvastatin 20mg per day. No previous surgeries recorded.   Chief Complaints: The patient presents with a chief complaint of episodes of chest discomfort for the last two weeks. The discomfort is described as a squeezing pressure  mainly located retrosternally and radiating towards the left arm. The episodes often occur during physical exertion  such as walking up stairs at home  and usually abate with rest or sublingual nitroglycerin. Rafael reports associated shortness of breath and diaphoresis during these episodes  but denies nausea  vomiting  palpitations  syncope  or recent illnesses. He additionally notes that these episodes are increasing in frequency  causing him to visit the Emergency Department.  This case presents a typical profile for Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The patient's complaints of exertional chest pain  or angina  with radiation to the arm along with shortness of breath  is a classic sign. This coupled with his demographic (middle-aged male)  unhealthy habits (smoking)  comorbidities (hypertension  diabetes  and high cholesterol)  and genetic predisposition would skew one towards suspecting CAD. In the course of managing this case  students should learn to recognize CAD risk factors and symptoms  diagnostic procedures like EKG and Echo  and management strategies including lifestyle changes and pharmacological therapies.

Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. Johnston  Age: 60 years old  Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Accountant Location: Urban area  Tennessee   Past Medical History: Mr. Johnston has a well-documented history of hypertension over the past 5 years  effectively managed with Lisinopril. He has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes for the past decade  controlled by metformin and lifestyle modifications. Mr. Johnston quit smoking 10 years ago  following a 30-year pack-a-day habit. He has a BMI of 28  indicative of overweight. There is a strong family history of heart disease; his father died from a heart attack at age 70.  Key Complaints: Mr. Johnston visited the ER with complaints of intermittent chest pain intensifying over the last month. The pain is described as a crushing sensation that radiates to his left arm and jaw  typically occurring during physical exertion or times of stress and relieved by rest. He experienced similar pain lasting for half an hour on the morning of his hospital visit. Accompanying symptoms included shortness of breath  fatigue  dizziness  and an episode of vomiting.   Upon establishing the primary patient history  provide the medical students with a brief description of their task: to effectively discuss a differential diagnosis based on the provided information  propose relevant diagnostic tests for coronary artery disease  and outline the potential management strategy for the patient's condition.

Patient Information  Name: John Doe Age: 68  Sex: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired lawyer  Past Medical History: John has been managing hypertension and Type II diabetes for the past 15 years and was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia seven years ago. He was a smoker for 30 years but quit ten years ago. His father died from a myocardial infarction at 72.   Presenting Complaints: John presented to the clinic complaining of increasing episodes of chest pain for the last two months  occasionally radiating to his left arm  typically occurring during physical exertion such as walking or climbing stairs. He also reports experiencing a shortness of breath and increasing fatigue. Neither antacids nor rest significantly relieve his symptoms.   Vital Signs:  Blood pressure – 148/95 mmHg Pulse – 80 bpm Body mass index (BMI) - 28 kg/m2   Additional Observations:  Upon physical examination  John was alert but appeared fatigued. Auscultation of the heart revealed no murmurs or gallops. John's breath sounds were clear bilaterally. His extremities exhibited no cyanosis  clubbing  or edema.   Pertinent Lab findings: - Fasting Blood Sugar: 180 mg/dL  - LDL Cholesterol: 160 mg/dL  - Serum Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL  - Troponin level: Slightly elevated - ECG: Shows ST depression during angina episodes   These observations strongly indicate the possibility of coronary artery disease. This case can now be used to teach students about the presentation  diagnosis  and management of CAD  along with the risk factors and co-morbidities that increase the chances of developing this disease.   Keep in mind to include discussions about appropriate tests and procedures (such as stress tests or coronary angiography)  treatment options (like medication  lifestyle changes  and potential surgical interventions)  and the importance of managing co-morbid conditions to reduce the progression of CAD.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics:   Gender: Male Age: 65 years old  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Electrical Engineer Place of Residence: Seattle  Washington   Past Medical History: • Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  which is controlled on medication. • Type-2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago  managed with diet control and oral medication. • His mother passed at an age of 70 due to heart attack. • Non-smoker but has a history of heavy drinking  although now sober for the past 5 years. • The patient led a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to his occupation.  Key Complaints: The patient came to the ER complaining of intermittent episodes of moderate to severe chest pain over the past week. The pain is often described as tightness in the chest which sometimes radiates to the left side of the jaw and down the left arm. He mentioned that these episodes frequently occurred during exertion like when he walks up the staircase or does any strenuous exercise. The episodes would typically last 5 to 10 minutes and tend to resolve with rest. He has associated these episodes with other symptoms  like shortness of breath  excessive sweating and feelings of nausea.   In the last hour before presenting  the patient experienced a bout of such pain whilst sitting in his chair at home; however  this time the pain seemed much more intense and did not diminish upon taking rest. He also experienced lightheadedness on this occasion.   Note for Medical Students: Red flags in this case revolve around the patient's age  gender  uncontrolled hypertension  diabetes  family history  and symptoms indicative of anginal episodes which signify underlying coronary artery disease. The onset of symptoms at rest suggests unstable angina  a potential precursor to myocardial infarction  which should prompt urgent evaluation and management.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 58 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Accountant Residence: Suburban  Middle-class neighborhood  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with Type II diabetes for the past 5 years and is on medications  mainly metformin. He was also diagnosed with mild hypertension two years ago  which is being controlled with lisinopril. His family history is significant  with his father dying of a heart attack at 62 and his older brother diagnosed with angina at 60. The patient does not smoke but consumes alcohol moderately. His BMI is within the overweight range.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the outpatient department describing a recurrent  constricting central chest pain usually lasting for 5-10 minutes for the past month. He attributed these episodes initially to gastric trouble. He states that the pain appears typically after meals or on exerting himself physically and is relieved by rest. Recently  he experienced the same type of pain while lying in bed  which led him to seek medical help. He also reported mild breathlessness and occasional lightheadedness during these episodes. He denies any symptoms of sweating  nausea  or radiation of pain.   This case report aims at highlighting different aspects of coronary artery disease  emphasizing patient history  risk factors like diabetes  hypertension  family history  obesity  and moderate alcohol use. The main symptoms presented are classical of angina  which should lead the medical students towards a probable diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Case Report  Patient Demographics:  Name: John Doe Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanic Location: Urban  Past Medical History: John has been a smoker for 30 years. However  he quit smoking five years ago. He also has a history of high blood pressure and Type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which he takes medication. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 72. He has a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 27  indicating he is overweight. He has hyperlipidemia and reports being inconsistently compliant with his prescribed statin therapy.   Key Complaints: John presents to the emergency department complaining of a pressure-like chest pain which he characterizes as a 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain radiates to his left arm and is accompanied by shortness of breath and sweating. These symptoms started 45 minutes ago while he was gardening and have not improved with rest. He also mentioned experiencing some episodes of similar  though less severe  chest pain while climbing stairs over the past week  but he attributed it to indigestion and didn't seek medical help.   This brief training case can be used to educate medical students about recognizing symptoms of coronary artery disease  understanding its risk factors  the importance of a detailed patient history  as well as effective communication and patient education to prevent avoidance or delay of medical attention.

Patient Information:  Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old Caucasian male who works as a senior executive in a high-stress corporate job. He is a long-term smoker  with a 40 pack-year history. He does not exercise regularly and admits to eating a diet high in saturated fats and drinking alcohol in a social setting.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 56. He is currently on an ACE inhibitor and a statin.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith presents with intermittent episodes of a dull  pressing pain in the central chest that is poorly localized. These episodes usually last for around 10 minutes and can occur at rest but are more frequent during exertion. The pain is often accompanied by shortness of breath  profuse sweating  and a feeling of unease. The following week  he experienced an episode of severe chest pain at rest that woke him up from sleep.  Physical Examination: Mr. Smith's blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg and heart rate is 85 beats per minute. His BMI is 31. Cardiovascular examination reveals no abnormalities  and ECG shows T wave inversions in the anterior leads. His lipid profile indicates elevated total cholesterol  low HDL  and high LDL.  These symptoms suggest the possibility of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). An exercise stress test will be performed to further evaluate his condition. Further management will also involve lifestyle modification advice and reconsideration of his current medications.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. James Smith  58-year-old African American male living in an urban environment with a supportive extended family network. He is an ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago. He's gainfully employed as a bank manager  is moderately physically active  and has a BMI of 28  which qualifies him as overweight.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a medical history of hypertension that is being managed with Amlodipine and Lisinopril. He also has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  which is controlled with Metformin. He has reported consistent adherence to his medications  but his BP and glucose levels are variably controlled. He has no history of any heart diseases but there is a strong family history of cardiac diseases. His father had died of myocardial infarction at age 63 and his oldest brother aged 61 had a recent diagnosis of coronary artery disease. His lipid profile is relevant for a high LDL cholesterol  and is managed on a statin (Atorvastatin).  Key complaints: Mr. Smith presented with two weeks history of recurrent  dull aching chest pain – typically whilst climbing stairs in his job or during his moderate intensity exercises. Pain was described as 5/10 in severity  relief with rest  and more on his left side and feels like ‘someone is squeezing my chest’. Accompanied by occasional shortness of breath  but no complaint of nausea  vomiting  or sweating. No previous history of such chest pain. He didn't take it seriously assuming it as due to his physical activity or indigestion but he noticed the pattern and occurrence with exertion  so he decided to meet his healthcare provider.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: African American Occupation: Retired financial analyst  Medical History: The patient is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus  diagnosed 8 years ago. He is also hypertensive for the last 10 years and is taking Metformin 500 mg twice daily and a daily dose of Losartan 50 mg for the management of these diseases. Mr. Doe is also on Atorvastatin 20 mg for hypercholesterolemia diagnosed 5 years ago. The patient has never smoked  but he claims he used to consume alcohol moderately up until 10 years ago. No family history of any cardiovascular diseases. No previous hospitalizations other than for minor surgical procedures.  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the outpatient department complaining of recurrent chest pain for the past 2 months. The pain is usually in the center of the chest  boring in nature  radiating to his left arm  and is associated with shortness of breath. The episodes typically last about 10-15 minutes and are often precipitated by physical exertion  adding an element of typical cardiac angina. Mr. Doe also mentioned increased fatigue in the past few weeks.  Objective: The medical students will need to assess the patient's symptoms  past medical history  and risk factors  allowing them to form a differential diagnosis with focused investigations for this case. Finally  they should be able to come up with an appropriate management plan for Mr. Doe's presenting complaint considering coronary artery disease is a likelihood.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Smith is a 62-year-old  Caucasian male. He is a former industrial worker  retired for 8 years  and a lifetime smoker with a 50-pack-year history. He drinks alcohol socially and lives with his wife in a suburban community. He is of medium build  with a height of 5’9"" and weight of 185 lbs. He does not participate in any particular physical activity.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith's medical history reveals that he was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago and type 2 diabetes five years ago. He has been on medication for both conditions: Lisinopril for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. His family history includes a father who died of a myocardial infarction at age 65 and a mother who had a stroke at the age of 72.  Lifestyle: He has a mostly sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in saturated fats and processed foods. He has tried quitting smoking several times but has always relapsed.  Chief Complaints: Over the past 4 months  Mr. Smith has noticed a growing discomfort in his chest. The discomfort occurs mostly during exertion  such as climbing stairs or walking long distances - it feels like a “pressure” or “squeezing” sensation. He initially dismissed it as indigestion or gas but grew concerned when the discomfort started to radiate down his left arm. The episodes usually last 5-10 minutes and are relieved with rest. He also mentioned experiencing shortness of breath  excessive perspiration  and occasional dizziness during these episodes.  Brief Summary: This case presents a 62-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension  type II diabetes  and smoking. He has been experiencing exertional chest pain with radiation to the left arm  dyspnea  diaphoresis  and occasional dizziness  all of which suggest that he may be suffering from coronary artery disease. His family history  sedentary lifestyle and poor dietary habits further contribute to his risk.

Patient Case:  Demographics: Name: Mrs. S. Johnson Age: 80 Sex: Female Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Teacher  Residential Status: Lives in an assisted living facility  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension - Diagnosed at age 50  on Lisinopril 20 mg daily  2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus - Diagnosed at age 60  diet controlled 3. Hyperlipidemia - Diagnosed at age 70  on Atorvastatin 40mg daily 4. Mild Cognitive Impairment – Diagnosed at age 78 5. Non-smoker 6. No history of drug allergies   Current Complaints: Mrs. Johnson presented with a two-week history of increasing chest pain that she describes as feeling like 'a tight band around her chest.' The pain radiates to her left arm and neck are. It usually occurs upon exertion like when climbing stairs in her care home but also at rest during the last two days. The pain typically lasts for about 15 minutes each time.  She reports associated complaints of breathlessness during these episodes  occasional feelings of dizziness  and nausea but no syncope.   Recent reports from her caregivers indicate a decrease in her usual activities due to fatigue. They also noticed her becoming increasingly concerned about these symptoms  leading to increased levels of anxiety.  The purpose of this case is to demonstrate the typical presentation of coronary artery disease and understand the severity of the disease given the advanced age of the patient and her multiple risk factors.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  Patient Information:  Patient J.D is a 63-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired construction worker and currently lives with his wife.  Past Medical History:  Patient has a history of hypertension and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  both controlled by medications. There's also a positive family history of cardiovascular disease  as his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 57. Patient is a former smoker  quit twenty years ago  and confesses occasional alcohol intake. His BMI falls within the overweight range.   Key Patient Complaints:  J.D presents with a 3-month history of irregular chest pain and discomfort  describing it as “pressure” and “tightness.” The pain is primarily located in the substernal region  occasionally radiating to the left arm and jaw. He notices that physical exertion such as house chores or climbing stairs seems to trigger or exacerbate this pain. The episodes usually last for few minutes and resolve at rest or very occasionally require sublingual nitroglycerin.   Recently  he has been experiencing episodes of indigestion each episode associated with diaphoresis and shortness of breath. J.D also reports episodes of fatigue and dizziness on exertion in the past few weeks. There have been no episodes of fainting  palpitations  cough  or orthopnea. However  J.D reports increased nocturia  which disrupts his sleep.   J.D’s wife forced him to seek medical attention as he has become increasingly irritable and anxious due to his symptoms and expresses fear that he might ""end up like my father.""  This case is designed to train students on how to assess  diagnose  and manage a classic presentation of coronary artery disease with an association of risk factors. After learning and practicing this case scenario  students would be able to obtain a focused history  perform a targeted physical exam  and proceed with appropriate diagnostic tests. They can also explore the importance of initiating lifestyle modifications and discuss possible medical or surgical treatments. Moreover  this case can help students to understand the psychological impact of chronic diseases like CAD on patients.

Patient Demographics:   Mr. Robert Adams  a 62-year-old Caucasian male  who is an ex-smoker and currently living a mostly sedentary lifestyle. He’s employed as an operations manager in a local company. Robert lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. The patient admits occasional alcohol intake. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father having suffered from a myocardial infarction at the age of 66.  Past Medical History:  Robert was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 5 years ago. He has been on antihypertensive medication (Losartan) and statins but admitted he does not always remember to take them as prescribed. He was also diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus two years ago and was prescribed Metformin. In addition  the patient underwent a total knee replacement one year ago due to severe arthritis.  Key Complaints:  Robert has recently been experiencing recurrent episodes of chest pain sometimes radiating to his left arm. He describes the pain as a pressure-like sensation that typically occurs after meals or with activity like climbing stairs or walking. The pain usually dissipates after about ten minutes of rest. Robert also reports shortness of breath  mild fatigue  and excessive sweating  particularly during these episodes of chest pain. He indicated that he's been avoiding certain activities due to fear of triggering the painful episodes. This led to his decision to seek medical help.   In the last week  he reported that these episodes have been increasing in duration and intensity despite resting. No complaints of nausea  vomiting  palpitation  or fainting were reported. Robert has not previously sought medical attention for this issue.

Case Report:  Patient Information:   Mr. James Brown  a 65-year-old African American male  who works as a senior manager  presents to the clinic.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of hypertension and Type II diabetes mellitus  both of which were diagnosed 10 years ago for which he is on Amlodipine 10mg daily and Metformin 500mg twice daily. James quit smoking 15 years ago and he reveals a family history of heart disease  with his father dying of a myocardial infarction at age of 60. The patient does not engage in any regular exercise and describes his diet as ""not particularly healthy.""  Presenting Complaints:  James reports experiencing a sensation of ""pressure and tightness"" in his chest – especially during physical activity such as climbing stairs. This pressure usually resolves upon rest. He also reports having fatigue  increased episodes of breathlessness and occasional  albeit minor  bouts of light-headedness. Symptoms have been present for the last 3-4 weeks  gradually increasing over time. James mentions feeling particularly panicked about his chest discomfort.  Initial Thoughts:  With the patient's presenting symptoms of exertional chest pain  shortness of breath  fatigue  and lightheadedness  his history of hypertension and diabetes  his lifestyle factors  and a family history of coronary artery disease (CAD)  there is a high likelihood of CAD.  The subsequent steps for this case should include physical examination  differential diagnoses  investigations (including EKG  stress test  blood tests for cardiac enzymes)  diagnosis  management (such as medications  lifestyle modification  and potential referral for coronary angiography or revascularization).  This case helps medical students to understand how to differentiate CAD from other diseases with similar presentations  manage CAD  and comprehend the relevance of prevention and lifestyle modification in managing CAD. It also emphasizes the concept of cardiovascular risk stratification and decision-making in CAD.

Patient Information & Demographics Name: James Johnson Age: 63 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired teacher Marital Status: Married Smoking status: Smoked 1 pack per day for 25 years  quit 15 years ago Alcohol Consumption: Social drinker  1-2 drinks per week Past Medical History: Hypertension  type II diabetes (both controlled with medication)  Chief Complaint James came to the clinic complaining of increasing shortness of breath and occasional chest pain that he described as a feeling of pressure in his left chest. These episodes have been occurring mostly during physical activities like gardening and climbing home stairs. The chest pain subsides with a bit of rest. James also mentions that he has experienced excessive perspiration during these episodes. He has noted a typical episode lasts 5-10 minutes and has been happening for about 3 months now.  Family History:  James's father passed away in his late 60s from heart disease. His mother is in her early 90s with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. James has two brothers: one with a history of myocardial infarction in his late 60s and the other is healthy.  Current Medications:  1. Metformin for diabetes 2. Lisinopril for hypertension  Review of Systems: 1. Cardiovascular: Positive for chest pain and shortness of breath 2. Respiratory: Negative for cough or wheezing 3. Gastrointestinal: Negative for nausea  vomiting  or heartburn 4. Metabolic: Positive for excessive perspiration during chest pain episodes.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  James was alert and oriented. His blood pressure was 135/85 mm of Hg  heart rate 78 bpm  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and SpO2 96% on room air. His lips and nail beds did not indicate signs of cyanosis. Upon auscultation  heart sounds were normal with no audible murmurs. Pulmonary examination revealed clear breath sounds bilaterally. His abdomen was soft and non-tender. Peripheral pulses were adequate. BMI was noted as 27.   Assessment and Possible Diagnosis: Given the patient's symptoms  age  sex  history of smoking  diabetes  and family history of heart disease  James is at a high risk of coronary artery disease (CAD). The exertional chest pain that subsides with rest  along with shortness of breath  highly suggests stable angina  which is an early symptom of CAD. The case of James Johnson is a potential clinical presentation of coronary artery disease. The intention is to teach medical students about CAD  its relation to other chronic diseases  risk factors  and the importance of early detection and intervention.

Case Report:   Patient Profile: Name: Bill Thompson Age: 68 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Bank Manager Marital Status: Married Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he receives treatment. He has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus and is a former smoker  having successfully quit 15 years ago. He had a healthy lifestyle in his early years but has become more sedentary since retirement a decade ago. He has no known allergies. Both his father and uncle died of heart-related issues in their early 70s.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Thompson visited his physician yesterday after experiencing intermittent chest pain for the past two weeks. The chest pain is described as 'pressure-like'  radiating to his left arm  usually induced by physical effort and relieved by rest/nitroglycerin. Additional symptoms include shortness of breath after mild exertion  fatigue  and occasional bouts of lightheadedness. He denies noticeable palpitations  syncope or episodes of sweating.  Vitals: Blood pressure: 142/90 mm Hg  Heart rate: 82 beats per minute  Regular rhythm  Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute  Oxygen saturation: 96% on room air. Body Mass Index: 29 kg/m^2 Fasting Blood Glucose: 168 mg/dL LDL Cholesterol: 130 mg/dL  These symptoms are raising suspicions of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  possibly angina. The next steps necessitate a thorough examination  diagnosis confirmation via investigations (like ECG  exercise stress test  and if necessary  coronary angiography)  and an appropriate treatment plan involving lifestyle modifications  medication optimization  and possible intervention. This case will allow students to understand how to evaluate  manage and stabilize a patient with suspected CAD and highlight the importance of lifestyle measures in managing such chronic conditions.

Case Report on Coronary Artery Disease:  Patient Information: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last 15 years maintained on Metformin and Losartan. He quit smoking ten years ago but smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for thirty years. He has occasional alcohol intake and follows a diet high in saturated fats. His father died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 68.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with acute chest pain for the past 4 hours. The pain is predominantly central and radiates towards his left arm  accompanied by dyspnea and diaphoresis. He describes it as a tight  squeezing pain  which started while he was gardening. His resting didn't provide any relief.  The case revolves around an elderly man  with a significant cardiovascular risk profile including advanced age  male sex  smoking history  diabetes  hypertension  unhealthy diet  and family history of cardiac disease. Complaints of acute central chest pain radiating to the left arm along with shortness of breath and sweating suggest a probable diagnosis of Acute Coronary Syndrome (which includes ST-Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)  Non-ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction (NSTEMI)  or Unstable Angina). This acute complain in the backdrop of significant CAD risk factors offers an excellent case study for medical students regarding the development  presentation  and management of Coronary Artery Disease.  Following this case presentation  students can be taught about physical examination in such cases  interpretation of ECG and other cardiac markers  differentiating between STEMI  NSTEMI and Unstable Angina  the pathophysiology of CAD  the role of risk factors in development of CAD  along with the immediate and long-term management of the condition. Finally  preventive strategies can be discussed to emphasize the importance of primary prevention in CAD.

Patient Profile:   Name: Mr. Sammy Thompson Age: 65 years Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired banker  Past Medical History:   Mr. Thompson has a 10-year history of hypertension controlled by thiazide diuretics and ACE inhibitors. He quit smoking about 15 years ago  having been a 20-cigarette-per-day smoker for 30 years. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes five years ago  managed with metformin and lifestyle modification. His BMI is 28  indicating he is overweight. His family history reveals that his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 60.  Chief Complaints:  For the past six weeks  Mr. Thompson has been experiencing progressive shortness of breath on exertion and a feeling of tightness in his chest that radiates to his left arm. These episodes typically occur when he is climbing stairs or carrying grocery bags from his car. The symptoms usually subside after five minutes of rest. He also casually mentions that he has been experiencing episodes of dizziness and has awakened from sleep during the night due to shortness of breath. When questioned specifically  he states he has not had any nausea  vomiting  or diaphoresis during these episodes.   Conclusion:  Based off of his increasing symptoms  past medical history  and family history  the patient needs to be thoroughly evaluated for coronary artery disease as his symptoms suggest angina pectoris  potentially unstable  thus warranting urgent medical attention and appropriate management to prevent possible myocardial infarction or other complications.

Patient Information: Mr. Alan Thompson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired carpenter  presented at the clinic.  Key Complaints: Mr. Thompson presented with complaints of recurrent chest pain over the past six weeks. He reported that the feeling is akin to pressure or heaviness in the center of his chest. Notably  these episodes seem to occur during exertion (e.g. mowing the lawn) but tend to resolve with rest.  The patient’s most severe chest pain episode occurred three days prior to the current consult. He noted that during this episode  the pain radiated down his left arm and was accompanied by excessive sweating and a feeling of unease. Although he was not engaged in any strenuous physical activity during this episode  the pain took longer than usual to resolve.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Thompson is a diagnosed hypertensive and his blood pressure has been mostly controlled with medication (lisinopril) over the past ten years. He has a 20-year history of smoking (averaging a pack a day) but quit five years ago. He has dyslipidemia and is on tocopherol. He is also overweight (BMI 29 kg/m2)  has a sedentary lifestyle and consumes a diet high in fat and sodium. There’s also a family history of heart diseases  as his father passed away at age 62 due to myocardial infarction.  No previous history of diabetes mellitus  stroke  kidney diseases or any other chronic illnesses reported.   Physical Examination/ Test Results: Upon examination  it is observed that Mr. Thompson has a blood pressure reading of 145/92  pulse of 78 beats per minute  Oxygen saturation of 95% on room air  and BMI is 29kg/m2. LDL cholesterol levels are high  per his most recent lipid profile.  Given the patient's symptoms  demographic and medical history  the high index of suspicion leans toward coronary artery disease.

Patient Information:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe visited his primary care physician complaining of intermittent chest discomfort upon exertion for the past couple of weeks. The discomfort usually lasts 2-3 minutes and is relieved by rest. He also reports experiencing shortness of breath during these episodes.  Past Medical History:   1. Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  managed mostly with lifestyle modifications. 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 7 years ago  currently on Metformin. 3. Father succumbed to a myocardial infarction at 66. 4. Active smoker with a history of 35 pack-years. 5. Known case of hyperlipidemia  on statins intermittently but not compliant. 6. No history of surgeries or allergies.  Physical Examination:  - Appears generally well  afebrile - Overweight with a body mass index of 30 - Blood Pressure: 145/90 mmHg - Respiratory rate: 18 breaths/minute (unlabored) - Pulse rate: 80 beats/minute  regular rhythm - Oxygen Saturation: 98% on room air - No notable abnormalities on cardiac  pulmonary  or abdominal examination. - Lower extremity examination with no notable edema.  The information given above is intentionally brief and targeted so as to be manageable for a student starting to learn about coronary artery disease (CAD). Further history  examination  and investigation can be discussed and tailored according to the academic level of the learner and the specific learning objectives for the session. More discussion could  for example  focus on the importance of risk factor management  approach to suspected stable angina  or the acute management and stabilization of unstable disease.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Profile: • Name: Mr. X • Age: 63 years  • Sex: Male  • Race: Caucasian  • Occupation: Retired  • Residential Status: Living with wife   Medical History:  Mr. X has been a hypertensive patient for the past 4 years  controlled on medication. He has a history of hyperlipidemia treated with diet modifications and statin therapy. He also has a background of a sedentary lifestyle and stubborn smoking habit of about 40 years  despite repeated health warnings. He has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaints:  Over the past few months  the patient has experienced episodes of chest discomfort upon strenuous activity and climbing stairs that usually fades away with rest. Recently  he experienced one such episode of severe chest pain even at rest  described as a central crushing pain radiating to his left arm  lasting about 20 minutes accompanied by profuse sweating and a sense of impending doom.   This concise case is designed for teaching medical students about Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The aspects to focus on would include relevant history-taking (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking)  the recognition of typical and atypical symptoms  stress related provocation  and the differential diagnosis of chest pain.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: Age: 60 years Gender: Male Ethnicity: Hispanic Occupation: Retired military personnel  Smoking Status: Former smoker with a history of 30 pack years  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago. The patient has been managing these with prescribed medications including an angiotensin-converting-enzyme (ACE) inhibitor for hypertension and Metformin for diabetes. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having had a myocardial infarction at age 65.  Key Complaints: The patient reports experiencing chest discomfort for the past three weeks  particularly on climbing stairs or walking a block. The discomfort is a pressing  central chest pain that radiates to his left arm  lasting around 10 minutes and usually resolving with rest. Recently  the chest pain started to wake him from his sleep. He also reported associated shortness of breath  mild dizziness  profuse sweating during these episodes  and an increasing discomfort with declining exertion in the recent week. The patient denies any nausea  vomiting  or palpitation.   The clinical instructor should focus on the stable angina that seems to have progressed to unstable angina in view of the increased severity  frequency and occurrence at rest. The emphasis should be on the need for further investigation  diagnosis  and possible intervention such as coronary angiography  as well as on modification of risk factors and addition of appropriate medication such as antiplatelet therapy. Special attention should also be paid to the patient's high-risk profile for coronary artery disease considering his age  gender  ethnicity  smoking history  hypertension  diabetes  and family history of early onset cardiovascular disease. It's important we stress the imperative nature of appropriate management to medical students as this could not only improve quality of life but is lifesaving  highlighting the principle 'Time is Muscle' in coronary artery disease.

Patient Information:   Mr.Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer.  Past Medical History:   Type 2 diabetes  hypertensive for 10 years  dyslipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He quit smoking two years ago. He is under medication for hypertension and diabetes and follows a prescribed diet.  Presenting Complaints:   Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department with central chest pain of 6 hours' duration. Describes it as a severe  persistent heaviness in the center of his chest  radiating to his left shoulder and jaw. He also reported associated symptoms including shortness of breath  nausea  and diaphoresis. He rates his pain as 7/10 and says it started while he was mowing his lawn.   On physical examination  he appeared anxious and diaphoretic. His vital signs showed BP - 160/95 mm Hg  P - 88/min  RR - 16/min  Sat O2 - 95% room air  Temp - 98.2°F. Other physical findings were unremarkable.  Pertinent lab findings include blood glucose - 180 mg/dL and cholesterol - 215 mg/dL with LDL –125 mg/dL  HDL - 35 mg/dL  and triglyceride level - 187 mg/dL.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   Mr. John Doe is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who lives in an urban setting. He is a retired mechanical engineer  non-smoker  but a moderate drinker with occasional alcohol use. His Body Mass Index (BMI) is 27  suggesting he's overweight. He lives with his wife and has three adult children.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Doe has a known history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus which is well-controlled by antidiabetic medication. He also suffers from hypertension controlled with angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors. He sustained a minor heart attack 10 years ago when he underwent a successful angioplasty and stent placement for a single-vessel disease. There is a family history of heart disease  with his father and an older brother having suffered heart attacks in their early sixties.  Key Complaints:  He has been experiencing intermittent episodes of chest pain for the past three months. The pain is located in the center of the chest  pressure-like  lasts for 15-20 minutes  and occurs on exertion like climbing stairs or walking uphill. Recently  the frequency has increased to almost every day  and he has noticed it occurring with less exertion than before. He has also started experiencing shortness of breath on exertion within the past month. He has not had any episodes of chest pain at rest  nor has he experienced any symptoms of heart failure like orthopnea or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. He denies symptoms of palpitation  dizziness  or syncope.  Based on the given demographics  medical history  and present complaints  it can be inferred that Mr. Doe is at a high risk of having coronary artery disease. He should be further evaluated with diagnostic tests such as electrocardiogram  exercise stress test  echocardiogram  or coronary angiography as indicated. His diabetes and hypertension also increase his likelihood of developing coronary artery disease. His lifestyle and diet choices could be contributing factors as well.

Case Report: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Information: - Name: Mr. Liam Barnes - Age: 67-years-old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired bank manager - Socioeconomic Status: Middle-class - Ethnicity: Caucasian  Past Medical History: - Diagnosed with high blood pressure and mild type 2 diabetes 10 years ago - Underwent gall bladder removal surgery 5 years ago - Had a minor stroke 3 years ago  with no lasting effects - Former smoker for 30 years  quit 15 years ago - Family history of coronary artery disease (father and grandfather passed away due to heart attacks) - No known allergies  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Barnes presented to his general practitioner  complaining of: - Intermittent chest pain for the past two months  worsened by physical exertion and relieved by rest. - Shortness of breath occurring during moderate physical activity. - Episodes of dizziness and occasional episodes of near syncope. - Unexplained fatigue and general weakness  particularly in the afternoons. - Mild unexplained weight loss over the last two months.  Primary Suspicion: Considering the patient's symptoms  clinical history  and family history of heart disease  the suspicion of coronary artery disease (CAD) is strong. Next steps involve further diagnostic testing to confirm CAD and assess its severity  followed by an appropriate treatment plan  which may include medication  lifestyle modifications  and potentially interventional procedures if necessary.

CASE REPORT:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. John Doe  68 years old  Caucasian male  retired high school teacher  married with three children  non-smoker  and moderate consumer of alcohol.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 20 years ago  for which he takes metformin. He also has a history of hypertension  managed by amlodipine. He suffers from hyperlipidemia and is on statin medication. The patient reported that his father had a fatal myocardial infarction in his early 50s.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented with a two-week history of recurring  mild to moderate chest discomfort. The discomfort was primarily located in the central and slightly to the left side of the chest and was described as a heavy sensation or pressure rather than sharp pain. The episodes usually lasted from 2-10 minutes and often occurred when he was engaged in activities like walking or gardening  but recently he also had attacks while at rest.   He has been experiencing fatigue  occasional shortness of breath during moderate exertion  and unexplained sweating. He reported that these symptoms were not severe enough to seriously disrupt daily activities but acknowledged they were soul-crushing  causing him to slow down. Mr. Doe did not report any significant weight changes  alterations in sleep pattern  or appetite.   Upon hearing that these are symptoms common in coronary artery disease  he felt scared  as his father had died of a heart attack at an early age. Therefore  he proactively consulted his medical practitioner.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Smith Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired engineer Ethnicity: Caucasian Smoking status: Ex-smoker Alcohol consumption: Moderate  two glasses of wine per evening  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension  for which he has been taking Lisinopril 10 mg daily for the last 5 years. His weight has been relatively stable but is slightly above ideal for his height. His body mass index (BMI) is calculated at 27 kg/m2 (Overweight). He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 8 years ago and has been managing it with Metformin 500 mg twice daily. He has also been on a statin (Atorvastatin 10 mg) due to his increased risk of cardiovascular disease. He has been compliant with his medications and lifestyle modifications.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Smith visited the doctor's office  complaining about experiencing chest discomfort over the past two weeks. The pain is retrosternal  usually appears after heavy meals and physical exertion  and is relieved by rest. He also reported experiencing the same discomfort while mowing his lawn  which he resolved by taking a break. He describes the pain as ""a heavy pressure sensation"" that sometimes radiates to his left arm but never to his neck or jaw. He denies any associated symptoms like shortness of breath  palpitations  or loss of consciousness. He has not experienced any episodes of sweating  nausea  or vomiting during these events. He noted that he has been feeling more fatigued than usual  but he attributed that to his age.  This case report should provide a good base for a discussion and training opportunity on the evaluation  management  and differential diagnosis of coronary artery disease in patients with multiple risk factors. Additional patient information such as family history of similar complaints or unexpected cardiac events could also serve as an enriching extension of the medical discussion.

Case Report - Acute Coronary Syndrome (Coronary Artery Disease)  Patient Information:  The patient is Mr. John Doe  55 years old  African-American male  employed as an accountant. He is a resident of the urban setting with a history of Type 2 diabetes and hypertension without any known allergies. He is an active smoker of 20 cigarettes/day for 30+ years and reports moderate alcohol intake on weekends.  Past Medical History: He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus at 45 and hypertension at 50 but has been irregular with his medication. His family history is significant with his father having succumbed to heart disease at the age of 60.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to the ER with central chest pain  initially taken for indigestion  persisting for several hours. He describes the pain as a heavy  crushing sensation  radiating to his left arm  neck  and lower jaw  associated with diaphoresis and shortness of breath. He also reported episodes of discomfort and chest tightness on climbing stairs or during brisk walking for the past 2 months  leading to stop and rest.   Clinical Examination: Mr. Doe appeared anxious  diaphoretic with cold clammy skin. Vital signs examination showed that he was tachycardic (heart rate of 110 bpm)  blood pressure was 165/95mmHg  and respiratory rate was 22 breaths/min  with oxygen saturation at 95% on room air. Cardiovascular examination revealed no murmurs or gallop  and fundoscopy showed signs of hypertensive retinopathy.  Conclusion: The suggestive clinical history and examination points towards coronary artery disease (CAD) which needs to be confirmed by further investigations like ECG  cardiac enzymes  and coronary angiography. This case helps students understand cardinal features of CAD  risk factors  related comorbidities  the importance of lifestyle modifications  and the need for adherence to medication in preventive cardiology. The case aims to emphasize timely diagnosis and efficient management of CAD to prevent complications like acute coronary syndrome  heart failure or life-threatening arrhythmias.

Case Report:   Patient Demographics:   Mr. Robert Davis  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  presents at the clinic. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. He lives with his wife  Mary  and has two adult children. They live in a suburban neighborhood with average socio-economic status. He is moderately active  likes to go for daily walks and gardening.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Davis has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes  both managed with medications for the past 10 years. He is currently on Metformin 500mg twice daily and Lisinopril 20mg daily. His most recent blood works revealed well-controlled blood pressure and blood sugars. He is not aware of any family history of heart disease. His cholesterol levels were borderline high during his last health checkup  six months ago. He has no known drug allergies.   Key Complaints:  For the past 3 weeks  Mr. Davis is complaining of occasional chest discomfort more towards the left side  felt like ""pressure"" or ""squeezing"". The discomfort seems to worsen with exertion (while mowing his lawn or climbing stairs) and usually eases with rest. He has also noticed a progressive decrease in his exercise tolerance over the last month. Two episodes were associated with shortness of breath and one with mild numbness in his left hand. A week ago  he experienced similar discomfort while at rest  which lasted nearly ten minutes  leading his wife to insist on medical consultation. Of note  he has been free of any similar symptoms in the past until these episodes started three weeks ago.  There is no associated palpitations  dizziness  swelling of feet  orthopnea  or paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. The review of other systems is unremarkable. His daily activities are significantly impacted due to his current symptoms. His wife also reports intermittent episodes of nocturnal sweating for the past week but no notable weight changes.  This scenario of progressive exertional chest discomfort in a patient with risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and borderline high cholesterol should raise suspicion for stable angina  caused by coronary artery disease (CAD).

Case Summary:  Patient Profile: Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 65 years old Gender: Male Occupation: Retired  previously worked in high-stress corporate job Race: Caucasian Smoking: Yes  1 pack a day for the past 40 years.  Alcohol: Occasional  2-3 drinks per week. Physical activity: Limited  reliant on car for transportation with light walking.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a medical history of uncontrolled Type 2 diabetes mellitus for the past 10 years that is complicated by diabetic neuropathy. He has been hypertensive for the last 15 years and has been inadequately treated due to medication non-compliance. He has a family history of coronary artery diseases  with his father dying of a myocardial infarction at age 58 and his older brother diagnosed with coronary artery disease at age 60. No known history of allergies.  Chief Complaints: He visits the clinic with the complaints of discomfort in the chest for the past 4 weeks  particularly during physical exertion. The pain typically lasts for 5-10 minutes & it is relieved on rest. The discomfort is described as a heavy sensation or tightness in the chest region  which occasionally radiates to the left arm. He denies any relation to eating with the presentation of the pain. He also reported shortness of breath with moderate exertion which was not present before.  In the past week  the episodes have increased in both frequency and intensity  leading to him seeking medical advice. He also reports occasional lightheadedness but no episodes of syncope. No reported episodes of paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or orthopnea. His appetite has been reduced for the past two weeks and he has noted unintentional weight loss. There's no history suggestive of fever  chills  or night sweats.  This clinical scenario can largely suggest a disturbed coronary blood flow  indicative of coronary artery disease. Further evaluation with cardiac diagnostic tests is required for confirmation and management accordingly.   End of Case.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Name: Mr. John Doe  Age: 62-years-old  Sex: Male  Race: African American  Occupation: Software Engineer  now retired.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe is a diagnosed hypertensive for the past ten years  on medication with consistent monitoring. He has Type II diabetes  controlled with diet modifications and Metformin  diagnosed seven years back. He has a 30-year history of smoking  quit 3 years back. His father died due to myocardial infarction at 65; his mother had stroke at 75. He is moderately active physically and has been managing his weight effectively. His BMI is 26 kg/m2. He regularly consumes alcoholic beverages at social events but not chronically. He has had no past surgeries or hospital admissions and has no known drug allergies.  Current Medication:   1. Lisinopril 20mg for hypertension 2. Metformin 500mg for diabetes  Key Complaints: Mr. Doe visited the consult room complaining of difficulties that started two weeks earlier. He reports experiencing an unusual pressure-like pain in the center of his chest on exertion  like mowing the lawn  going upstairs  or carrying groceries. The pain usually subsides after resting. He also reported episodes of breaking into a cold sweat with these physical activities. Additionally  he has been feeling unusually fatigued for the past week.   Comment: These symptoms indicate possible chronic stable angina. The patient’s risk factors are male sex  middle age  hypertension  diabetes  family history  previous smoking habit  and occasional alcohol consumption. CAD (Coronary artery disease) could be a significant possibility considering these factors. Further evaluation  including laboratory tests such as lipid profile and cardiac enzymes  ECG  echocardiogram  or coronary angiography  may be needed for a final diagnosis.

Case Description:  Patient Information: John  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the outpatient department of the hospital. He works as an accountant and is a heavy smoker with a 40-pack year history. He admits having a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in red meat and saturated fats. He's also been dealing with increasingly high levels of stress at work and rarely finds time for regular physical activity.  Past Medical History: John was diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago and has been receiving treatment for the same. His paternal side of the family has a history of early-onset coronary artery disease (CAD). His father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 50 and his paternal uncle died of CAD at 48. There is no documented history of diabetes mellitus  hypercholesterolemia or any other systemic disease.   Presenting Complaints: The patient reports experiencing intermittent chest pain for the last 3 weeks. The pain  which he describes as pressure-like  primarily occurs with exertion  lasts about 10-15 minutes  and subsides with rest. Recently  he has noticed that the frequency of these episodes has increased. He has experienced these episodes of chest pain even while sitting at his desk or climbing stairs at home. He also mentions experiencing episodes of shortness of breath and feeling unusually fatigued after mild physical exertion over the past week.  Suspected Diagnosis: Considering the patient's age  sex  smoking history  family history  increased levels of stress  irregular and unhealthy diet  and presenting complaints  a provisional diagnosis of Coronary Artery Disease is made.  Further evaluation is required to confirm the diagnosis and assess the severity of the condition. This might include but is not limited to- Electrocardiogram  Exercise Stress Test  and/or Coronary angiography. Educational emphasis here would include identifying risk factors  recognizing typical and atypical symptoms  learning about diagnostic process and formulating a treatment plan.

Patient Case Report  Patient Demographics:  Mr. James Mitchell  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  retired police officer  married with three children. Non-smoker and non-alcoholic. Resides in a suburban area.  Past Medical History: He has been hypertensive for the past 10 years  controlled with lifestyle modifications and medication (Lisinopril). He also has Type 2 diabetes managed with Metformin for 8 years now. He had an episode of Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) 3 years ago with full recovery. Family history reveals his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 59.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Mitchell visited his primary care physician complaining of intermittent chest pain primarily located in the center/left side of the chest area that started about 2 months ago. The chest pain is described as pressure-like  typically lasting for 10-15 minutes  and usually occurs while he is doing gardening work or climbing stairs. The chest pain is relieved with rest.   Recently  the chest pain episodes have been occurring more frequently and with less physical exertion than before. Occasionally  the chest pain is accompanied by shortness of breath and cold sweats. He also reported a 10 lbs unintentional weight loss in the past 6 months.  In addition to these  Mr. Mitchell also indicated episodes of lightheadedness  fatigue  and nocturnal awakenings. He denied any symptoms of fever  cough  palpitation  or lower limb swelling.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  - Name: Joseph Miller - Age: 66 years old - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired CPA - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Marital Status: Married - Living Situation: Lives with his wife in a suburban area  Past Medical History:  The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  diagnosed 10 years ago. Partially controlled with medication (lisinopril 20mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 40mg once a day for hyperlipidemia). He has a 20 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease with his father having a myocardial infarction at the age of 55. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a body mass index (BMI) of 28  indicating that he is overweight. He reports moderate alcohol intake.  Key Complaints:  Joseph came to the clinic complaining of intermittent and progressively worsening chest pain over the last couple of months  especially during exertion or stress and relieved with rest. He describes it as a heavy  squeezing sensation. That is sometimes accompanied by feelings of indigestion. He also mentions shortness of breath on climbing stairs or walking uphill  as well as occasional episodes of dizziness. He denies any nausea  vomiting  or sweating during these episodes.   The chest pain lasted longer and was not relieved by rest during an episode that occurred last night  causing him to visit the emergency department. There has been no previous diagnostic workup for his symptoms.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 63 Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Bank Officer Current Residency: Miami  Florida  Presenting complaint:  The patient complains of mid-sternal chest pain that radiates to his left shoulder and jaw. The pain has been progressively worsening over the last few months  but in the past week has occurred with shorter periods of exertion. He also mentions episodes of shortness of breath  dizziness  and nausea.  Past Medical History: John was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 7 years ago. He also has a 20-year history of hypertension. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago but had a 20 pack-year history before quitting. His father died due to myocardial infarction at the age of 65.   Current Medications:  Metformin 1000mg twice daily  Lisinopril 20mg once daily  Amlodipine 5mg once daily.  Physical Examination: His Body Mass Index is 28  and his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. The rest of his physical examination is unremarkable.  Characteristic Symptoms: Chest pain described as tightness or pressure occurring on exertion and relieved by rest  shortness of breath  and dizziness are characteristic of angina pectoris which is a classic symptom of coronary artery disease. The presence of risk factors such as age  male sex  diabetes  hypertension  family history of coronary artery disease  and smoking further points towards the diagnosis of coronary artery disease.

Patient Case:      Patient Information:  Mr. Samuel Lawrence  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  retired bank manager.  Present Complaints:  Complained of progressive chest pain  specifically described as pressure-like  radiating to the neck and left arm. According to Mr. Lawrence  these episodes often occur during physical exertion and are relieved by rest. He has also noticed increasing shortness of breath over the past three months and complained of fatigue and occasional dizziness.  Past Medical History:  1. History of hypertension for the past ten years  managed with Lisinopril 10mg daily. 2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed five years prior  managed with Metformin 500mg twice daily. 3. Past smoker  quit 10 years ago. He smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. 4. Father died of a heart attack at the age of 60.  Family History:  His father had a history of coronary artery disease and suffered from a fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 60. His younger brother  currently 62  was recently diagnosed with coronary artery disease.  Social History:  He lives with his wife who assists with his care. He has two adult children who live in other states. He consumes alcohol occasionally  usually wine with dinner. He is a retired bank manager leading a sedentary lifestyle.  Review of Systems:  No history of palpitations  syncope  orthopnea  paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea  or edema. He frequently feels an acid-like taste in his mouth post meals  which he managed with over-the-counter antacids. Conscious changes in urine volume  frequency  or color not reported. Regular bowel habits.  The purpose of this case is to highlight the key considerations in the evaluation  diagnosis  and management of coronary artery disease. The risk factors present include the patient’s age  sex  medical history with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  history of smoking  family history of heart disease  sedentary lifestyle  and reported symptoms.

Patient Information: Mr. John Thompson  65-year-old Caucasian male  retired school teacher  residing in a suburban neighborhood with his wife.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension for the past ten years  which is controlled with medication. Identified as a type 2 diabetic five years ago  he manages his condition with oral hypoglycemic agents. He smokes approximately 10 cigarettes per day for the past 20 years. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 70.   Chief Complaints:  Mr. Thompson presents to the medical facility complaining of recurrent chest pain for the last few months. He describes the pain as a heavy  squeezing feeling concentrated in the center of his chest  which radiates towards his left arm. He further reports that the pain is more frequent during physical activities or emotional stress but is relieved at rest. He also mentions experiencing shortness of breath  increased fatigue  and episodes of lightheadedness.  Preliminary Diagnosis: The patient's age  sex  past medical history- notably hypertension  type 2 diabetes  smoking habit  and the nature of his symptoms suggest a possible case of Coronary Artery Disease (CAD). The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through appropriate investigations and initiate management soon due to the high risk of myocardial ischemia  and consequent myocardial infarction or heart failure.   Objective: With this case  medical students can learn about the classic presentation of CAD  understand the risk factors contributing to this condition  as well as familiarize themselves with appropriate diagnostic and management strategies.

Patient Case Summary:  Patient Information: Albert  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic for a regular check-up. He lives alone and prior to his retirement  he worked as a truck driver for over 30 years. He admits to smoking a pack of cigarettes every day for the past 35 years. He consumes alcohol only on social occasions and has poor dietary habits  preferring fast food over home-cooked meals. Albert has been fairly healthy all his life and therefore does not partake in regular physical activity; his weight categorizes him as obese.
