Past Medical History: Albert was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago which he controls with metformin and insulin. He also has hypertension  managed with amlodipine. Though he was advised to quit smoking after his diagnosis  he has been unable to do so. His family history reveals his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 62 and his mother has chronic hypertension.   Key Complaints: Today  Albert expresses concerns about intermittent  dull  central chest pain over the past few weeks. He describes the pain as pressure-like  radiating to his left arm and lasting around 10-15 minutes  typically induced by physical exertion such as walking his dog or climbing stairs. He also describes a new onset of shortness of breath and mild fatigue over the same period. He has taken over-the-counter antacids  considering it to be heartburn initially  but with no relief.  Based on the patient's complaints  his risk factors (smoking  obesity  lack of exercise  type 2 diabetes  hypertension  and family history)  and the characteristics of his chest pain (exertional  pressure-like  radiating to the arm)  a suspicion of coronary artery disease would be appropriate. Further diagnostic testing should be conducted to confirm this hypothesis and evaluate the extent of Albert's potential disease.

Patient Case: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: Patient Name: John Doe Age: 66 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Civil Engineer Insurance: Medicare  Past Medical History: Chronic hypertension for 10 years Type 2 diabetes for 7 years History of smoking: 20 cigarettes/day for 40 years  quit 5 years ago Father died of a heart attack at age 62  and mother had stroke at age 70 No known drug allergies   Key Complaints: Presented to the emergency department with chief complaints of: 1. Acute  severe chest pain  described as crushing pressure radiating to the left arm and jaw.  2. Shortness of breath for the last 2 hours. 3. Feeling of heaviness and tightness in the chest. 4. Feeling lightheaded and dizzy. 5. Brief episodes of sweating.  Additional Notes:  The pain began while the patient was doing yard work. Rest and sublingual nitroglycerin did not relieve symptoms. The patient lives alone and called for an ambulance when symptoms did not resolve.  The patient denies prior episodes of similar pain. He follows up regularly with his primary care physician and is compliant with his hypertension and diabetes medications. He has limited exercise tolerance due to old age but has not noticed any decline recently. BMIs calculated during his regular visits indicate that he is overweight.  The comprehensive training case should elaborate on physical examination  laboratory and diagnostic imaging findings  definitive diagnosis  medical and possible surgical management options  and necessary lifestyle changes for coronary artery disease management.

Patient Case Profile  Patient Information:  - Name: James Smith - Age: 62 years - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired Banker - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Marital Status: Married  Past Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed 15 years ago  on regular medication ACE inhibitors. 2. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2: Diagnosed 10 years ago. Controlled on metformin. 3. Smoking: 1 pack/day for the past 40 years. 4. Family History: Father suffered from myocardial infarction at the age of 60  mother has hypertension.  Key Complaints: 1. Mr. Smith recently started experiencing intermittent chest pain  typically on exertion. 2. He describes the pain as ""heavy"" and ""crushing "" often radiating to his left jaw and arm. 4. Episodes usually last 15-20 minutes  relieved by rest. 5. He has reported an episode of chest pain during sleep. 6. He also mentioned experiencing bouts of breathlessness and fatigue during his daily walks which never happened before. 7. He admitted his symptoms are increasing in frequency and severity over the past week.  This case of Mr. Smith challenges medical students to focus on the correlation between risk factors  symptoms  and Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)  emphasizing the importance of taking an exhaustive history  correctly interpreting reported symptoms (typical angina  increase in severity and frequency)  and recognizing potential CAD. It showcases the importance of early identification and prompt management of this life-threatening condition.

Case Study: Coronary Artery Disease  Patient Demographics: - Name: John Smith - Age: 65 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired police officer  Past Medical History: John has been managing Type II diabetes mellitus for the past 15 years  with moderate control  using Metformin. He has moderate hypertension and is taking Lisinopril to manage it. His cholesterol levels have been slightly high over the past few years and he takes Atorvastatin for it. He has a 20-year history of smoking one pack a day  although he quit eight years ago. His father passed away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 70 and one of his two older brothers had a cardiovascular event at 67. John does not regularly exercise and acknowledges to being overweight.  Key Complaints: For the past two months  John Smith has been experiencing occasional chest pain while carrying heavy items and during intense emotions  which he initially dismissed as indigestion. The pain in the chest is dull and heavy in nature  located at the center and radiating to left arm  often accompanied by a slight shortness of breath. However  recently John experienced a chest pain episode while at rest watching TV which was more severe than previous times and lasted for about 10 minutes. He also mentions feeling fatigued more quickly than usual for the past few weeks.  This case would facilitate learning objectives about risk factors  presentation  and progression of coronary artery disease  as well as its management approach and the importance of lifestyle modifications in managing such chronic diseases. The students should be guided to analyze the patient’s risk factors  understand the symptoms  and design an appropriate diagnostic and treatment plan.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Thomas Green Age: 65 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired civil engineer  Medical History: Mr. Green has a 15-year history of Type 2 diabetes mellitus which has been generally well controlled with metformin and a dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitor (sitagliptin). He also has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which have been managed with a low-dose thiazide diuretic (hydrochlorothiazide) and a statin (atorvastatin)  respectively. He had a smoking history (30-pack years) but quit 20 years ago. The patient has a family history of heart disease with both his father and elder brother having myocardial infarctions in their early sixties.  Key Complaints: Mr. Green reports recently experiencing episodes of chest discomfort. The pain  described as a pressure-like sensation in the center of his chest  is associated with shortness of breath and it often occurs after climbing a flight of stairs at his home and occasionally after meals. The discomfort usually eases within 10-15 minutes of resting.  Presentation: On physical examination  he is found to be overweight with a BMI of 28. His blood pressure is elevated at 145/95 mmHg and his heart rate is regular at 75 beats per minute. No abnormalities are detected during cardiac or lung auscultation. His fasting blood glucose levels are within the acceptable range for his diabetes  but his low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels have been trending upward despite medication.  Possible Learning Objectives: - Understand and recognize the signs and symptoms of coronary artery disease (CAD). - Associate key risk factors such as diabetes  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and family history to CAD. - Conduct a comprehensive patient assessment considering the past medical history and current complaints. - Develop a reasonable differential diagnosis and recommend relevant investigations to confirm the diagnosis. - Discuss the influence of lifestyle modifications and medication regime on the management and outcomes of CAD.

Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  a 58-year-old Caucasian male  Background: Occupation: Software engineer Smoking history: One pack of cigarettes per day for the last 30 years Drinking history: Occasional; two to three beers per week Exercise: Infrequent; walks during lunch breaks  History of Present Illness: Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with complaints of recurring chest pain especially during his walks in the past 3 weeks. He described it as a squeezing sensation radiating to the left arm  accompanied by shortness of breath  fatigue  and occasional nausea.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed 6 years ago  under treatment with lisinopril - Type 2 Diabetes diagnosed 4 years ago  controlled with metformin - High Cholesterol diagnosed 2 years ago  currently on atorvastatin - Father passed away from a heart attack at age 50  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Smith appears overweight. His BMI is 28. Vital signs include a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 96 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. Auscultation reveals no additional heart sounds  murmurs  or rubs. Lung sounds are clear.  This case delves into coronary artery disease (CAD). The typical patient with CAD is often a male over 45 years old or a female over 55 years old with one or more risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  dyslipidemia  obesity  sedentary lifestyle  cigarette smoking  or a family history of heart disease. The classic symptom is angina  characterized by chest pain that can radiate to the left arm or jaw  often precipitated by exertion and relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. Other potential signs and symptoms include fatigue  shortness of breath  syncope  sweating  nausea  and vomiting.

Patient Case Report  Patient Information: Name: John Smith Age: 66 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired software engineer  Past Medical History: John is a non-smoker and non-alcoholic. He has a confirmed history of hypertension and Type II diabetes for which he takes Metformin. John has a family history of coronary artery disease; his father suffered from a heart attack at the age of 58. There are no other significant components to his past medical or surgical history. He also has no known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaint: John presented to the clinic with a three week history of intermittent chest discomfort  often occurring with a slight exertion such as climbing stairs and relieved by rest within a few minutes. Lasting about 5-10 minutes each time  he describes the pain as a 'heavy' sensation centrally located in his chest. He has also recently started experiencing shortness of breath whilst attending his regular exercise classes  something which he never experienced before.  Recent Incident: Over the last 24 hours  his chest pain has increased in intensity and has been experienced at rest as well. Alongside this  John also noted increased episodes of breathlessness and an episode of diaphoresis (excessive sweating). This combination of symptoms compelled him and his wife to seek immediate medical attention.

Patient Profile:  Demographics: - Name: John Doe - Age: 67 years - Gender: Male  - Occupation: Retired Engineer  - Marital status: Married - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Geography: Urban   Past Medical History: - Hypertension: Diagnosed 10 years prior - Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed 7 years prior - Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed 5 years ago - No history of congenital heart disease or clotting disorders - Non-smoker  Non-drinker  - Family history of cardiovascular disease: father died of a heart attack at 60  Key Complaints: In the last four weeks  John has noticed an increasing frequency of discomfort in the chest  especially during exercise or physical activity. The discomfort seems to radiate towards the left arm and occasionally to the jaw. Typically  the pain subsides with rest. He has also reported feeling unusually fatigued and experiencing shortness of breath more frequently  along with bouts of dizziness. He also mentions waking up on occasional nights due to mild chest discomfort.   Recently  he experienced a more intense episode of chest tightness while mowing his lawn that took longer than usual to subside at rest  which pushed him to seek medical advice. He denies any recent cold/flue symptoms  fevers  cough  or symptoms of hyperglycemia  and shows no signs of clinical depression. His daily diabetes and hypertension medications include metformin  lisinopril  and atorvastatin.  (This case specifically presents symptoms of stable angina which is an early stage of coronary artery disease).

Patient Case:  Name: John Doe Age: 65 years Gender: Male Race: African American Occupation: Retired Engineer Location: Houston  Texas  Past Medical History: John has a 20 years history of uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus  hypertension (HTN)  and hyperlipidemia. He smokes one pack of cigarettes a day and has done so for the last 40 years. He reports inattentiveness to his diet  with a preference for meat and processed foods. His medications include Metformin  Lisinopril  and Atorvastatin. His father had an MI at age 60.  Presenting Complaints: John attends his annual review and complains of intermittent chest pain for the past two weeks which he initially thought was heartburn. The pain is substernal  radiating to his left arm with associated shortness of breath. He admits that the pain gets worse when he tries to walk to his mailbox or exert himself in any way but usually subsides with rest.  Physical Exam: He is obese (BMI 31)  pale  and appears visibly worried. His heart rate is 80/min  BP is 160/95 mm Hg  and his respiratory rate is 18 breaths/min  oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. His cardiovascular exam reveals a strong regular pulse. There are no audible murmurs or gallops  and lungs are clear to auscultation.  Upon these parameters  the preliminary diagnosis could be suspected as Chronic Stable Angina secondary to probable Coronary Artery Disease. This case provides the learning platform to understand the pathology  risk factors  assessing steps  differential diagnosis  and management of Coronary Artery Disease.

Patient: Mr. John Smith Age: 68 years old Occupation: Retired Truck Driver Ethnicity: Caucasian Sex: Male Marital status: Married Location: Midwest  United States  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension diagnosed 10 years ago  under control with Lisinopril 2. Type II Diabetes Mellitus diagnosed 15 years ago  managed with Metformin 3. High cholesterol diagnosed 5 years ago  managed with Simvastatin 4. Mild obesity  BMI 30  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith has come to the outpatient department complaining of a persisting chest discomfort which he describes as ""pressure"" rather than a sharp pain. It has been occurring on and off for the last two months  mainly on exertion like when he attempts to shovel the snow or mow the lawn and usually subsides with rest.   Lately  he noticed it had become more frequent and was waking him at night and seemed unrelated to physical activity. Additionally  he mentioned episodes of breathlessness during moderate activities that were previously easy for him.   Smoking status: Smoked one pack of cigarettes a day for the last 35 years. He quit 8 years ago. Alcohol: Occasionally in moderation Exercise: Minimal; mostly sedentary since retirement Diet: High in processed and salty foods with limited intake of fruits and vegetables.    Family history: His father had a myocardial infarction and passed away at the age of 72.  On today's visit  his blood pressure is adequately controlled  BMI remains at 30  and his fasting glucose reveals good diabetes control. His latest cholesterol panel shows borderline elevated LDL cholesterol.   The patient has recognized these symptoms as unusual and is eager to understand the cause of his discomfort. He is compliant with his medication. However  his lifestyle changes are limited.   This scenario alludes to stable angina progressing to unstable angina in the setting of coronary artery disease. The students should formulate differentials that would cover other potential reasons for chest pain and dyspnea  interpret findings  and develop an appropriate diagnostic and treatment plan for Mr. Smith.
